story:
Who

Clownhouse, Cal Walker and the creative team of The Anxiety Variety Show!

What

The Anxiety Variety Show, performing as a part of Rhinofest 2020.

Where

Premiers at the Prop Thtr in Chicago, IL. However! It has the potential to tour-- this is the part that requires your support.

Why

Clownhouse is a brand-new company that puts the story before the pocketbook.  A production requires many different ingredients, and while there is only one actor on the stage, there are numerous creatives who work to make this show the best it can be.  Many of these people have chosen this show because it is an important story to tell. That being said, financial support will allow for a better production quality come showtime, and it allows for the show to continue to perform in other venues such as festivals, limited-run circuits, and even in secondary and post-secondary educational sectors.

story:
ENOUGH!!! Let's make NOT ENOUGH happen in 2016.

Not Enough is a new solo show about anxiety. It is touring Toronto, Winnipeg, Edmonton, and Vancouver this summer 2016. It's written by myself, Megan Phillips, (PEOPLE SUCK, BREAKING VELOCITY), and directed/dramaturged by TJ Dawe (POST SECRET: THE SHOW, MEDICINE).

I’m SO excited to share this project with the world! And now I need YOUR HELP to make it real!


According to the Anxiety & Depression Association of America:

“Anxiety disorders are the most common psychiatric illnesses affecting children and adults. An estimated 40 million American adults suffer from anxiety disorders.”

– source: http://www.adaa.org/understanding-anxiety

… and I didn’t even know I had it.

Until, sitting in a tiny room  with a hundred other people, I was 4 days into an intense silent meditation retreat... when I came face-to-face with demons I didn't even know existed. Suddenly, I saw with extreme clarity all of the ways anxiety has been sabotaging me since childhood... and I had to fight for my life. Hard.

And when I got home, coming out the other side, I did what any sane, self-respecting person would do in this situation.

I got a loop pedal, a dramaturg, and I wrote a show about my story.


And now I have the opportunity to take that show across Canada.

Not many people know that Fringe artists are ENTIRELY self-supporting when on the road!

Finances include the following:

$1500 - TRANSPORTATION:  Flights/gas/ground transportation from Vancouver to Toronto, Winnipeg, Edmonton, Vancouver

$2500 - FESTIVAL, VENUE FEES, AND DIRECTOR/DRAMATURG HONORARIUM: Fringe artists need to pay for our spot in the festival, and also TJ deserves every penny.

$1000 - SHOW TECHNICAL NEEDS: Loop pedal, set costs,other equipment rented in each city

$1000 - MARKETING MATERIALS

=$6000

                                   

$6000? But why are you only asking for $3500??

I believe so strongly in this project that I am willing to pay for it myself.

Goal 1: $3500 pays for dramaturgy, technical needs, and transportation.

Goal 2: $5000 pays for all of the above, plus marketing materials and some venue fees

Goal 3: $6000+ after that, this will cover all of the above, all venue fees, plus all living expenses on the tour!

Your support means the world in bringing this show to life. ENOUGH... let's change the story.



Why should I invest in this show?

My mission is to write shows that alchemize the struggle of our human existence. Humour through truth. Lofty goal? Sure. Necessary? Absolutely. The ultimate goal is to have a show for schools, conventions, and anywhere else to reach people who suffer from/live with anxiety.  We always have more control than this disorder likes us to think, so my hope is to offer a story of possibility to others.


How can I support the show?

Attend a Performance: Come see what the show is all about!

Shout-out on Social Media: @megnatphil, #notenoughshow, or join my mailling list at meganphillips.com. All buzz is helpful!

Make a Donation: For yourself, or in the name/memory of others.



Thank you so much for your time ... together, we can change the story.

YOU ARE ENOUGH.

M




Photos: (c) Kia Vance 2016
Poster Design: (c) Carla Mah 2016
Makeup by Sarah Elizabeth 
Video Shot, Directed by Ashley Slater

--

2016 SCHEDULE:

TORONTO - June 2016

WINNIPEG - July 13-24, 2016

EDMONTON - Aug 11-21, 2016

VANCOUVER - Sept 8-18, 2016


ABOUT THE CREATOR:


"Phillips is a warm, generous, and brave performer" - Vancouver Courier

"NNNN" - NOW Magazine

"Beautiful voice and personable acting" - Mooney on Theatre

meganphillips.com

story:
Summary

Ad Hoc Beaumont is passionate about bringing NEW and exciting theatre to Southeast Texas! We prove that theatre is still a fresh and vital art. That's why we are bringing "The Other Mozart" to Beaumont!

"The Other Mozart" by Sylvia Milo tells the story of Nannerl Mozart, the sister of Amadeus. A prodigy, a keyboard virtuoso and composer who toured Europe performing with her brother to equal acclaim, Nannerl's story faded. This one-woman show uses family letters to tell the compelling true story of this other Mozart.

With the opulent beauty of a stunning 18-foot dress, elaborate hair design, the sweet smells of perfume and clouds of dusting powder rising from the stage, the performance creates a multi-sensual experience and transports the audience into a world of outsized beauty and delight -- but also of overwhelming restrictions and prejudice for women.

This venture builds on the success of previous Ad Hoc Beaumont productions such as:

"My Aim is True" at Beaumont's Spindletop Gladys City Boomtown Museum in 2013. (Article HERE: http://blog.beaumontenterprise.com/cat5/2013/02/07/wild-wild-theater/#9789101=0)

AND

"Butcher Holler Here We Come!" at the Betty Greenberg Center for Performing Arts in 2014. (Article HERE: http://blog.beaumontenterprise.com/cat5/2014/06/05/butcher-holler-brings-viewers-into-the-depths-of-the-human-experience/#16731101=0)

What We Need

Doing a show like this is expensive!

Your donation will GREATLY help us get the cast, crew, costumes and props to Southeast Texas from NYC.

We also need funds for marketing and PR - printing postcards, posters, programs, etc.

Impact

"The Other Mozart" will run for five nights at the Betty Greenberg Center for Performing Arts in Beaumont - June 4-6 and June 12-13.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Buy a ticket and come see the show. Tickets are $20 each available at beaumontcommunityplayers.com or email adhocbeaumont@gmail.com
  • Talk it up! Spread the word on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter.

story:
Help A Theatre Company 

Take Off Into the Unknown!

Wily West is entering a new phase and to celebrate, we are launching two new shows in rep this summer.  One will take us into Outer Space and the unknown territory of Mars. The other brings us back to Earth where a strange and catastrophic event has rocked a city.

Are the problems for humanity the same on Mars as they are on Earth? This is one of the questions 9 Bay Area Playwrights are asking with these two shows.

ZERO HOUR:  The Mars Experiment

This year we are going to be one of the first theatre companies in the U.S. to write about the first colony on Mars!   We have commissioned 9 outstanding local Bay Area playwrights write for the next 6 weeks, gathering a range of perspectives, about what it would be like to actually be the first humans to colonize Mars.   Audiences will get to take the ride from Earth to Mars!

We are writing the TV show before the TV show about the first Colony on Mars!  

Would you leave everything behind, all the comforts of earthly life—friends, family, ice cream, sex—for the experiment? To live in isolation and the experience taped for a reality show for the people back home on Earth, so that you can be a pioneer, the first to colonize the planet Mars? These six humans did. They left their jobs. Some lost their families. They underwent physical and mental evaluations. They signed contracts. They trained. They made love for the last time. And at ZERO HOUR, they made peace with their decision. But that was six months and sixty-eight days ago.

I SAW IT.

Did you? An anomalous event has occurred. A city in ruins. Some are saying it wasn’t an act of nature, but a creature, a shadow, a…something. Rumors run rampant, suspicions run high. The #ISawIt hashtag has gone viral. Unsubstantiated reports, conspiracy theories, panic! Does Isla have the answers everyone wants? The government thinks so. Inside an interrogation room, Isla is questioned while outside, a city tries to recover.

Who We Are

Wily West Productions is an award-winning Bay Area Theatre company devoted to presenting world premiere plays by local playwrights.   We are scrappy, nimble, innovative, and entirely dependent on private funding and the efforts of our team.  Creating, maintaining, and sustaining an independent theatre company is hard work!  And it’s risky! Like going to Mars. Or staying alive on Earth.  

With your help, there may be hope for humanity (and independent theater) yet!

What We Need

Rather than just do a series of staged readings we actually want to fully stage these plays!  We are working with up-and-coming Director Ariel Craft (Co-Artistic Director of Bread Box Theatre Company) to create a fully realized production at the Exit Theatre in San Francisco!    

HOW YOUR CONTRIBUTION CAN HELP

Your support is crucial.   Even a small contribution will make a big difference for this campaign.  You will be supporting over 20 local artists with this ONE project.  If we reach goal we will be able to  present our two summer shows in full color and also add an additional week of staged readings which could lead into Wily West presenting shows in 2016.  

All funds will go to the essentials:  

·  Rehearsal Space

·  Costumes - we need space suits!

·  Sets - materials for our set!

·  Venue Rent - we will be able to run more than 3 weeks!

·  Artist/writer stipends

CONTRIBUTIONS OF $40 COME WITH TICKETS!

Seating to Mars is limited.   Why wait in line or be forced to buy over-priced tickets from scalpers when you can secure your seats now?

MORE ABOUT WILY WEST

Wily West Productions formed in 2008 to provide a locally run, locally cast, locally produced outlet for new plays by Bay Area playwrights.  The production team members have a combined background totaling several dozen productions of various sizes and budgets from New York to Salt Lake City and San Francisco.  Wily West is now in its sixth full season and has produced critically acclaimed and award-winning productions. We value not only quality production elements, but strive for a creative and fun production environment. 

AWARDS AND HONORS:

2010 Listed as one of the "Top 10 Productions of 2010" by SF BAY TIMES

2013 Bay Area Theatre Critics Circle Award for Best Original Script 

2013 Bay Area Theatre Critics Circle Award Nomination for Best Featured Actor

2014 Theatre Bay Area Award for Outstanding World Premiere

2014 Theatre Bay Area Award for Outstanding Featured Female Actor

and TWO shows were nominated for the 2014 Theatre Bay Area Award for Outstanding Anthology

That we received any recognition, given our small budget, is a testament to the excellent work of our team.  So donating funds to Wily West means you are giving to an under dog...but the dog has talent!

You Can Help

Help us meet our goal.  No donation is too small.  Everything helps!  

For those among you who have never attended one of our shows, this is your golden opportunity. Attend an exciting, new theatrical production. And maybe even assuage some guilt. (And guilt is bad.) You can be a true patron of the arts for artists that actually live and work in San Francisco. And who hasn't secretly imagined him or herself a Lorenzo de' Medici or a Queen Elizabeth I?

story:
My Story


I was born at Secret Heart Medical Center at 12:53 am on December 5, 2000. I was 3 months early and 2 pounds. I was barely alive, but after two months in the hospital, I was brought home on the day of love February 14, 2001. My full name is Alaja Oni Le’alla Badalich, which means Understanding, Strength, and Adoration. I was a strong baby and considered a miracle baby. For being born so early I have athsma but that never gets in the way of anything. I’m from Eugene, OR. I attend Roosevelt middle school and I am a straight A student.

My family is also a big part of my life. I live with my mom, step-Dad, and my little half-brother. My grandparents also live in Eugene too, while my cousins and aunts all live in California. I love my family so much, they give so much support to me, and without them I am sure that I wouldn't be who I am today. I also love my friends, they are always lending a helping hand, and I can always count on them.

I’am a dancer! I dance to express not to impress. When I dance everything fades away in my life that is bothering me even if its dance stressing me out. I like to say that dance is my “escape.” Each movement, even if its just a turn, a balance, a pointed foot, A pile, or even one hand guiding your body through its movement, that little rise, ronde de jambe, any movement you think is small is really big. Because if you didn't have the small movements we wouldn't make the big ones so beautiful. Each moment of the movement gets me closer to finding myself, finding who I am on the inside. We are all different thats what makes us unique. I think if I didn’t dance I wouldn't be unique. 


As an artist I want to inspire people, Because everyday not just dancers but my friends, family, and even school teachers inspire me to “dream big and hope my dreams come true” and work my hardest to be the best I can be. I hope to be in a company one day to be a principal dancer and be able to dance ballet and contemporary/improvisation because I have a love for both. Ballet is very classical and elegant, then we have contemporary/improvisation where you have to be able to feel and connect with yourself to show the beauty of it. Either way to be a dancer you must stand out, you must be passionate, obsessed, and willing to sacrifice you body. 

I started dancing when I was 2 years old. I can’t remember a time when I wasn't dancing. I never really thought of dancing as career until I turned 11 and thats when started taking it seriously. I feel like dancing and I have this connection thats so hard to express in words it can only be expressed in dance it self.  I have been dancing at Oregon Ballet Academy since I was 5. I take ballet, contemporary/improv, and Pilates. I usually dance around  5-7 days a week. I recently Auditioned for Summer Dance Lab, Alonzo King Lines Ballet, and Texas Ballet Theater. I was excepted into all 3. I chose Texas Ballet Theater and received a 50% scholarship. Even with the scholarship my family and I can not afford it.

What We Need & What You Get

I need 4,200$ for: The rest of my tuition(975$) , Housing ( 2,250), Transportation, Meal plan, Activities and Airfare.
The perks to donating: for 50$ you get a personal Facebook or Instagram Shout-out from Alaja, for 100$ you get a personalized " Thank you" Dance to your favorite song with a mini tutorial on the steps,and for 1000$ you get a Gift Package with one signed pair of point shoes by Alaja, two 5x7 signed Dance photos of Alaja, One 18x24 original drawing of Alaja,and one T-shirt that says" I help make dreams come true"
All of the money goes towards my trip even if the goal is exceeded or not reached!


The Impact

I think Texas ballet theater will help me, be a better dancer, teach me to take risks in my dancing, I also think that it will teach me to be more determined to succeed. I also will get one step closer to making my dreams come true

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute money, then please spread the word on your social media sites and to your friends.

What We Need & What You GetI need 4,200$ for: The rest of my tuition(975$) , Housing ( 2,250), Transportation, Meal plan, Activities and Airfare.The perks to donating: for 50$ you get a personal Facebook or Instagram Shout-out from Alaja, for 100$ you get a personalized " Thank you" Dance to your favorite song with a mini tutorial on the steps,and for 1000$ you get a Gift Package with one signed pair of point shoes by Alaja, two 5x7 signed Dance photos of Alaja, One 18x24 original drawing of Alaja,and one T-shirt that says" I help make dreams come true"All of the money goes towards my trip even if the goal is exceeded or not reached!


The ImpactI think Texas ballet theater will help me, be a better dancer, teach me to take risks in my dancing, I also think that it will teach me to be more determined to succeed. I also will get one step closer to making my dreams come trueOther Ways You Can HelpIf you can not contribute money, then please spread the word on your social media sites and to your friends.

story:
Short Summary

Hello Indiegogo world, 

My name is Kali and i'm the Creative Director of what we call Project X Collective ( mostly because we haven't found a name yet ... but kinda catchy, right?). Since I was a little girl travelling with the circus, I imagined what it would be like to have my own show and bring to the world something new and exciting. Over the past few years i've met likeminded people who have shown a similar interest. To give young, talented emerging artists a chance to shine. Wether in the production aspect of a creation or as a performer. Our goal is to provide these opportunities and show the world what we come up with. Most of us met whilst at the Banff Arts Center in their Work Study program - we've now all gone our own way but still keep mulling around this idea of making something ourselves. I thought it was time we did something about it but without YOU, our contributors, we would never have the opportunity to follow one of our biggest dreams. so THANK YOU from all of us. Your contribution means the world to us, it will be bringing a very interesting blend of people together from various backgrounds to create something we can all universally understand and enjoy together. 

Meet the Team

Kali Grenier-Prieur  -  Creative Director
Amelia Scott - Video and Interactive Media Designer
Jessica MacDuff - Props and Costumes Designer
Nicholas Vincent - Lighting Designer
Dalyanne Gauthier - Buisness Consultant & Social Media


What We Need & What You Get

Funding from this campaign will go towards various aspects of our production. A large sum of it will go towards taking care of our cast and crew during the creation process. A lot of us will have to take some time away from good jobs and will need some support on that front. We will then distribute the funds in a very calculated manner between taking care of props, costumes, set and the creative process. After that - we bring the show to you !! And for that we have to travel, get visas and make rental agreements with venues which will all be worth it to be able to share our creation with you.

10$ will get you a thank you letter from us and a cast and crew photo.
50 $ will get you a video thank you and a photo album of the creation process.
100$ will get you a will get you a video thank you and a photo album of the creation process and a tee-shirt.
200$ will get you a will get you a video thank you and a photo album of the creation process and a tee-shirt. As well as tickets to one of our performances.
500$ will get you a will get you a video thank you and a photo album of the creation process and a tee-shirt. As well as 4 tickets to one of our performances, a backstage tour, followed by a meet and greet. Complete V.I.P. treatment
1000$ will get you 10 tickets plus dinner with the cast and autographed photo.
3000 $ will get you all the above plus a limited edition autographed poster.
5000$ will get you all of the above PLUS an original artwork based on the show.

    The Impact

    We believe that the young fresh minds of today aren't necessarily being given the opportunities they deserve and we're here to change that. We would like to commit to giving internships and work experience to young professionals as well as offer an educational outreach program. We want to let kids know that their dreams of being on stage or backstage are possible and we want to let them play in our world even if only for an hour to broaden their horizons.

    Individually, the Project X team has been very successful in their career paths and vow to bring the same energy and dedication to this new adventure we are all embarking on. If we can do so much individually imagine what we can conjure up all together !! 

      Risks & Challenges

      Starting a new company is risky business in itself - but our team is driven and ready to take on the challenge. 

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Can't contribute? That doesn't mean you can't help! Get the word out, send us words of encouragement - let us know if you want to see us in your city ! We're always looking for new talent as well so send us a shout out and we'd be more than happy to have a chat. Our door is always open, common by ! :)

story:
Update:

We are SO proud and grateful to have reached our first goal of $6,500. Endless thanks to all who have contributed and are making Lolly Willowes a reality. 

Thanks to this generous enthusiasm and support, we are excited to announce a new final goal of $8,500, as we unveil our Lolly Willowes Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/LollyWillowes2019/). The additional $2,000 will allow us to add two important features to the production: first, a raised platform allowing our director Dash Waterbury to move the cast and sets between two distinct areas, one for London and one for the countryside (check out his sketch here on this page!); and second, costumes for the string players, clarifying their role as Laura’s spiritual allies.

We're also happy to announce that tickets are now on sale through the MATCH Box Office: https://matchouston.org/events/2019/lolly-willo...

LOLLY WILLOWES

Lolly Willowes is the story of a London woman who is lost, alone, perplexed, a woman caught for many years in a life she hasn't chosen...but then something happens, something comes to her, something that perplexes her even more, a great disquiet, an energy beyond her understanding, a force that draws her out of her life as the meek and kindly "Aunt Lolly”. She follows the wild call of her heart into the countryside, where she discovers who she truly is. It is the story of the beauty and strangeness and risk of one woman’s process of discovering her authentic selfhood — and of the natural and supernatural elements at work in her drama.

One of the great English novels of the 20th century, Lolly Willowes has never been adapted for dramatic presentation, neither on stage nor on screen. We are the first to request and receive permission to do so, with the blessing of the author's estate. 

Our show offers a completely new kind of theater, one that undoes the distance between singers, musicians, dancers, and audiences, dissolving the boundary between “actor” and “witness,” “voice” and “instrument,” and (most radically) “good” and “evil.”

Kazoos are called for.

We’re two months away from opening night. The theater is booked. Rehearsals are underway. We’ve assembled an extraordinary company of young artists: three marvelous singers, a brilliant string quartet, two thrilling dancers, a visionary director, a costume designer, plus other personnel who will come on board in the weeks ahead, leading up to the April performances. We’ve organized a community outreach event, a musical celebration of Houston’s Independence Heights neighborhood to honor its ongoing recovery from Hurricane Harvey. The Houston Arts Alliance has awarded us its maximum development grant of $15,000 to cover production costs. Now we need to raise the remaining $6,500 we need for the show. We hope you'll join us. We can't wait. 

 

What We Need & How We’ll Say “Thank You”

The $6,500 we need to raise will go directly into the production of Lolly Willowes. Your contribution will go toward:

  • Venue rental cost
  • Set design and costumes
  • Marketing and PR: ads, flyers, radio segments
  • And last but not least, remuneration for our incredible cast and crew, who are working for minimal rates to make this project happen

GOOD NEWS: thanks to our fiscal sponsorship by the distinguished Artaria String Quartet, all contributions to Lolly Willowes are tax-deductible non-profit donations.  

Take a look at the right side of the page for some donation levels and associated perks! Or click "Back It" to enter any amount you choose. 

 

The Impact

Lolly Willowes is a dream come true: new music has become the ground on which a community of artists can do what they love to do, do what they do best, an opportunity for them to take their skills and their insights into unprecedented regions of technical and spiritual inquiry, giving their gifts not only to theater audiences, but to the larger and needful Houston community, which is still in the process of recovery from Hurricane Harvey.  

On March 3, the Lolly Willowes cast is producing a Hurricane Harvey recovery and community engagement event in Houston’s Independence Heights neighborhood with our partner Rebuilding Together Houston, a disaster relief non-profit whose home rebuilding efforts have been focused on devastation in Independence Heights.

 

The Team

Michael Alec Rose, composer and librettist

Dashiell Waterbury, director

Chelsea Helm, soprano

Ben Edquist, baritone

Raphaella Medina, mezzo-soprano

Matt Lammers, violin

Chandler Yu, violin

Natasha Galitzine, viola

Minzo Kim, cello

A.J. Garcia-Rameau, choreographer

Rachel Clinkscales, costume designer

 

Producers: 

Matt Lammers

Lee Hallman

Chandler Yu

 

Other Ways You Can Help

No contribution is too small. But if you can’t contribute toward our budget, there are others ways to help! Come to the show. Tell your friends. Share this page. Ask us questions. Send us some love. Your support matters.

Garcia-Rameau, choreographerRachel Clinkscales, costume designer Producers: Matt LammersLee HallmanChandler Yu Other Ways You Can HelpNo contribution is too small. But if you can’t contribute toward our budget, there are others ways to help! Come to the show. Tell your friends. Share this page. Ask us questions. Send us some love. Your support matters.

story:
DEAR ABOUT THIS PROJECT,  

✺ YOU ARE SAYING YES TO TWO SEATTLE INDEPENDENT ARTISTS ✺                                   

“This is not a post office” is inspired by letters and the act of correspondence.  Creating inclusive and intimate space flavored with informality is a fundamental aspect of this work. We make live-work because we seek an antidote to today's disconnection. In the absence of smart-phones, computers, streaming services...come reach out, with us, to each other. When was the last time you wrote and sent a letter with postage?  The evening will be full of tenderness, healing our contemporary dissociation with call & response, grateful for the universality of the camaraderie.  Expect: overhead projections, dance improvisation, writing, speaking, and consensual participatory inquiry.

SINCERELY, Corina + Vanessa

✺ YOU VALUE THE KIND OF DISCOVERY EPHEMERAL PERFORMANCES INSPIRE ✺

THE TWO PIECES IN THE EVENING

“DEAR & SINCERELY” by Corina Iona Dalzell

This work uses performance as a means of unpacking the relational subtext behind written correspondence. Performers become the body of the letter shaped by the history and dialogue of sender and receiver. "This is Not a Post Office" will feature "Dear & Sincerely" ensemble members: Mercedes Klein, Jordan Colvard, and Margaret Behm under the direction of Corina Iona Dalzell. For more information on this year long research project, visit corinadalzell.com.

“LOVELETTERING” by Vanessa DeWolf 

A heartbreak transformed into a love-letter.  Both conceptual and participatory, Vanessa proposes to fall out of heartbreak by use of imagination, to transform. Using overhead projections, live-readings, gestures encased in the softest fur, WE, together write a love-letter.  Let's become the mail-slots, without fear of return-to-sender notifications.  Let's receive the simple succor of postage.  Dear cruel hard heart, let's melt.  I will need your voice, and I will ask gently.  

✺ YOU SUPPORT A CULTURE THAT IS CREATIVE & VULNERABLE ✺

DEAR HOW WE WILL USE THE MONEY,

Thank you for inquiring about our commitment to paying the artists involved. It is because of this campaign, we will be able to do just that.  It is because of your generosity, we can trust the creative process and create the most vivid live experience.  

Corina & Vanessa are raising $1600 over the next 24 days to pay the artists & Gallery 1412☆ 

☆ ABOUT GALLERY 1412:  Not only has this space supported independent artists for the last 30 years in Seattle, it is also ideally intimate for our participatory performance.  It's MICRO-sized, we'll be able seat a maximum of 30 people per performance!  Yet another reason your dollars make this possible since we can't make our budget at the door.  Supporting us supports the space, which in turn supports the ecosystem of Seattle's rich independent art ecology.  At the current level of gentrification, small spaces hold on by a thread
-----THANK YOU.  

✺ COMBINED WE'VE CREATED PERFORMANCE IN SEATTLE FOR MORE THAN 25 YEARS ✺ 

"This is not a post office," though low-budget and intimate, aspires to touch those present emotionally and profoundly. With this work we do ask some big questions:

Is our culture missing PLAY?  Could we use PLAY to find not the space that is known, but that which is to be discovered?  Can a performance include the viewer in the creative process and entertain? 

✺ THANK YOU FOR SUPPORTING SPONTANEOUS WORK RESIDING IN BOTH THE UNKNOWN AND THE PRESENT MOMENT ✺

There is inherent risk in improvisation.  There's always the possibility of something richly unexpected and timely arising from the unknown.  We adore the challenge of the fleeting experience of a newness, we revel in the potential to draw us toward a fresh awareness.      

Sincerely, Vanessa & Corina

DON’T HAVE ANY MONEY TO GIVE BUT STILL WANT TO HELP US?

We will definitely need some VOLUNTEERS to bring these works to fruition, both for the performances and in some other areas too.  Please feel free to email us at: plastiqarts@gmail.com and let us know when and how you’d like to volunteer.

story:
What are you doing?

Basically, I'm asking people to sponsor me to continue Batusi-dancing for as long as possible. The entire thing will be live streamed on the day, and anyone is welcome to come along and dance in the background for as long as they want - costumes encouraged!

I'll do the whole thing live from Roma Street Parkland, in a 1960s-style Batman costume. This will be a family friendly event, so expect lots of costumed kids to be running around the place.

How do we help?

For the first hour, pledging a dollar will get you one minute of Batusi-dancing goodness. For the second hour, it will be two dollars a minute, and so on (as per below).

 

My goal is to get to around $900 - that will be enough to cover costs, pay off a vet bill, and take the family out for dinner to recover.

And if, by some bizarre miracle, I get sponsored for an entire 24 hours, I'll use the money to open up a Batusi cafe, complete with 1960s Batman character costumes, and Bat-labels on everything...

More reasons to sponsor this madness

  • Because it's ridiculous, and the world needs more ridiculous
  • To ensure the Batusi is never forgotten
  • To pay tribute to Adam West
  • To possibly witness a Batusi-induced heart attack.

Other Ways You Can Help

It's completely fine to watch along without sponsoring - if you don't want to put any money into this, here's some other ways to help.

  • If you're in the Brisbane area, turn up and show your support! (Roma Street Parkland, Saturday 13/07/2019, from 9am)
  • Share this Indiegogo campaign!
  • Follow along on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/BatusiGuy/), and Twitter (https://twitter.com/BatusiGuy), and encourage your friends to do the same...

And that's it! Thanks everyone - this will either be a spectacular success or an embarrassing failure, but it should be fun to watch either way...

story:
Wearing Black

Death ends a life, not a relationship.

A New Musical
by Riley Thomas
Presented as part of the 2015 New York Musical Theatre Festival

 Theater 3 - 311 W. 43rd St

Thursday, July 9th at 8PM
Friday, July 10th at 9PM
Saturday, July 11th at 1PM
Monday, July 13th at 5PM
Wednesday, July 15th at 1PM

Synopsis

When his twin brother Charlie suddenly passes away, all Evan wants to do is forget their complicated relationship and move on, but the tangled relationships Charlie left behind keep Evan from truly letting go. As he falls into a spiral of self-destruction, Evan must make a stark decision: either accept and forgive his dead twin brother, or become him. Set to a lush, contemporary musical theatre score, Wearing Black explores how people grieve, and the different ways they accept and reject love. 

History

Wearing Black performed a 15-minute snapshot at the 2011 West Village Musical Theatre Festival, then performed the first act as part of the 2013 FRIGID Festival where it was awarded Best Original Score. Wearing Black also performed a 15-minute snapshot as part of the 2013 NYMF event Riley Thomas: Looking Forward.

About the Author

Riley Thomas is a New York based playwright/composer. Thomas’s previous musical Stuck ran at NYMF 2012 where it won four accolades: the Theater for the American Musical Prize, the DIMF Production Award, and honorable mentions for Best Book and Best Music. Stuck has since gone on to be a made into a full-length Hollywood feature film starring Giancarlo Esposito, Amy Madigan and Ashanti with an expected winter 2015 release. Executive Director of Dark Prophet Productions since 2010, Thomas has been awarded the 2012 Anna Sosenko Assist Trust Grant and the 2009 Johnny Mercer Songwriter’s Certificate.

Goals at NYMF and Beyond

Wearing Black follows in the footsteps of smash successes like Fun Home, Next to Normal and Rent in the way it handles its material: by using the characters and story to create the spectacle. The small personnel requirements, humble scope of the show, and star vehicle potential make it a perfect contender for an Off-Broadway run, as well as keep it eminently producible at regional theaters and colleges.
story_txt:
Wearing BlackDeath ends a life, not a relationship.
A New Musicalby Riley ThomasPresented as part of the 2015 New York Musical Theatre Festival Theater 3 - 311 W. 43rd St
Thursday, July 9th at 8PMFriday, July 10th at 9PMSaturday, July 11th at 1PMMonday, July 13th at 5PMWednesday, July 15th at 1PM
Synopsis
When his twin brother Charlie suddenly passes away, all Evan wants to
 do is forget their complicated relationship and move on, but the 
tangled relationships Charlie left behind keep Evan from truly letting 
go. As he falls into a spiral of self-destruction, Evan must make a 
stark decision: either accept and forgive his dead twin brother, or 
become him. Set to a lush, contemporary musical theatre score, Wearing Black explores how people grieve, and the different ways they accept and reject love. History
Wearing Black performed a 15-minute snapshot at the 2011 West 
Village Musical Theatre Festival, then performed the first act as part 
of the 2013 FRIGID Festival where it was awarded Best Original Score. Wearing Black also performed a 15-minute snapshot as part of the 2013 NYMF event Riley Thomas: Looking Forward.About the Author
Riley Thomas is a New York based playwright/composer. Thomas’s previous musical Stuck ran at NYMF 2012 where it won four accolades: the Theater for the American Musical Prize, the DIMF Production Award, and honorable mentions for Best Book and Best Music. Stuck
 has since gone on to be a made into a full-length Hollywood feature 
film starring Giancarlo Esposito, Amy Madigan and Ashanti with an 
expected winter 2015 release. Executive Director of Dark Prophet 
Productions since 2010, Thomas has been awarded the 2012 Anna Sosenko 
Assist Trust Grant and the 2009 Johnny Mercer Songwriter’s Certificate.Goals at NYMF and Beyond
Wearing Black follows in the footsteps of smash successes like Fun Home, Next to Normal and Rent
 in the way it handles its material: by using the characters and story 
to create the spectacle. The small personnel requirements, humble scope 
of the show, and star vehicle potential make it a perfect contender for 
an Off-Broadway run, as well as keep it eminently producible at regional
 theaters and colleges.

story:
:A Summary:

My name is Hannah Hiaasen. I am an interdisciplinary artist whose work sits on the edge between visual and textual. My choreography entitled PUNCTUATE is being featured in an International Conference on punctuation entitled "Punctuation in Practice" at the Dahlem Humanities Center, as part of the Freie Universitat in Berlin, Germany.  
This funding assists with performance conceptualization, preparation, and actualization. 
 

The work traveling across the atlantic is PUNCTUATE. PUNCTUATE is the reading of a poem that directs a performance with its embedded punctuation marks. Every mark on the page translates to a gesture of the performers on the stage (the punctuators).  These gestures are simple, linear, and based off the typography of punctuation.  The choreography personifies punctuation provoking an elaboration on intimacy within rigidity.   

 

The Impact

 I am the only artist incorporated in this event. The other featured speakers are scholars presenting academic papers.  Through PUNCTUATE, I am investigating the cross-pollination between body and textual language. Therefore, PUNCTUATE's presence brings cross-disciplinary diversity to the public and academic conversation.
This is PUNCTUATE's very first international debut. It has been performed publicly three times: MICA's Black Box Theater (2014), Baltimore, MD and at School 33 (2015), and once in Brooklyn, New York at The Brooklyn Art Space (2014).  

School 33, March 14, 2015, 8-person version

Risks & Challenges

The performance changes every time it is taught. The punctuators this time, may not share the same language as me or each other, therefore direction will have to evolve. Translation plays such significant part in this performance already, that language barriers pose a perfect challenge to enhance the process and final product of this project.   ! !

Therefore, PUNCTUATE's presence brings cross-disciplinary diversity to the public and academic conversation.
This is PUNCTUATE's very first international debut. It has been performed publicly three times: MICA's Black Box Theater (2014), Baltimore, MD and at School 33 (2015), and once in Brooklyn, New York at The Brooklyn Art Space (2014).

story:
Til.T a besoin de vous!

Après le succès de Les débuts de Loretta, présenté en 2011 à la Salle intime du Théâtre Prospero, la compagnie présente Les têtes baissées, cette fois-ci sur la scène principale.

Til.T a besoin de vous pour financer cette production. Que ce soit au niveau des décors, des costumes, des cachets aux artistes et collaborateurs ou de la promotion, les entrées de billetterie ne suffisent pas à boucler le budget. Votre participation est donc essentielle et très appréciée!

Résumé du spectacle

Lorsqu’un événement tragique vient secouer l’équilibre fragile de sa vie, Thomas s’en prend à sa mère, lui reprochant jusqu’à l’amour qu’elle lui a prodigué. Un blâme de trop dans la vie de Danielle, qui n’a plus d’autre choix que de dévoiler à son fils les secrets d’un passé familial restés trop longtemps enfouis. Thomas s’engage alors dans une guerre d’honneur dont il souhaite sortir vainqueur, portant l’histoire de sa mère comme sa propre croix. Sur le champ de bataille, six êtres en quête d’amour assisteront à l’éclatement de la vérité sous le regard d’un jeune homme qui a tout à gagner. Mais les règles du jeu sont cruelles, car au pays des têtes baissées, c’est la loi du plus fort.

Spectacle présenté au Théâtre Prospero du 21 avril au 9 mai 2015

TEXTE Mickael Lamoureux

MISE EN SCÈNE Louis-Karl Tremblay

ASSISTANCE À LA MISE EN SCÈNE Isabelle Duchesneau

DISTRIBUTION Muriel Dutil, Mickael Lamoureux, Jean Maheux, Marie-France Marcotte, Luc Morissette, Lise Roy

CONCEPTION DES COSTUMES Mari-Philippe Comeau

SCÉNOGRAPHIE Julie-Christina Picher

CONCEPTION SONORE Michel Smith

ÉCLAIRAGES Robin Kittel-Ouimet

RÉGIE Audrey Janelle

COMMUNICATIONS ET RELATIONS DE PRESSE Éric Senécal

Biographies de l'auteur, du metteur en scène et des interprètes

Mickael Lamoureux

Auteur et interprète

Diplômé en interprétation théâtrale du Collège Lionel-Groulx, on a pu le voir dès sa sortie d’école dans Les Soleils Pâles de Marc-Antoine Cyr et N’habbek de Louis-Dominique Lavigne, sous la direction de Lise Gionet. En plus de travailler activement avec Le théâtre de quartier,  il a cofondé le Théâtre Agitato avec lequel il a présenté Le Projet Laramie, à la salle Fred-Barry en 2009. Soucieux de s’inscrire dans une démarche artistique singulière et engagée, il co-fonde en 2010 la compagnie Til.T pour créer Moribonds avec la complicité de Dave St-Pierre et de Sarah Berthiaume. En 2011, il est de la distribution du Numéro d'Équilibre d'Edward Bond, mise en scène de Louis-Karl Tremblay, puis du Cycle de la Boucherie de Dave St-Pierre, présenté au Théâtre La Chapelle. En 2012, il interprétait Dave dans la pièce Les débuts de Loretta de Georges F Walker, mise en scène de Sébastien Gauthier, présentée à la salle intime du Théâtre Prospero. Dans la dernière année, il a également participé au spectacle PANIK de la compagnie Pirata Théâtre, sous la direction de Michelle Parent, Album de finissants, dirigé par Anne-Sophie Rouleau et L’incendie de la Triangle Factory, dans une mise en scène de Valérie Lemaire. Son premier texte, Les têtes baissées, a été présenté à la Maison de la culture Maisonneuve en août 2013, dans le cadre du festival Zone-Homa, sous la direction de Louis-Karl Tremblay.

À l'écran, on a pu le voir dans L’Espérance, Rêve d’acteurs et plus récemment dans le court métrage Bloodbath et le long métrage Aurore 2. Il est également de la distribution d’une nouvelle série jeunesse qui verra prochainement le jour à Radio-Canada : Les aventuriers galactiques.

Louis-Karl Tremblay

Metteur en scène

Depuis sa sortie de l’École Supérieure de Théâtre de l’Université du Québec à Montréal en 2008, Louis-Karl travaille comme comédien et metteur en scène. On a pu le voir au théâtre dans notamment Leitmotiv au Théâtre La Chapelle (mise en scène d’Émilie Cormier) et dans le spectacle jeunesse Sous les toxiques du Théâtre Parminou. On a également pu le voir à la télévision dans Toute la vérité, Providence, L’auberge du chien noir et Traitement choc. En 2008, il cofonde sa compagnie, Théâtre Point d’Orgue, et y travaille comme metteur en scène. Il s’attaque en 2009 aux Troyennes qu’il présente au Bain Saint-Michel. À l’automne 2011, il présente Yvonne, Princesse de Bourgogne de Witold Gombrowicz, au Théâtre Prospero. En avril 2013, il propose une version inédite des Atrides à l’Église Saint-Jean-Baptiste, ce qui lui vaut une nomination aux prix de la critique pour la meilleure mise en scène de l’Association québécoise des critiques de théâtre.

Muriel Dutil

Interprète

En mai 2014, Muriel Dutil fêtera 44 ans de vie artistique.  Au théâtre, parmi plus de 80 productions, ne citons que les 5 dernières : Avec Norm de Serge Boucher, mis en scène par Robert Bellefeuille (Théâtre du Rideau Vert);  Thérèse et Pierrette à l’École des Saints Anges, adaptation du roman de Michel Tremblay par Serge Denoncourt (Théâtre Denise-Pelletier); Opium_37 de Catherine Léger, mis en scène par Éric  Jean (Théâtre de Quat’Sous); Félicité d’Olivier Choinière, mis en scène par Sylvain Bélanger (Théâtre de la Manufacture); Sacré Cœur d’Alexis Martin et Alain Vadeboncoeur, joué en tournée au Québec ainsi qu’au Nouveau Théâtre Expérimental.

À la télévision, on a pu la voir dans Graffiti, Les Girouettes, La Fricassée, Radio Enfer, SOS J’écoute, Bonjour docteur, Tandem, Chartrand et Simonne, Virginie, Portrait Vidéo, l’Amour avec un grand A, Le Cœur découvert, Les Voisins, Mirador, Le Gentleman et La Promesse.

Au cinéma, elle a interprété le rôle de la mère de Mimi dans Idole Instantanée d’Yves Desgagnés;  Madame Odile dans Curling de Denis Côté et dernièrement Dorine dans Ressac de Pascale Ferland.

Lors du premier gala des prix Gémeaux (1987), Muriel se mérite le trophée de la meilleure interprète pour son rôle de Marie dans l’épisode « Marie et François » de la série L’Amour avec un grand A de Jeannette Bertrand.  Par la suite, elle s’est retrouvée en lice pour ses rôles dans Portrait Vidéo, Graffiti, Le Gentleman et La Promesse.

 En 2005, au gala des Masques, elle reçoit le prix de la meilleure interprète de l’année pour le rôle de Grace qu’elle interprète dans la pièce Grace et Gloria de Tom Siegler, traduite par Michel Tremblay, dans une mise en scène de Marc-Alain Robitaille.

Jean Maheux

Interprète

Artiste polyvalent, Jean Maheux est reconnu autant comme chanteur, acteur et danseur. Il a été remarqué pour son interprétation magistrale de Don Quichotte dans L’Homme de la Mancha (Mise en nomination pour la meilleure interprétation masculine pour ce rôle par l’Académie québécoise du théâtre). Il a joué Antoine dans Antoine et Cléopâtre, sous la direction de Lewis Furey au Théâtre du Nouveau Monde, a été de la distribution de Toute Femme de Peter Karpatià l’Espace Go, de L’Iliade d’après Homère au Théâtre du Nouveau Monde, Du vent entre les dents de Emmanuelle Jimenez au Théâtre d’Aujourd’hui, Billy L’Éclopé de Martin McDonagh à la Compagnie Jean Duceppe et Imago de Marie-Christine Lê-Huu; pour n’en nommer que quelques-unes. Il a été de l’aventure de trois opéras créés et produits par Chants Libres: Le vampire et la nymphomane de Serge Provost et Claude Gauvreau, L’Enfant des glaces de Zack Settel et Pauline Vaillancourt et L’Archange de Louis Dufort et Alexis Nouss.

Marie-France Marcotte

Interprète

Diplômée du Conservatoire d’Art dramatique de Montréal (1989) et enseignante à l’Option théâtre du Cégep Lionel Groulx depuis 1998, Marie-France Marcotte a tenu de nombreux rôles, tant dans des créations que dans des pièces du répertoire ainsi qu’au cinéma et à la télévision. Il s’agit de sa troisième collaboration avec Til.T, après Moribonds (2010) et Le laboratoire Camus (2011).

Parmi les auteurs québécois, elle joue Gauvreau, Tremblay, Danis, Monmart, Bienvenue, Pedneault. Elle fréquente en outre Molière, Shakespeare, Mishima, Tchekhov, Bergman. En 2000, elle reçoit le Masque de la meilleure interprétation féminine pour son rôle de Cégestelle dans Les oranges sont vertes de Claude Gauvreau, mis en scène par Lorraine Pintal. En 2002, elle reçoit le prix Gascon-Roux pour son rôle de Blanche Dubois dans Un tramway nommé désir de Tennessee Williams, mis en scène par René Richard Cyr. De 2005 à 2010, elle tourne en France avec Forêts de Wajdi Mouawad. À l’été 2009, elle participe à sa trilogie Le sang des promesses présenté à la Cour d’honneur du Palais des Papes au Festival d’Avignon ainsi qu’au Festival TransAmériques  de Montréal à l’été 2010. À l’automne 2010, elle reprend Forêts et Le sang des promesses au Théâtre National de Chaillot à Paris. De retour à Montréal, elle travaille avec le chorégraphe Dave St-Pierre. Elle tient également plusieurs rôles à la télévision (Trauma, Destinée, Montréal ville ouverte ainsi que tribu.com qui lui vaut une nomination au prix Gémeaux. Au cinéma, on la retrouve dans : Ils s’aiment d’Anaïs Barbeau Lavalette et André Turpin, En plein coeur de Stéphane Géhami, Ne dis rien de Simon Lacombe, Caboose de Richard Roy ainsi que dans Le dernier tunnel de Erick Canuel qui lui vaut également une nomination au prix Jutra.

Luc Morissette

Interprète

Luc Morissette est un mordu de théâtre. Après avoir été comédien-fondateur de L'Atelier de Sherbrooke, il passe dix-sept ans de sa vie à des études et à une pratique clinique et universitaire, pour revenir, au début des années 1980, à ses anciens amours : le théâtre.

En vingt-cinq ans, il a joué dans plus de cinquante productions à la scène. Ses rôles marquants sont nombreux : François Ier dans Vie et mort du roi boiteux de Jean-Pierre Ronfard, Vendôme dans Les Cauchemars du grand monde de Gilbert Turp, Léo Girard dans La Nuit des p'tits couteaux de Suzanne Aubry, Ulysse dans Le Cyclope d’Euripide, le contrebassiste dans La Contrebasse de Patrick Suskind, Gubetta dans Lucrèce Borgia de Victor Hugo, masque de la meilleure production de Montréal en 1997, Pécuchet dans Gustave n'est pas moderne d'Armando Llamas, Vincent van Gogh dans L'Ange et le Corbeau de Francis Montmart, où il s'est mérité une nomination au Masque de la meilleure interprétation masculine en 1995, et Théo Steiner dans Toujours l'Orage d'Enzo Cormann.

Il a joué dans plus de 15 films, dont Nelligan de Robert Favreau, Le Party de Pierre Falardeau, L'Idée noire de Mireille Dansereau, Familia de Louise Archambault, Mémoires affectives de Francis Leclerc, Transit de Christian De la Cortina et The Timekeeper de Louis Bélanger.

Il a enfin été de plusieurs téléséries et téléromans au petit écran : les derniers en lice : Nos étés, Prochaine station, René Lévesque, Les Ex et Les Super mamies de Lise Payette.

Durant 23 ans, il a enseigné l’interprétation à l’École professionnelle de théâtre du Collège Lionel-Groulx. Il a aussi été professeur pendant 11 ans à l’École nationale de Théâtre.

Lise Roy

Interprète

Lise Roy, issue du Conservatoire d'Art dramatique de Montréal, poursuit une carrière de comédienne autant au théâtre, à  la télévision qu'au cinéma en plus de continuer à  parfaire sa formation en fréquentant entre autres, les Ateliers Warren Robertson pendant une dizaine d'années. Trilingue, elle a également fait une maîtrise à  l’Université du Québec à Montréal.

Au théâtre, elle fût remarquée pour sa création de Camille Claudel dans le spectacle Camille C.; depuis, elle a joué, entre autres, une puissante Élisabeth 1ère dans Marie Stuart (mise en scène de Alexandre Marine) ; d'autres spectacles ont  marqué son parcours dont Top Girls (mise en scène de Martine Beaulne), La Casa azul et La Géométrie des miracles ((mise en scène de Robert Lepage), Le Bruit des os qui craquent (mise en scène de Gervais Gaudreault), Tom à  la ferme (mise en scène de Claude Poissant), Les Bonnes (mise en scène de Marc Béland).

Elle participe à  plusieurs séries télévisées, dont Un Homme mort, Vice Caché, Grande Ourse II et Toute la vérité. On l'a vue au cinéma dans Les Invasions Barbares, Le Secret de ma mère, Peau Blanche, À l'origine d'un cri et, tout récemment, dans Tom à  la ferme, rôle grâce auquel elle a remporté le prix de la « Best Supporting Actress in a Canadian Film » décerné par le Vancouver Film Critics Circle. Elle a aussi reçu le Prix Gemini de la meilleure actrice dans un rôle de soutien pour The Boys of St-Vincent ainsi qu'une mise en nomination pour son interprétation de Miss Lafleur dans Children of my heart.

En plus de son travail de comédienne, Lise Roy enseigne dans différentes écoles de théâtre depuis près de vingt ans. Elle a également participé à  de nombreuses tournées soit, au Québec, avec le TPQ, en Europe et aux États-Unis avec la compagnie Ex Machina, et en France et au Mexique, avec le Théâtre le Caroussel.


Vous ferez une différence parce que vous...

  • Permettrez aux artistes et artisans de créer avec le moins de contraintes financières possibles
  • Contribuerez à diversifier les sources de revenus de la compagnie, réduisant ainsi les risque financiers de la production

Vous pouvez aussi...

  • Demander aux gens de passer le mot et de faire de la publicité autour de nôtre projet.
  • Acheter vos billets en vous rendant au www.creationtilt.com/achetez-vos-billets
  • Acheter un ou des billets pour le spectacle-bénéfice du 24 avril prochain, à 20h, au coût de 100$. Pour de plus amples informations, écrivez-vous à tilt.theatre@gmail.com .

Qui est Til.T?

Découvrez-en plus sur nous au www.creationtilt.com !

À la télévision, on a pu la voir dans Graffiti,
Les Girouettes, La Fricassée, Radio Enfer, SOS J’écoute, Bonjour docteur,
Tandem, Chartrand et Simonne, Virginie, Portrait Vidéo, l’Amour avec un grand
A, Le Cœur découvert, Les Voisins, Mirador, Le Gentleman et La Promesse.
Au cinéma, elle a interprété le rôle de la mère de Mimi dans Idole Instantanée d’Yves Desgagnés;  Madame Odile dans Curling de Denis Côté et dernièrement Dorine dans Ressac de Pascale Ferland. 
Lors du premier gala des prix Gémeaux (1987), Muriel se mérite le trophée
de la meilleure interprète pour son rôle de Marie dans l’épisode « Marie et François » de la série L’Amour avec un grand A de Jeannette
Bertrand.  Par la suite, elle s’est
retrouvée en lice pour ses rôles dans Portrait
Vidéo, Graffiti, Le Gentleman et La
Promesse.
 En 2005, au gala des Masques, elle
reçoit le prix de la meilleure interprète de l’année pour le rôle de Grace
qu’elle interprète dans la pièce Grace et
Gloria de Tom Siegler, traduite par Michel Tremblay, dans une mise en scène
de Marc-Alain Robitaille.
Jean Maheux
Interprète
Artiste polyvalent, Jean Maheux est reconnu autant comme chanteur, acteur
et danseur. Il a été remarqué pour son interprétation magistrale de Don
Quichotte dans L’Homme de la Mancha
(Mise en nomination pour la meilleure interprétation masculine pour ce rôle par
l’Académie québécoise du théâtre). Il a joué Antoine dans Antoine et Cléopâtre, sous la direction de Lewis Furey au Théâtre
du Nouveau Monde, a été de la distribution de Toute Femme de Peter Karpatià l’Espace Go, de L’Iliade d’après Homère au Théâtre du Nouveau Monde, Du vent entre les dents de Emmanuelle
Jimenez au Théâtre d’Aujourd’hui, Billy
L’Éclopé de Martin McDonagh à la Compagnie Jean Duceppe et Imago de Marie-Christine Lê-Huu; pour
n’en nommer que quelques-unes. Il a été de l’aventure de trois opéras créés et
produits par Chants Libres: Le vampire et
la nymphomane de Serge Provost et Claude Gauvreau, L’Enfant des glaces de Zack Settel et Pauline Vaillancourt et L’Archange de Louis Dufort et Alexis
Nouss.
Marie-France
Marcotte
Interprète
Diplômée du Conservatoire d’Art dramatique de Montréal (1989)
et enseignante à l’Option théâtre du Cégep Lionel Groulx depuis 1998,
Marie-France Marcotte a tenu de nombreux rôles, tant dans des créations que
dans des pièces du répertoire ainsi qu’au cinéma et à la télévision. Il s’agit
de sa troisième collaboration avec Til.T, après Moribonds (2010) et Le
laboratoire Camus (2011).
Parmi les auteurs québécois, elle joue Gauvreau, Tremblay, Danis, Monmart,
Bienvenue, Pedneault. Elle fréquente en outre Molière, Shakespeare, Mishima,
Tchekhov, Bergman. En 2000, elle reçoit le Masque de la meilleure
interprétation féminine pour son rôle de Cégestelle dans Les oranges sont vertes de Claude Gauvreau, mis en scène par
Lorraine Pintal. En 2002, elle reçoit le prix Gascon-Roux pour son rôle de
Blanche Dubois dans Un tramway nommé
désir de Tennessee Williams, mis en scène par René Richard Cyr. De 2005 à
2010, elle tourne en France avec Forêts de
Wajdi Mouawad. À l’été 2009, elle participe à sa trilogie Le sang des promesses présenté à la Cour d’honneur du Palais des
Papes au Festival d’Avignon ainsi qu’au Festival TransAmériques  de Montréal à l’été 2010. À l’automne 2010,
elle reprend Forêts et Le sang des promesses au Théâtre
National de Chaillot à Paris. De retour à Montréal, elle travaille avec le
chorégraphe Dave St-Pierre. Elle tient également plusieurs rôles à la
télévision (Trauma, Destinée, Montréal
ville ouverte ainsi que tribu.com
qui lui vaut une nomination au prix Gémeaux. Au cinéma, on la retrouve dans : Ils s’aiment d’Anaïs Barbeau Lavalette
et André Turpin, En plein coeur de
Stéphane Géhami, Ne dis rien de Simon
Lacombe, Caboose de Richard Roy ainsi
que dans Le dernier tunnel de Erick
Canuel qui lui vaut également une nomination au prix Jutra.
Luc Morissette
Interprète
Luc Morissette est un mordu de théâtre. Après avoir été comédien-fondateur
de L'Atelier de Sherbrooke, il passe dix-sept ans de sa vie à des études et à
une pratique clinique et universitaire, pour revenir, au début des années 1980,
à ses anciens amours : le théâtre.
En vingt-cinq ans, il a joué dans plus de cinquante productions à la scène.
Ses rôles marquants sont nombreux : François Ier dans Vie et mort du roi boiteux de Jean-Pierre Ronfard, Vendôme dans Les Cauchemars du grand monde de Gilbert
Turp, Léo Girard dans La Nuit des p'tits
couteaux de Suzanne Aubry, Ulysse dans Le
Cyclope d’Euripide, le contrebassiste dans La Contrebasse de Patrick Suskind, Gubetta dans Lucrèce Borgia de Victor Hugo, masque de
la meilleure production de Montréal en 1997, Pécuchet dans Gustave n'est pas moderne d'Armando Llamas, Vincent van Gogh dans L'Ange et le Corbeau de Francis
Montmart, où il s'est mérité une nomination au Masque de la meilleure
interprétation masculine en 1995, et Théo Steiner dans Toujours l'Orage d'Enzo Cormann.
Il a joué dans plus de 15 films, dont Nelligan
de Robert Favreau, Le Party de Pierre
Falardeau, L'Idée noire de Mireille
Dansereau, Familia de Louise
Archambault, Mémoires affectives de
Francis Leclerc, Transit de Christian
De la Cortina et The Timekeeper de
Louis Bélanger.
Il a enfin été de plusieurs téléséries et téléromans au petit écran : les
derniers en lice : Nos étés, Prochaine station, René Lévesque, Les Ex
et Les Super mamies de Lise Payette.
Durant 23 ans, il a enseigné l’interprétation à l’École professionnelle de
théâtre du Collège Lionel-Groulx. Il a aussi été professeur pendant 11 ans à
l’École nationale de Théâtre.
Lise Roy
Interprète
Lise Roy, issue du Conservatoire d'Art dramatique de Montréal, poursuit une
carrière de comédienne autant au théâtre, à 
la télévision qu'au cinéma en plus de continuer à  parfaire sa formation en fréquentant entre
autres, les Ateliers Warren Robertson pendant une dizaine d'années. Trilingue,
elle a également fait une maîtrise à  l’Université
du Québec à Montréal.
Au théâtre, elle fût remarquée pour sa création de Camille Claudel dans le
spectacle Camille C.; depuis, elle a
joué, entre autres, une puissante Élisabeth 1ère dans Marie Stuart (mise en scène de Alexandre Marine) ; d'autres
spectacles ont  marqué son parcours dont Top Girls (mise en scène de Martine
Beaulne), La Casa azul et La Géométrie des miracles ((mise en
scène de Robert Lepage), Le Bruit des os
qui craquent (mise en scène de Gervais Gaudreault), Tom à  la ferme (mise en
scène de Claude Poissant), Les Bonnes
(mise en scène de Marc Béland).
Elle participe à  plusieurs séries
télévisées, dont Un Homme mort, Vice
Caché, Grande Ourse II et Toute la
vérité. On l'a vue au cinéma dans Les
Invasions Barbares, Le Secret de ma
mère, Peau Blanche, À l'origine d'un
cri et, tout récemment, dans Tom
à  la ferme, rôle grâce auquel elle a
remporté le prix de la « Best Supporting Actress in a Canadian Film » décerné
par le Vancouver Film Critics Circle. Elle a aussi reçu le Prix Gemini de la
meilleure actrice dans un rôle de soutien pour The Boys of St-Vincent ainsi qu'une mise en nomination pour son
interprétation de Miss Lafleur dans Children
of my heart. 
En plus de son travail de comédienne, Lise Roy enseigne dans différentes
écoles de théâtre depuis près de vingt ans. Elle a également participé à  de nombreuses tournées soit, au Québec, avec
le TPQ, en Europe et aux États-Unis avec la compagnie Ex Machina, et en France
et au Mexique, avec le Théâtre le Caroussel.






Vous ferez une différence parce que vous...

Permettrez aux artistes et artisans de créer avec le moins de contraintes financières possibles
Contribuerez à diversifier les sources de revenus de la compagnie, réduisant ainsi les risque financiers de la production



Vous pouvez aussi...

Demander aux gens de passer le mot et de faire de la publicité autour de nôtre projet.
Acheter vos billets en vous rendant au www.creationtilt.com/achetez-vos-billets

Acheter un ou des billets pour le spectacle-bénéfice du 24 avril prochain, à 20h, au coût de 100$. Pour de plus amples informations, écrivez-vous à tilt.theatre@gmail.com .

Qui est Til.T?
Découvrez-en plus sur nous au www.creationtilt.com !

story:
Monumental Theatre is very proud and excited to announce that it will be debuting its first full-length, all-original musical, UGLY: The Other, Other Cinderella Story. 

UGLY is the story of Cinderella’s ugly step-sisters, Imogen and Maxine, and their journey to find who they are. It’s a story or love, bravery, acceptance, and inner-strength, as the girls come to realize that not every happy ending looks the same.

Ugly is set to have its world premiere in Langley, BC on October 23, 24, and 25, 2015, as well as debut a selection of songs at the creatiValley festival in Abbotsford, BC on September 29th, 2015.

Ugly has been a labour of love for both writers, Annastasia Unger and Lauren Trotzuk. They have poured countless hours into the creation of this show thus far, but they can’t finish it alone. Monumental Theatre needs your help to make this dream a reality.
 

And for those of you who can’t make it to British Columbia, Canada to see the show, we will be filming the show and releasing it online for everyone to see. 

We are looking for people with a love of the theatre and of new creations to support us through this process, through both encouragement and financial support. We have brought this show so far already, and we are so close to reaching our goals, so please help make our dream a reality.

story:
We'd like to take a minute to introduce ourselves. Our business name is Dance Kahncepts and we are a family run small business local to Oshawa.  We've just celebrated 10 years in business and we teach a variety of dance styles to children of all ages! 

We are looking to raise funds to relocate our studio and create a safe, healthy new space for our students and families and we need your support! 

After many years in our current space we've decided to move as it's become an unsafe environment. Due to some water damage and mold issues mixed with poor ventilation it's become a space not fit for for dancers or athletes. We feel our students deserve only the best and we need to make this dream a reality... Please donate today:)

We are very fortunate to have found a new address for our studio but now we need the funds to build it! All funds raised over the next two months will go towards actually building a new studio space... Allowing us to provide our students with a new dance floor, new mirrors, a viewing wall, a functioning washroom as well as making it an accessible space for all!

We thank you for taking the time to read our story and hope you can be a part of this special moment for DK.

feel free to meet our DK dance family by checking out our website!

Thanks so much,

Merideth and team

story:
DogEar Theatre will create immersive theatrical experiences based on literary worlds. This season, we are focusing on transforming one room in two separate schools into the Mad Hatter’s Tea Party from Wonderland. Our experiences at each school are done in two week long residencies. In the first week, teaching artists come in and introduce the literary work, and integrate theatre and (in this year’s case) Wonderland into the curriculum. DogEar then disappears, and, with the ideas from the children in mind, we then build the world. A few months later, the principal calls an emergency assembly. Something and someone has landed in the school. Throughout the week, the young people will interact with the new space and characters, forming their own adventures in Wonderland. This week culminates in an immersive theatrical event to which families and community members are invited.

DogEar Theatre Company was recently chosen as one of three PAVE arts incubator ventures that Arizona State University is helping kickstart. PAVE will give us up to $2000 of matching money to create our immersive experiences (props, costumes, set), pay the actors, and cover creative administrative costs, such as a website and publicity. So this is where you all come in. We need to fundraise at least $2000 to receive the matching money so we may afford to create the art that we will bring to schools who are eager to partner with us! With experiences as grand as this, we want to ensure that our designs are of the highest quality. However, we cannot do this without the generous support of patrons excited for our work.

Your contribution will help bring a truly unique experience to public school students in the Phoenix area and inspire them through full body learning, arts integration, and promotion of literacy. It will also support a group of MFA candidates' exploration of new and creative artistic space, pushing forward the field of Theatre for Young Audiences in the USA.

If you would like to support the company but are unable to donate at this time, you can help us by spreading the word, and inviting others to donate!

(You can even use the Indiegogo share tools to help you out!)

story:
Hello!

We are three women with a background and experience in theatre and music, who are all currently employed within mental health charities in Oxford. 

We all have an understanding and interest in the social function of theatre, and in view of this, we plan to develop a production of a musical called 'Songs for a new World', by Jason Robert Brown: A musical which is meaningful to all of us, and which is powerful in it's portrayal of the mental health struggles which many of us face.

Songs for a new world is a brave modern musical where each song is a world in itself; exploring layers of human experience, emotion and expression.

Four performers. Minimalistic  props and set. Lending a focus to the heart of each story: A hysterical woman on a ledge about to jump, a basketball player running from the past, a couple learning that love means commitment. It is an abstract piece exploring themes vulnerability and strength, the individual and community, resilience found through suffering and choice.

The varied and interesting score composed by Jason Robert Brown, is intense and stylistically diverse, drawing on jazz, blues, pop rock and musical theatre styles. It provides artistic challenge for its performers, which is something we want to offer to its cast.

 We want to create a series of workshops facilitating the exploration of the participants story by looking at themes explored in the musical. We will use creative tools such as writing performance art and storytelling.

We are looking to raise £1000 for the project, but through this campaign we aim to raise funds to cover the basic production costs; venue hire and the performance rights. We estimate this at £600.

With this project we hope to help in breaking down the polarisation between people with diagnosed issues and other members of the community. We hope you will support us in this.

Thank you for reading, please email us if you have any further questions.

Ellen, Laura and Jo

story:
Short Summary

"Summer of Stories" is produced by hereandnow theatre company in association with the Rosenthal Theater at Inner City Arts.  Since 1989, hereandnow theatre company has been committed to the idea that "Everybody has a story to tell,"  and this summer we will be presenting a series of 10 plays, 2 of which be fully staged, over a  two-week period.  "Summer of Stories" brings together over 50 artists - actors, writers, and directors to bring these pieces to life.

 What We Need & What You Get

To make this festival a success, we need to raise $6,000 for rehearsal and theater rental, marketing, and production costs (equipment, lighting, sound, video, etc.).  With your contribution, we would like to raise more than $6,000 so that we can compensate all of the artists involved with more than just the Equity minimum in the hopes of starting a trend of paying artists an actual living wage for their talents and their time.
