story:
Help us to play a role in putting some imagination back into education.

We are facing a crisis as this is under threat.

Creativity is being squeezed out of schools across the UK. As a country we seem to have lost sight of its importance during those vital, formative years.

But what does this mean for future generations?

We expect many things from schools; we want our children to gain all sorts of skills. Amongst these, we want to see them listening with understanding, learning to work with others and experiencing what it means to take the lead. We hope they will learn to look, think and have ideas and, then, be confident about expressing those ideas. Taking part in cultural activities gives children the chance to develop and practice these skills. 

But with these experiences being increasingly rationed how will the challenges of an increasingly complex world be met?   

Who will be doing the creative thinking, the collaborating and communicating in the future?

If we are going to develop the next generation of politicians, scientists, entrepreneurs, artists… who will discover, imagine and lead, then it is imperative for creativity to thrive.

In a bid to combat the squeezing out of the creative spirit in schools, Into Opera has created a unique Education Project which will immerse children in an exciting cultural experience and encourage creativity and imagination across the whole curriculum.

Our creative team running a workshop with 11-year-olds to develop A King's Ransom (Norwich, 2012).

Help us play a role in securing the UK as a creative nation

Into Opera's project can make an impact. It will bring 200 children, from 4 schools, from different social backgrounds together. 200 children will be offered a truly unique experience. Integrating, collaborating and working side by side, these children will stage a brand new opera. They will work with a composer, a librettist and a range of professional artists to explore this all encompassing art form and discover how a production develops from its inception through to a full-scale production. Into Opera will work closely with teachers. In fact, the aim is for teachers, parents and children of all four schools to come together with this opera at its core.  

Into Opera hopes to demonstrate the numerous ways in which cultural activity can really encourage the creative imagination across the whole curriculum. All children deserve a high quality cultural education. The multifaceted nature of opera can inspire and empower children; it can help them become what UNESCO calls an 'all round complete person’.

A King's Ransom

Into Opera has teamed up with the acclaimed British Classical Composer, Patrick Hawes. The project is focussed upon working with children aged 7-11 to stage the Professional World Premiere of Patrick’s children’s opera, A King’s Ransom.

The opera offers an unusual twist on the well-known story of Robin Hood. It explores what happens when Robin is unable to save the day, and instead, the community must look within itself for answers to its problems.

A King’s Ransom was originally written in 1994. Now, 21 years later, Patrick and  brother Andy, the opera's librettist, are returning to this work with fresh eyes and collaborating with Into Opera to revise and expand the work. The characters in the opera clearly split into four chorus sections: the villagers, soldiers, bagmen and masons. Each of these chorus sections will be performed by an individual school.

A King's Ransom's creative team : Stage Director: Genevieve Raghu, Musical Director: Benjamin Hamilton, Composer: Patrick Hawes, Librettist: Andrew Hawes   (Norfolk, 2015). 

This is a wonderful opportunity for children to work closely with professional artists to develop, nurture and build skills in creativity and self-confidence.

Into Opera will also provide teachers with resources and workshops aimed at embedding creativity into the whole curriculum.

A King’s Ransom is the core of our education project and will enable us to carry out our mission: to put creativity at the pulse of education.

Into Opera has formed a partnership with the Prince's Foundation for Children and the Arts, a charity which helps disadvantaged children across the UK to become involved with the arts. With the support of the Prince’s Foundation, Into Opera plans to develop the project beyond the premiere of A King’s Ransom so that it becomes a national education project, reaching schools in need of it most.

At a time when school subjects engendering creativity and imagination seem to be valued less and less, Into Opera and Children and the Arts will endeavour to put some of the creative spirit back.

How Can You Help?

Into Opera's goal of raising £10,000 goal will help to secure major components of this project as shown below. 

1st Funding Goal: £5000. This will pay for each child to work with a professional designer to design and create their costume. For each child, this will cost £25.   


2nd Funding Goal: £2,200. This will pay for a professional 11 piece orchestra to perform alongside the children at the premiere. So, one individual donation of £200 will pay for one orchestral instrument!

3rd Funding Goal: £2,800. This will ensure we can pay the initial costs to secure a premiere class venue to stage A King's Ransom. We would love to give children the opportunity to perform and experience the inner workings of a professional theatre.

Your support counts. By actively helping us to raise £10,000 for some key components of this project, you will also help us to build a compelling case to present to the Arts Council in order to gain the remaining £65,000 required to bring this project to life. With your support, we can convince them that this is not a project to be dismissed.

Help us prove to the Arts Council that an investment in A King’s Ransom is an investment worth making.

The money applied for will be used to cover payment for the artists'  time, the educational resources for schools (Key Stage 2 Curriculum activity packs, learning aids for the music and vocal scores), the props and set, a workshop with the orchestra, rehearsal time at the venue and Into Opera's administration costs.

Who Are We?

Our company was founded by two good friends and colleagues, Genevieve Raghu and Benjamin Hamilton. They met at the University of Warwick in 2008 and quickly developed a shared passion for the way in which opera could touch people’s lives. Genevieve and Ben launched a tour of Henry Purcell's ‘Dido and Aeneas’ across the West Midlands and brought it to Covent Garden, London. Later, the pair staged a striking production of 'The Threepenny Opera' at Warwick Arts Centre.

Genevieve went on to run a 10 week project for children exploring Mozart’s opera, 'The Magic Flute'. The experience left Genevieve stunned by the level of creativity and sensitivity that sprang from the children involved with this project. Opera and its fusion of drama, dance, music and poetry, to tell one compelling story, created unity amongst the children. There was greater respect, individual expression and collaboration. Opera empowered those children and unlocked their imaginations. Our co-founders have continued working extensively in the arts across the UK and in other parts of Europe.

Now, Genevieve and Ben have united to make something special happen. 
Our aim: get more people Into Opera! 
How will we do it: Into Opera will stage new, bold opera productions integrated with imaginative education projects, starting with the children’s opera, A King’s Ransom.

How Else Can You Help?

For those of you who can’t help us reach our goal, you can still make a difference:
Spread the word! Support our campaign through telling your friends and family about our cause. You can do this online through the Indiegogo share tools on the left hand side of this page. The more noise we can make, the better chance we have of giving these children this amazing experience they would not otherwise experience! 
Volunteer with us! Into Opera will be welcoming help from volunteers on different aspects of the project, these could include educational roles and helping with costume and set design. If you would like to get involved then this information will be updated on the company website when available. 
Work with us! To realise this project we will be looking for designers, choreographers, education artists and stage managers to build our creative team. So please do look out for postings for such opportunities.
story_txt:
Help us to play a role in putting some imagination back into education.
 We are facing a crisis as this is under threat.
Creativity is being squeezed out of schools across the UK. As a country we seem to have lost sight of its importance during those vital, formative years.
But what does this mean for future generations?

We expect many things from schools; we want our children to gain all sorts of skills. Amongst these, we want to see them listening with understanding, learning to work with others and experiencing what it means to take the lead. We hope they will learn to look, think and have ideas and, then, be confident about expressing those ideas. Taking part in cultural activities gives children the chance to develop and practice these skills. 
But with these experiences being increasingly rationed how will the challenges of an increasingly complex world be met?   


Who will be doing the creative thinking, the collaborating and communicating in the future?



If we are going to develop the next generation of politicians, scientists, entrepreneurs, artists… who will discover, imagine and lead, then it is imperative for creativity to thrive.
In a bid to combat the squeezing out of the creative spirit in schools, Into Opera has created a unique Education Project which will immerse children in an exciting cultural experience and encourage creativity and imagination across the whole curriculum.
Our creative team running a workshop with 11-year-olds to develop A King's Ransom (Norwich, 2012).
Help us play a role in securing the UK as a creative nation
Into Opera's project can make an impact. It will bring 200 children, from 4 schools, from different social backgrounds together. 200 children will be offered a truly unique experience. Integrating, collaborating and working side by side, these children will stage a brand new opera. They will work with a composer, a librettist and a range of professional artists to explore this all encompassing art form and discover how a production develops from its inception through to a full-scale production. Into Opera will work closely with teachers. In fact, the aim is for teachers, parents and children of all four schools to come together with this opera at its core.  
Into Opera hopes to demonstrate the numerous ways in which cultural activity can really encourage the creative imagination across the whole curriculum. All children deserve a high quality cultural education. The multifaceted nature of opera can inspire and empower children; it can help them become what UNESCO calls an 'all round complete person’.
A King's Ransom
Into Opera has teamed up with the acclaimed British Classical Composer, Patrick Hawes. The project is focussed upon working with children aged 7-11 to stage the Professional World Premiere of Patrick’s children’s opera, A King’s Ransom.
The opera offers an unusual twist on the well-known story of Robin Hood. It explores what happens when Robin is unable to save the day, and instead, the community must look within itself for answers to its problems.
A King’s Ransom was originally written in 1994. Now, 21 years later, Patrick and  brother Andy, the opera's librettist, are returning to this work with fresh eyes and collaborating with Into Opera to revise and expand the work. The characters in the opera clearly split into four chorus sections: the villagers, soldiers, bagmen and masons. Each of these chorus sections will be performed by an individual school.

A King's Ransom's creative team : Stage Director: Genevieve Raghu, Musical Director: Benjamin Hamilton, Composer: Patrick Hawes, Librettist: Andrew Hawes   (Norfolk, 2015). 
This is a wonderful opportunity for children to work closely with professional artists to develop, nurture and build skills in creativity and self-confidence.
Into Opera will also provide teachers with resources and workshops aimed at embedding creativity into the whole curriculum.
A King’s Ransom is the core of our education project and will enable us to carry out our mission: to put creativity at the pulse of education.
Into Opera has formed a partnership with the Prince's Foundation for Children and the Arts, a charity which helps disadvantaged children across the UK to become involved with the arts. With the support of the Prince’s Foundation, Into Opera plans to develop the project beyond the premiere of A King’s Ransom so that it becomes a national education project, reaching schools in need of it most.
At a time when school subjects engendering creativity and imagination seem to be valued less and less, Into Opera and Children and the Arts will endeavour to put some of the creative spirit back.
How Can You Help?
Into Opera's goal of raising £10,000 goal will help to secure major components of this project as shown below. 



1st Funding Goal: £5000. This will pay for each child to work with a professional designer to design and create their costume. For each child, this will cost £25.   










2nd Funding Goal: £2,200. This will pay for a professional 11 piece orchestra to perform alongside the children at the premiere. So, one individual donation of £200 will pay for one orchestral instrument!






3rd Funding Goal: £2,800. This will ensure we can pay the initial costs to secure a premiere class venue to stage A King's Ransom. We would love to give children the opportunity to perform and experience the inner workings of a professional theatre.



Your support counts. By actively helping us to raise £10,000 for some key components of this project, you will also help us to build a compelling case to present to the Arts Council in order to gain the remaining £65,000 required to bring this project to life. With your support, we can convince them that this is not a project to be dismissed.
Help us prove to the Arts Council that an investment in A King’s Ransom is an investment worth making.
The money applied for will be used to cover payment for the artists'  time, the educational resources for schools (Key Stage 2 Curriculum activity packs, learning aids for the music and vocal scores), the props and set, a workshop with the orchestra, rehearsal time at the venue and Into Opera's administration costs.
Who Are We?



Our company was founded by two good friends and colleagues, Genevieve Raghu and Benjamin Hamilton. They met at the University of Warwick in 2008 and quickly developed a shared passion for the way in which opera could touch people’s lives. Genevieve and Ben launched a tour of Henry Purcell's ‘Dido and Aeneas’ across the West Midlands and brought it to Covent Garden, London. Later, the pair staged a striking production of 'The Threepenny Opera' at Warwick Arts Centre.
Genevieve went on to run a 10 week project for children exploring Mozart’s opera, 'The Magic Flute'. The experience left Genevieve stunned by the level of creativity and sensitivity that sprang from the children involved with this project. Opera and its fusion of drama, dance, music and poetry, to tell one compelling story, created unity amongst the children. There was greater respect, individual expression and collaboration. Opera empowered those children and unlocked their imaginations. Our co-founders have continued working extensively in the arts across the UK and in other parts of Europe.
Now, Genevieve and Ben have united to make something special happen. 



Our aim: get more people Into Opera! 



How will we do it: Into Opera will stage new, bold opera productions integrated with imaginative education projects, starting with the children’s opera, A King’s Ransom.





How Else Can You Help?


For those of you who can’t help us reach our goal, you can still make a difference:


Spread the word! Support our campaign through telling your friends and family about our cause. You can do this online through the Indiegogo share tools on the left hand side of this page. The more noise we can make, the better chance we have of giving these children this amazing experience they would not otherwise experience! 



Volunteer with us! Into Opera will be welcoming help from volunteers on different aspects of the project, these could include educational roles and helping with costume and set design. If you would like to get involved then this information will be updated on the company website when available. 



Work with us! To realise this project we will be looking for designers, choreographers, education artists and stage managers to build our creative team. So please do look out for postings for such opportunities.

story:
Opera'r Ddraig

Opera'r Ddraig is a unique and exciting social enterprise, committed to providing a professional platform for young people who are preparing for, or in the early stages of, a career in opera performance, production administration or education. Founded, and based in the Royal Welsh College of Music and Drama, Opera'r Ddraig were the winners of the 2010 Wales Future Entrepreneur Award and have gone from strength to strength.

Previous performances have included Mozart's Cosi fan Tutte, The Magic Flute andThe Marriage of Figaro, Offenbach's Orpheus in the Underworld, Handel's Acis and Galatea, Purcell's Dido and Aeneas, Bizet's Carmen and Humperdink's Hansel and Gretel. In addition, the company toured to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2013, and recently traveled to Colwyn Bay to perform at Ysgol Bryn Elian, both with great success.

Why we need your help

Opera'r Ddraig do not charge performers to take part in our performances or to be a member and, as such, are reliant on donations and other privately sourced funding to make our dreams a reality. We need to raise critical funds to cover everything from costumes to programmes to score purchases.

How will your money be used?

Opera'r Ddraig is an incredibly valuable company to the performers, creative team, administrative and marketing team, and the dedicated audiences who benefit from seeing its vibrant and fresh productions year on year. However, without financial support and donations the much loved productions of Opera'r Ddraig cannot make it to the stage.

Your money will support the cast and production team through what promises to be a new and exciting production. Even the smallest amount will make a difference so please support us in any way that you can. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to contribute financially, you can still help by publicising our campaign to others. Please pass on our campaign information to your friends/family/neighbours/colleagues/dogs and anyone else that you think might be interested. (An easy way to do this is to use the Indiegogo share tools).

The more people that get involved, the greater this next production can be!!

story:
The Rogue and Peasant Players is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Rogue and Peasant Players must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Prefer to donate the old fashioned way? Come on out to our Fundraising event in midtown manhattan December 5th. 

"And let us...on your imaginary forces work"

Hello! We are the Rogue and Peasant Players, a theatre company that treats the text as our primary production value. We are led by:

  • Malka Wallick- A RADA and Sarah Lawrence trained Shakespearean actress and scholar. Her fervent belief in the power of Shakespeare united the Rogues.  
  • Kelly Monroe Johnston- The former artistic director of the Arizona Shakespeare Festival and a stage director with over two decades of experience, He loves it when you call him "Big Papa Johnston"
  • Tim Dowd- A Shakespeare & Company trained actor and writer. He has made the not at all maddening decision to manage a theatre company's budget.

We at the RP&P believe in producing the works of William Shakespeare as well as new and emerging playwright's who have been inspired by his words. We just want to tell you a good story...which brings us to:

HENRY V

by William Shakespeare

Directed by Kelly Monroe Johnston

Access Theater

380 Broadway 

New York NY 10013

January 28th-February 14th

"...a kingdom for a stage, princes to act..."

After the success of our last production "R+J" we are moving on to our very first in a long line of Shakespeare productions. One of the reasons for choosing this play is the chorus' frustrated plea at the top of the show. Trying to cram one of England's greatest histories, a story involving the rise of a king and multiple battles, into a wooden theater on the bank of the Thames. We won't be performing in a wooden theater (thankfully) nor on the bank of the Thames (unfortunately) but we are similarly bringing this massive story to the stage, and that requires resources, and for that we need you.

  • We have rented the beautiful Access Theater space in SoHo!
  • We have hired a talented music director and are providing her with found instruments to give a evolving and unique live score to every performance!
  • We are providing stipends for our talented Rogues, regardless of union affiliation!
  • Our show's lighting is being designed by Susannah Baron of "Sleep No More" fame!

This brings our budget to a total of 10,000 dollars. With that we will be able to share our vision of this play with you and the world. To reach our goal, we need your help. So make your tax deductible donation and choose one of our exciting perks!


"...once more into the breech dear friends..."

A wise man once said "one of the easiest things to do is to produce theater in New York"

...what?

oh no one said that?

Are we sure?

...hmmm. Sooooo apparently producing theatre in NYC is not easy. Who knew? But we have a team that is up to the task.

  • Our company has some of the best training in the industry, from places such as RADA, LAMDA, NYU, Shakespeare & Company and many others.
  • Our director, Kelly Monroe Johnston is a stage director with more than 25 years experience including 12 years as the Artistic Director of the Arizona Shakespeare Festival. 
  • Our marketing team has spent the past year building a following on social media sites to make sure that we'll have an audience to fill those seats.
  • Our last production, "R+J" sold out one third of it's performances and was met with glowing reviews like this one from OnStage.

"...and monarchs to behold the swelling scene.."

So you want to help but you just can't contribute, what can you do?
  •  Whelp, every little bit truly does help. The Indiegogo algorithm favors campaigns with many donors, so even a 5 dollar donation does help bring attention to our campaign which could help us reach our goal. 
  • You can use any of the share buttons right here on this page to help spread the word about us on social media. 
  • Beyond that? Come on out to the show! We're kinda partial to ol' Billy Shakes and we'd love to share his story with all of you.

story:
SHORT SUMMARY

Omnia Dance is an eclectic company focused on dance for film in hopes to touch people all around the world. We want to provide a collaborative atmosphere so that we introduce a variety of dance for everyone to enjoy.

The company is directed by award-winning choreographer Kaitlin Bauld. All six company members have different dance backgrounds and bring wonderful energy to the company.

Since Omnia is new, they are in the process of building a versatile repertoire that they can't wait to share. In order for the WORLD to see it, they have to film and produce it, and this takes time and money.

WHAT WE NEED

From space to rehearse, filming equipment, to costumes and editing, it takes quite a team to make one of these amazing dance films. In the next year we hope to create FOUR more dance films, below is the breakdown of the cost for each film:

DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY - $500.00

FILM EDITOR - $500.00

VENUE - $1,000.00

EQUIPMENT - $1,000.00

COSTUMES - $300.00

TRAVEL EXPENSES - $200.00

REHEARSAL SPACE - $1,000.00

MISC. (food, makeup, permits, unexpected expenses)- $500.00

Altogether, to create four more dance films in the next year, we need roughly $17,000 to do so.

YOUR IMPACT

How amazing would it be to say that you contributed to a company that reached people globally?

Omnia has big hopes and dreams that their professional company will inspire others to dance and create. If this campaign should be successful, we hope this creates interest in others to be a part of the company, whether it be to choreograph, dance, or even produce our next film.

After gaining momentum, Omnia wants to stretch beyond film and eventually perform live, perhaps start a school and give back to the community that has been so gracious to them. All we want to do is share our love of dance, we just need a little help to do so.

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

First, putting your creative self out to the world is a risk. We are risking that people may not support what we are doing. However, the dance and artisitic worlds tend to be some of the most supportive communites out there. But there are still challanges. The biggest challenge will be gaining popularity, people wanting to see our dances and wanting more. That is why it will be crucial to create these dance films and show everyone what we are all about: versatility, collaboration, family, community, beauty, dance.

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everyone can donate money. But you can still help us out! You can help us by word of mouth and make noise about Omnia Dance Company. Please share this campiagn and you can also follow us on Instagram and Twitter.

Please also utilize the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank You!

Omnia Dance Company

story:
The Project

you & i Theatre is run by Co-Artistic Directors Kevin Kraussler and Ming Hudson.  Our mandate is to create works of devised physical theatre that promote social change.

We are so excited to finally be bringing The Air Loom to the stage this year!

We will have our world premiere performance at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival in August 2016 (the largest Fringe Theatre Festival in North America) and then tour our production to the Vancouver International Fringe Festival in September.

This project has been a passion for co-creators Ming Hudson and Kevin Kraussler since 2012. They have held various development workshops and enlisted the dramaturgical assistance of Jan Derbyshire and Jack Paterson to assist them in discovering this new play. Yoshié Bancroft is the latest co-creator to join forces with you & i Theatre to direct The Air Loom. Costumes and graphic design for this production have been created by Keira Daniels.

The Air Loom has two parallel intersecting storylines.  The first takes place in 18th Century London and follows the real-life story of James Tilly Matthews, the first person to be diagnosed with schizophrenia. Matthews believed himself to be antagonized by a gang of strange characters whom he claimed had influence over his thoughts through the use of a loom made of air. The second story takes place in present day British Columbia, and centers around a young child whose parent is experiencing delusional behavior for the first time, and their subsequent diagnosis with schizophrenia.  Just as Matthews had experienced hundreds of years earlier, the parent too believes themselves to be stalked by mysterious strangers, the difference being that they are certain these villains are electronically monitoring and invading their home.  This aspect of the play draws on Kraussler’s personal experience growing up in a household with a schizophrenic family member. These two seemingly separate stories are linked by the Air Loom Gang, a terrifying and complex group of mercenaries who exist outside of time.  They target both the parent and Matthews, altering their victims’ behaviour with the symptoms of schizophrenia.

There is currently a stigma around issues concerning mental wellness in Canada even though roughly 1 in every 4 people will be diagnosed with some form of mental health issue within their lifetime.  Approximately 1 in every 100 people are schizophrenic.  For this community, and for the people who love them, it is important to tell the stories of those afflicted by schizophrenia in order to open up a dialogue about the condition, and to reduce the stigma that interferes with integration and acceptance of those with this illness.  

you & i Theatre will be donating 5% of our box office take to the BC Schizophrenia Society. 

What We Need

There are many costs associated with producing and touring your own theatre work!

  • Fringe Festival registration fees for both Edmonton and Vancouver! 
  • Venue Rental fee for a Bring You Own Venue at the Vancouver Fringe! 
  • Canadian Actor's Equity Association union fees! 
  • Costume materials! 
  • Poster and Flyer printing costs! 
  • Car Rental and Gas to get to and from Edmonton!

Who We Are

MING HUDSON - creator/performer 

Ming Hudson is performer and deviser who is extremely passionate about the creation of new theatre as a collective ensemble, especially when this creation is rooted in the practice of physical theatre. A graduate of The London International School of Performing Arts, Ming also holds a Masters in Ensemble Theatre from Rose Bruford College and a BFA in Acting from the University of Victoria.  Select recent acting credits include: PostSecret: The Show (The Firehall Arts Centre), A Study on the Stillness of Love (Blackout Creative Arts), The Little Leaf (Inside I'm a Mermaid), Big Bad and Fall Away Home (Boca del Lupo), and The Penelopiad (The Arts Club Theatre Company).  Ming also spent the past year working as the Associate Producer Intern at Boca del Lupo, and is very proud to have been the administrator for The 3.7% Initiative.  Besides the Air Loom, she can be seen next in Generation Post Script (Nebula Company Theatre) at Performance Works in Vancouver this July and will be a member of the core creation team for the The Circus Project (Twenty-Something Theatre) in October. 

KEVIN KRAUSSLER - creator/performer

Kevin Kraussler is a graduate of the Bachelor of Fine Arts Acting Program at the University of British Columbia.  He was cast in the 2007 season of Bard on the Beach while a student at UBC.  His career has since focused on daring new work and innovative adaptations of classical theatre. Kevin has performed in numerous world premiere pieces: The Mechanical Bride written collaboratively by himself , Ming Hudson, Quinn Harris, James Foy, and Graham Newmarch for Gasheart Theatre for the 2008 Vancouver and Victoria International Fringe Festivals, The Cabinet of Doctor Caligari for Somnambulist productions for the aforementioned festivals in 2010 which was adapted from the original  film script by  Chris Kattner, By Some Divine Mistake for Vital Spark Theatre written by Joan Bryans (to be published next year), Macbeth: nach Shakespeare written by Heiner Muller and translated by Carl Weber for Theatre Conspiracy/Gasheart Theatre, Falling in Time for Screaming Weenie Theatre/Meta For Theatre/The Vancouver Playhouse Theatre written by Chris Gatchalian (recently published), and finally Unstuck for The Frank Theatre written by Evan Tsitsias.   

YOSHIÉ BANCROFT- creator/director 

Yoshie is very excited to be part of the development of The Air Loom.  Recent theatre credits include Ithaka (dream of passions / Excavation Theatre), Pride and Prejudice (Arts Club), Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike, Home is a Beautiful Word (Belfry), Tour (Universal Ltd.) — a show she co-created with support from The Electric Company for Hive 3 and toured to Toronto for Summerworks — and Cocktails at Pam’s (Staircase).  Other favourite roles include ‘Lydia’ in Big Love (UBC) and ‘Zhaboonigan’ in The Rez Sisters (UBC).  Since graduating from UBC, Yoshié has worked steadily in film and TV; notable credits include Emily Owens M.D., The Flash, Bates Motel, Supernatural, Impastor, and Pancake Breakfast, which screened in Austin at SXSW.  @YoshieBancroft

KEIRA DANNIELS - costume and graphic designer 

Keira Danniels comes from Nelson,BC and holds a BFA with an emphasis in Costume Design from the University of Victoria. During her time at the University she was employed as a Wardrobe Work Study in the Costume Department while simultaneously completing her costuming credits on Phoenix Theatre shows. Upon graduation Keira was hired by the Capilano Suspension Bridge, where for three years she ran the Costume Department and completed the design and manufacturing of her own clothing line. Keira then moved abroad to Wales for a number of years, where she picked up credits as a Costume Standby on the BBC show Casualty. Additional credits include Costume Assistant on the short film RIPPED and the short film Mars Bitch, as well as Phoenix Theatre credits in Wind in the Willows, School for Scandal, and Tartuffe. Keira delights in costume design's ability to spark an audience’s imagination and reveal a character's inner workings. She specializes in creating garments that serve multiple purposes and can be used to show transformation on stage. Keira currently lives in Vancouver,BC.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help! 

You can get the word out and make some noise about our campaign by sharing it on social media!
story_txt:
The Project 

you & i Theatre is run by Co-Artistic Directors Kevin
Kraussler and Ming Hudson.  Our mandate is to create works of devised physical
theatre that promote social change.
We are so excited to finally be bringing The
Air Loom to the stage this year! 
We will have our world premiere performance
at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival in August 2016 (the largest
Fringe Theatre Festival in North America) and then tour our production to the
Vancouver International Fringe Festival in September. 
This project has been a passion for
co-creators Ming Hudson and Kevin Kraussler since 2012. They have held various
development workshops and enlisted the dramaturgical assistance of Jan
Derbyshire and Jack Paterson to assist them in discovering this new play. Yoshié Bancroft is the latest co-creator to join forces with you & i Theatre to direct The Air Loom. Costumes and graphic design for this
production have been created by Keira Daniels.
The Air Loom has two parallel intersecting
storylines.  The first takes place in 18th Century London and follows the real-life story of James
Tilly Matthews, the first person to be diagnosed with schizophrenia. Matthews
believed himself to be antagonized by a gang of strange characters whom he
claimed had influence over his thoughts through the use of a loom made of air. The second story takes place in present day British Columbia, and centers around a young child whose parent is experiencing delusional behavior for the first time, and their subsequent diagnosis with schizophrenia.  Just as Matthews had experienced hundreds of years earlier, the parent too believes themselves to be stalked by mysterious strangers, the difference being that they are certain these villains are electronically monitoring and invading their home.  This aspect of the play draws on Kraussler’s personal experience growing up in a household with a schizophrenic family member. These two seemingly separate stories are linked by the Air Loom Gang, a
terrifying and complex group of mercenaries who exist outside of time.  They target both the parent and Matthews, altering
their victims’ behaviour with the symptoms of schizophrenia.
There is currently a stigma around issues concerning mental
wellness in Canada even though roughly 1 in every 4 people will be diagnosed
with some form of mental health issue within their lifetime.
 Approximately 1 in every 100 people are schizophrenic.  For this
community, and for the people who love them, it is important to tell the stories of those afflicted by schizophrenia in order to open up a dialogue about the condition,
and to reduce the stigma that interferes with integration and acceptance of
those with this illness.  
you & i Theatre will be donating 5% of our box office take to the BC Schizophrenia Society. 

What We Need
There are many costs associated with producing and touring your own theatre work!
 Fringe Festival registration fees for both Edmonton and Vancouver! 
Venue Rental fee for a Bring You Own Venue at the Vancouver Fringe! 
Canadian Actor's Equity Association union fees! 
Costume materials! 
Poster and Flyer printing costs! 
Car Rental and Gas to get to and from Edmonton!


    Who We Are


MING HUDSON - creator/performer 
Ming Hudson is performer and deviser who is extremely
passionate about the creation of new theatre as a collective ensemble,
especially when this creation is rooted in the practice of physical theatre. A graduate
of The London International School of Performing Arts, Ming also holds a
Masters in Ensemble Theatre from Rose Bruford College and a BFA in Acting from the
University of Victoria.  Select
recent acting credits include: PostSecret:
The Show (The Firehall Arts Centre), A Study on the Stillness of
Love (Blackout Creative
Arts), The Little Leaf (Inside I'm a Mermaid), Big
Bad and Fall Away Home (Boca del Lupo), and The Penelopiad (The Arts Club Theatre Company).  Ming also spent the past year working as the Associate Producer
Intern at Boca del Lupo, and is very proud to have been the administrator for The
3.7% Initiative.  Besides the Air Loom, she can
be seen next in Generation Post Script (Nebula Company
Theatre) at Performance Works in Vancouver this July and will be a member of the core creation team for the The Circus Project (Twenty-Something Theatre) in October. 
KEVIN KRAUSSLER - creator/performer
Kevin Kraussler is a graduate of the Bachelor of Fine Arts Acting Program at the University of British Columbia.  He was cast in the 2007 season of Bard on the Beach while a student at UBC.  His career has since focused on daring new work and innovative adaptations of classical theatre. Kevin has performed in numerous world premiere pieces: The Mechanical Bride written collaboratively by himself , Ming Hudson, Quinn Harris, James Foy, and Graham Newmarch for Gasheart Theatre for the 2008 Vancouver and Victoria International Fringe Festivals, The Cabinet of Doctor Caligari for Somnambulist productions for the aforementioned festivals in 2010 which was adapted from the original  film script by  Chris Kattner, By Some Divine Mistake for Vital Spark Theatre written by Joan Bryans (to be published next year), Macbeth: nach Shakespeare written by Heiner Muller and translated by Carl Weber for Theatre Conspiracy/Gasheart Theatre, Falling in Time for Screaming Weenie Theatre/Meta For Theatre/The Vancouver Playhouse Theatre written by Chris Gatchalian (recently published), and finally Unstuck for The Frank Theatre written by Evan Tsitsias.   
YOSHIÉ BANCROFT- creator/director 
Yoshie is very excited to be part of the development of The Air Loom.  Recent theatre credits include Ithaka (dream of passions / Excavation Theatre), Pride and Prejudice (Arts Club), Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike, Home is a Beautiful Word (Belfry), Tour (Universal Ltd.) — a show she co-created with support from The Electric Company for Hive 3 and toured to Toronto for Summerworks — and Cocktails at Pam’s (Staircase).  Other favourite roles include ‘Lydia’ in Big Love (UBC) and ‘Zhaboonigan’ in The Rez Sisters (UBC).  Since graduating from UBC, Yoshié has worked steadily in film and TV; notable credits include Emily Owens M.D., The Flash, Bates Motel, Supernatural, Impastor, and Pancake Breakfast, which screened in Austin at SXSW.  @YoshieBancroft
KEIRA DANNIELS - costume and graphic designer 


Keira Danniels comes from Nelson,BC and
holds a BFA with an emphasis in Costume Design from the University of Victoria.
During her time at the University she was employed as a Wardrobe Work Study in
the Costume Department while simultaneously completing her costuming credits on
Phoenix Theatre shows. Upon graduation Keira was hired by the Capilano
Suspension Bridge, where for three years she ran the Costume Department and
completed the design and manufacturing of her own clothing line. Keira then
moved abroad to Wales for a number of years, where she picked up credits as a
Costume Standby on the BBC show Casualty.
Additional credits include Costume Assistant on the short film RIPPED and the short film Mars Bitch, as well as Phoenix Theatre
credits in Wind in the Willows, School for Scandal, and Tartuffe. Keira delights in costume
design's ability to spark an audience’s imagination and reveal a character's
inner workings. She specializes in creating garments that serve multiple
purposes and can be used to show transformation on stage. Keira currently lives
in Vancouver,BC.   Other Ways You Can Help Even if you can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help! 
You can get the word out and make some noise about our campaign by sharing it on social media!

story:
Excitingly last July I received a place on the MFA Choreography at Roehampton University. Unfortunately at the time, I was given an International fee place and could not afford the deposit, let alone the fee for this place. After months of careful follow up from both sides however, it transpired that I did indeed qualify for a UK based fee place - so commencing my Masters this September entered the realms of possibility!!

The University of Roehampton has one of the best Dance departments in the world and I am absolutely delighted to be given the chance to study there.The two year programme gives emerging choreographers the time and space to develop their artistic practice with the support and mentorship of highly talented and experienced teachers. This is an opportunity that I am really craving at this point in my dancing journey...to build upon what I have and with guidance and support take the next leap to where I want to be.

My plan is to raise the first instalment of my tuition fees which totals £4000. I am continuing my method of raising funds in bite-sized pieces so have been busy running fund-raiser dance classes, holding bake-sales etc. I am hoping to raise £1000 through this Kickstarter campaign which is a fairly big bite so to speak, but if I can find 100 people willing to lend or give me £10, then it is possible! I have added a 'Social lending' aspect to this campaign whereby if you can temporarily lend me money, then I will send you an IOU and repay you within an agreed timeframe. Essentially I am testing an idea of sourcing a loan from a community as opposed to an institution...we'll see how it fares! Future fee instalments I hope to cover through a bank loan (when eligible), grants and/or scholarships.

I would be incredibly grateful for any support you are able to give me towards this goal of mine. If you have any questions about what I am up to please do not hesitate to ask. 

Many thanks!

Anna

story:
The New England New Play Anthology is designed to show the rest of the world some of our most exciting New England playwrights and their plays. We are partnering with Smith & Kraus to publish the anthology.  They will do a 2,000 copy paperback print run, distributed nationally by them and on their web site, and it will also be an ebook.  We have already solicited scripts from New England theater companies and we have a selection committee in place who are working on selecting the plays to be published.  The Anthology will contain between 4 - 6 new full-length plays written by New England playwrights, as well as a handful of short plays. Each of the plays was nominated by a New England theater company, who produced that play on their stages.


Though we have a vibrant new play scene in New England, it’s very difficult for our regional writers to find productions of their plays in other parts of the country. This book will put the script in the hands of theater lovers all across the country. Our hope is that these plays that first found life on stage here in New England will find new incarnations, for new audiences. We want New England to be a net-exporter of theatrical creativity, and this book can help that happen.



The New Play Alliance-

The New England New Play Alliance is a group of theater companies, playwrights, directors, arts advocates, and students coming together to support new plays created in New England. They work to:

  • Grow audiences for new plays.

  • Encourage more new play development and production.

  • Spread the word outside of Boston about plays/playwrights from Greater Boston/New England”

The New England New Play Alliance currently publishes a free weekly New Play Newsletter that details all the new play events happening in New England. We also released a study on new play attendance in Greater Boston from 2012-2014 and have many other working groups and projects underway.


StageSource-

StageSource provides leadership and services to advance the art of theater in the Greater Boston and New England region. Our mission is to unite theater artists, theater companies, and related organizations in vision and goals that inspire and empower our community to realize its greatest artistic potential.


The lead fundraisers for this project include Patrick Gabridge, a local Boston playwright, Julie Hennrikus, Executive Director of StageSource.




  • In order to get the book published, the publishing company needs us to guarantee that we can sell a minimum of 500 books.

  • We have had Theater Companies around Boston pledge to buy 233 copies.

  • This means that we are 267 copies short.

  • In addition to copies, we also need to raise money for author royalties, post-publication marketing, and to pay some our readers.

  • If we do not raise this money, the book will not be published and these fantastic plays won’t be shared with theaters, actors, directors, writers, and other theaters across the country.

  • We are a group of theater artists in New England invested in showcasing new voices, ideas, and stories. As theater folk, we constantly put together projects that need to happen on budget, and on time.

  • We are working collaboratively with playwrights and theater companies. The playwrights have a lot at stake in seeing this book published and published well.

  • Patrick Gabridge and Julie Hennrikus are both published authors who value stories. They have gone through the publishing process. They know what to expect, and know how to approach this.

  • The selection committee has already been working tirelessly to select the plays for the Anthology.

  • The publisher, Smith & Kraus, is highly respected and publishes numerous anthologies of plays, scenes, and monologues.


Campaign Calendar

  • Monday March 21st, 2016 - Campaign Launch Date

  • Friday March 25th, 2016 - First supporter update goes out

  • Monday March 28th, 2016 - Second Update goes out

  • Monday, April 4th, 2016 - Third Update goes out

  • Monday, April 21st, 2016 - LAST DAY FOR CAMPAIGN



  • $30 USD -- “New Play Anthology Book”: Unlimited; Copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $40 USD -- “Signed Copy”: Out of 50; Signed copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $50 USD -- “Julianne Holmes Book Bundle”: Out of 2; Get a copy of Julianne Holmes’ new book Just Killing Time plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $50 USD -- “Patrick Gabridge Book Bundle”: Out of 5; Get a copy of Patrick Gabridge’s book Steering to Freedom plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $75 USD -- “Huntington Theatre”: Out of 20; 2 Tickets to an upcoming show at the Huntington Theatre plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $75 USD -- “Merrimack Repertory Theatre”: Out of 2; 2 Tickets to an upcoming show at the Merrimack Repertory Theatre plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $75 USD -- “Fresh Ink Theatre”: Out of 1; 1 Season Pass to Fresh Ink Theatre plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $75 USD -- “Wilbury Theatre Group”: Out of 3; 2 Tickets to an upcoming show at the Wilbury Theatre Group plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $75 USD -- “Boston Playwrights Theatre”: Out of  2; 2 Season Passes to Boston Playwrights Theatre plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $75 USD -- “Blood on the Snow”: Out of 1; 2 Tickets to Blood on the Snowby Patrick Gabridge, courtesy of The Bostonian Society plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $75 USD -- “Dine Out at Ester Restaurant”: Out of 2; $50 gift card to Ester Restaurant plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $75 USD -- “Porter Square Books” : Out of 2; $50 gift card to Porter Square Books plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $90 USD -- “Patron of the Anthology”: Unlimited; name listed in the anthology, plus a signed copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $100 USD -- “Be Part of New England’s Theatre Community”: Out of 2; 2 Individual StageSource memberships plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

  • $200 USD -- “Become a Character”: Out of 1; Have a character named after you in Julianne Holmes’ next book plus a copy of the New Play Anthology

story:
Our production is slated for a four-week run, beginning Aug. 4, 2017, at the Pan Andreas Theater, in Hollywood, CA. The show is produced by Proof Doubt Closer co-founder, Trace Oakley (who will also direct) and Alena Bernardi (who will musical direct and play the glamorous Lily Garland).

ON THE TWENTIETH CENTURY will be the third production of the Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company, following its critically acclaimed re-imagining of Gilbert and Sullivan's RUDDIGORE, and the musical revue, CARRIE THAT TUNE: HIT SONGS FROM FLOP MUSICALS. Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company is dedicated to revisiting plays and musicals that fell through the cracks: long-neglected hits, should-a-been successes, ahead-of-their-time flops, and other works that deserve a dusting-off, a hand-up and a new lease on life. We are also dedicated to developing new works, and adaptations. Our name is, in fact, and ironic twist on our mission, as we seek and embrace the rarely-performed buried treasures, and leave the PROOF, DOUBT and CLOSERs of the world to others.

Being just a shade more than a year old, the Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company has progressed well beyond our expectations, in terms of our audience reception, name recognition, but mostly in terms of the performers and other artists who have carried over from one show to the next. We know we are headed in the right direction when outstanding artists want to continue working with us, and also join our production team.

We hope you can see, via this page, and through our videos and postings during this campaign, that we are truly passionate about this very special project, and about theatre itself. It is, after all, much more than just a ticket, a good seat or an excuse to dress up. It’s the live reactions, the actors and audience breathing the same air, the thrill, energy and even danger that only a live performance can bring.

Part of our job, once we hit the stage, is to make it all look seamless and easy. Let us tell you, easy is hard work. And, even with many participants volunteering their artistic abilities, producing a musical is also rather expensive. Here's a look at the major items on the tab.

 

_____________________________________________________________________
 

_____________________________________________________________________

Lead Actor/Musical Director/Producer/Campaign Manager

Ever since she was 4 years old Alena had a passion for putting on plays and productions. Any chance she would get to order her little brother or cousins or friends at her daycare around and "Make a Play" as she would say; she would. This fascination with using groups of humans to portray a story continued through middle school (where she discovered her love of singing), high school (where she started producing her own shows), college where she studied Classical Voice and participated in school operas, and on to Los Angeles where she Co-Founded Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company. Alena has starred in all three of Proof Doubt's debut productions. First in her title role as the wide eyed Rose Maybud  in Gilbert and Sullivan's "RuddiGORE," then the sassy Legs in their musical review titled '"Carrie" That tune! Hit Songs From Flop Musicals," and finally now she takes on the most challenging role she has taken on to date; the glamorous Lily Garland in "ON THE TWENTIETH CENTURY." As Alena always says: GO TEAM!

Director/Producer/Campaign Manager 

TRACE OAKLEY has directed more than 50 productions, and has more than 100 additional productions to his credit as either actor, playwright, producer, or administrator, working in his home town of Denver, on both coasts, and on national and international tours. Los Angeles directing credits include PEARLY GATES (El Portal Theatre), CRIMES OF THE HEART (Windward JG), LOVERS AND OTHER STRANGERS (Avery Schreiber Playhouse), BOB CRATCHIT AND MR. TIGHTWAD (Secret Rose Theater), RUDDIGORE (Studio/Stage), STANDING ON MY KNEES (Collaborative Artists Ensemble), and 'CARRIE' THAT TUNE: HIT SONGS FROM FLOP MUSICALS, which he also conceived and wrote. Trace worked on the Off-Broadway and Broadway productions of ROLLIN’ ON THE TOBA, and later stage managed and co-directed the Los Angeles production. He received a United Nations medal for distinguished service for his U.S. Depart­ment of Defense touring production, HOLLYWOOD HOMICIDE WHODUNNIT, which performed at military bases throughout Europe. Recent regional credits include HEDDA GABLER and ANNA CHRISTIE for Northern New England Repertory Theatre Company and RADIUM GIRLS, as artist-in-residence for Stage III Theater in Casper, WY. Other directing credits include A CHRISTMAS CAROL (where he had the distinction of giving fu­ture teen heartthrob Zac Efron his first professional acting job), BUTTERFLIES ARE FREE, and SISTER MARY IGNATIUS, and more than 15 world premieres at Denver’s historic Changing Scene Theatre. He also served as artistic director for Den­ver’s famed Chicken Lips Comedy Theatre, where he also co-starred in Murder Most Fowl, the longest running show in Denver theatre history.

Set Designer/Technical Director

Rebekah is thrilled to be back for her second show with Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company. She is more them humbled by the expectancies she has gained and is happy to be apart of a loving theater company. 

 

Choreographer 

Averi Yorek is a choreographer/actress/singer originally from Texas. She has been a part of Proof Doubt Closer from the start working as the company's resident choreographer. she choreographed the company's first show Ruddigore, choreographed and sang in Carrie That Tune, and is currently choreographing On The Twentieth Century. Outside of Proof Doubt Closer, Averi is also the assistant choreographer for the LA Sparkids and Ginuwine. She has also danced for the BCS Championship Bowl halftime show, Koda Corvette, BGlo, Varsity Dance Company, Jstylzfam, Vlado Footwear, John Joseph, Baby Bash, and Royal Carribean. 

Costume Designer

Rachel Harmon is thrilled to be making her design debut with the Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company. She recently completed her MFA in Costume Design at the University of South Carolina. Recent Design Credits at Theatre South Carolina include Scapin, Blithe Spirit, and Translations. She would like to thank you for all of your support!

Supporting Actor/Social Media/Campaign Support

Chelsea recently played the lead in a 15-minute musical for the 2017 Hollywood Fringe Festival as part of NMI's "1001 Minutes of New Musicals." She also performed in PDC'S musical revue "Carrie That Tune: Hit Songs From Flop Musicals" as Carrie, and she costars in the improvised web show "Gurlz Who Hike." Chelsea has a BA in English Lit from UCLA, as well as some hard-won theatre credits from Chaffey Community College. She studies sketch comedy at UCB and The Groundlings and performs with her indie improv teams Soulmate, Hyenas, and Bean, as well as her sketch team Small Dinosaurs (rawr). She also co-wrote a pilot. It's real good.

Pianist/Assistent Music Director

Cynthia Heath is so excited to be doing her third successful production with the Proof Doubt Closer Theater company. Her passion has been Musical Theater since High School when her amazing High School drama teacher gave her the opportunity to Music Direct "The Fantastiks." She did many many productions in the Bay Area but is enjoying the amazing talent pool in La La Land.

Supporting Actor/Arranger

After a thirteen year absence from the stage inadvertently pursuing other ventures within the theatre world, Philip is beyond thrilled to be back on stage! A recent transplant from NYC, Philip is excited to see what LA has in store. Favorite credits include CARRIE That Tune - Hit Songs From Flop Musicals, Rex and Bob’s Excellent Misadventure (World Premiere), Beguiled Again, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street, big the musical and Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat. For Dad and Aunt Phyllis – who have the best seats in the house.

Graphic Designer

Sarah makes things with computers and sometimes in real life, and also performs the hottest Broadway hits daily in traffic to a packed house.

Supporting Actor/Social Media/Campaign Support

Tat is a singer/songwriter and actress. Her favorite past roles include- Googie Gomez in The Ritz, Lydia in Eastside Heartbeats, and Likipulani in the orignal cast of Aloha! The Musical. She is currently writing a musical and working on her debut album.  Beraudmusic.com. She is excited to be making her debut with proof doubt closer theatre company in this show.

Supporting Actor/Campaign Support

Talya Sindel (Porter) is so excited to be part of this production!  She got her degree in Astrophysics from UC Berkeley, but suspects that her true passions lie with the theatrical arts!  Recently she has been acting at the Will Geer Theatricum Botanicum and the Zoo Theatre Company.

Supporting Actor

Rafael Orduna, playing Oliver Webb. 1st show with the company. Originally from Laredo,TX. 

Liking us on Facebook, Follow us on Twitter, share us, retweet us, drop off fliers/promotional postcards to area hotspots, tell your friends, tell your enemies, and if you've ever wanted to work in the thrilling world of theatre, let us know! We would love to have you...we're a passionate and driven, but remarkably fun bunch!

We are so grateful that you have spent some time with us on this page, and we hope you can help us out in making this beautiful show come to life.
story_txt:
Our production is slated for a four-week run, beginning Aug. 4, 2017, at the Pan Andreas Theater, in Hollywood, CA. The show is produced by Proof Doubt Closer co-founder, Trace Oakley (who will also direct) and Alena Bernardi (who will musical direct and play the glamorous Lily Garland).ON THE TWENTIETH CENTURY will be the third production of the Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company, following its critically acclaimed re-imagining of Gilbert and Sullivan's RUDDIGORE, and the musical revue, CARRIE THAT TUNE: HIT SONGS FROM FLOP MUSICALS. Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company is dedicated to revisiting plays and musicals that fell through the cracks: long-neglected hits, should-a-been successes, ahead-of-their-time flops, and other works that deserve a dusting-off, a hand-up and a new lease on life. We are also dedicated to developing new works, and adaptations. Our name is, in fact, and ironic twist on our mission, as we seek and embrace the rarely-performed buried treasures, and leave the PROOF, DOUBT and CLOSERs of the world to others.Being just a shade more than a year old, the Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company has progressed well beyond our expectations, in terms of our audience reception, name recognition, but mostly in terms of the performers and other artists who have carried over from one show to the next. We know we are headed in the right direction when outstanding artists want to continue working with us, and also join our production team.We hope you can see, via this page, and through our videos and postings during this campaign, that we are truly passionate about this very special project, and about theatre itself. It is, after all, much more than just a ticket, a good seat or an excuse to dress up. It’s the live reactions, the actors and audience breathing the same air, the thrill, energy and even danger that only a live performance can bring.Part of our job, once we hit the stage, is to make it all look seamless and easy. Let us tell you, easy is hard work. And, even with many participants volunteering their artistic abilities, producing a musical is also rather expensive. Here's a look at the major items on the tab.

 
_____________________________________________________________________ _____________________________________________________________________Lead Actor/Musical Director/Producer/Campaign ManagerEver since she was 4 years old Alena had a passion for putting on plays and productions. Any chance she would get to order her little brother or cousins or friends at her daycare around and "Make a Play" as she would say; she would. This fascination with using groups of humans to portray a story continued through middle school (where she discovered her love of singing), high school (where she started producing her own shows), college where she studied Classical Voice and participated in school operas, and on to Los Angeles where she Co-Founded Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company. Alena has starred in all three of Proof Doubt's debut productions. First in her title role as the wide eyed Rose Maybud  in Gilbert and Sullivan's "RuddiGORE," then the sassy Legs in their musical review titled '"Carrie" That tune! Hit Songs From Flop Musicals," and finally now she takes on the most challenging role she has taken on to date; the glamorous Lily Garland in "ON THE TWENTIETH CENTURY." As Alena always says: GO TEAM!Director/Producer/Campaign Manager TRACE OAKLEY has directed more than 50 productions, and has more than 100 additional productions to his credit as either actor, playwright, producer, or administrator, working in his home town of Denver, on both coasts, and on national and international tours. Los Angeles directing credits include PEARLY GATES (El Portal Theatre), CRIMES OF THE HEART (Windward JG), LOVERS AND OTHER STRANGERS (Avery Schreiber Playhouse), BOB CRATCHIT AND MR. TIGHTWAD (Secret Rose Theater), RUDDIGORE (Studio/Stage), STANDING ON MY KNEES (Collaborative Artists Ensemble), and 'CARRIE' THAT TUNE: HIT SONGS FROM FLOP MUSICALS, which he also conceived and wrote. Trace worked on the Off-Broadway and Broadway productions of ROLLIN’ ON THE TOBA, and later stage managed and co-directed the Los Angeles production. He received a United Nations medal for distinguished service for his U.S. Depart­ment of Defense touring production, HOLLYWOOD HOMICIDE WHODUNNIT, which performed at military bases throughout Europe. Recent regional credits include HEDDA GABLER and ANNA CHRISTIE for Northern New England Repertory Theatre Company and RADIUM GIRLS, as artist-in-residence for Stage III Theater in Casper, WY. Other directing credits include A CHRISTMAS CAROL (where he had the distinction of giving fu­ture teen heartthrob Zac Efron his first professional acting job), BUTTERFLIES ARE FREE, and SISTER MARY IGNATIUS, and more than 15 world premieres at Denver’s historic Changing Scene Theatre. He also served as artistic director for Den­ver’s famed Chicken Lips Comedy Theatre, where he also co-starred in Murder Most Fowl, the longest running show in Denver theatre history.Set Designer/Technical DirectorRebekah is thrilled to be back for her second show with Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company. She is more them humbled by the expectancies she has gained and is happy to be apart of a loving theater company.  Choreographer Averi Yorek is a choreographer/actress/singer originally from Texas. She has been a part of Proof Doubt Closer from the start working as the company's resident choreographer. she choreographed the company's first show Ruddigore, choreographed and sang in Carrie That Tune, and is currently choreographing On The Twentieth Century. Outside of Proof Doubt Closer, Averi is also the assistant choreographer for the LA Sparkids and Ginuwine. She has also danced for the BCS Championship Bowl halftime show, Koda Corvette, BGlo, Varsity Dance Company, Jstylzfam, Vlado Footwear, John Joseph, Baby Bash, and Royal Carribean. Costume DesignerRachel Harmon is thrilled to be making her design debut with the Proof Doubt Closer Theatre Company. She recently completed her MFA in Costume Design at the University of South Carolina. Recent Design Credits at Theatre South Carolina include Scapin, Blithe Spirit, and Translations. She would like to thank you for all of your support!Supporting Actor/Social Media/Campaign SupportChelsea recently played the lead in a 15-minute musical for the 2017 Hollywood Fringe Festival as part of NMI's "1001 Minutes of New Musicals." She also performed in PDC'S musical revue "Carrie That Tune: Hit Songs From Flop Musicals" as Carrie, and she costars in the improvised web show "Gurlz Who Hike." Chelsea has a BA in English Lit from UCLA, as well as some hard-won theatre credits from Chaffey Community College. She studies sketch comedy at UCB and The Groundlings and performs with her indie improv teams Soulmate, Hyenas, and Bean, as well as her sketch team Small Dinosaurs (rawr). She also co-wrote a pilot. It's real good.Pianist/Assistent Music DirectorCynthia Heath is so excited to be doing her third successful production with the Proof Doubt Closer Theater company. Her passion has been Musical Theater since High School when her amazing High School drama teacher gave her the opportunity to Music Direct "The Fantastiks." She did many many productions in the Bay Area but is enjoying the amazing talent pool in La La Land.Supporting Actor/ArrangerAfter a thirteen year absence from the stage inadvertently pursuing other ventures within the theatre world, Philip is beyond thrilled to be back on stage! A recent transplant from NYC, Philip is excited to see what LA has in store. Favorite credits include CARRIE That Tune - Hit Songs From Flop Musicals, Rex and Bob’s Excellent Misadventure (World Premiere), Beguiled Again, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street, big the musical and Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat. For Dad and Aunt Phyllis – who have the best seats in the house.Graphic DesignerSarah makes things with computers and sometimes in real life, and also performs the hottest Broadway hits daily in traffic to a packed house.Supporting Actor/Social Media/Campaign SupportTat is a singer/songwriter and actress. Her favorite past roles include- Googie Gomez in The Ritz, Lydia in Eastside Heartbeats, and Likipulani in the orignal cast of Aloha! The Musical. She is currently writing a musical and working on her debut album.  Beraudmusic.com. She is excited to be making her debut with proof doubt closer theatre company in this show.Supporting Actor/Campaign SupportTalya Sindel (Porter) is so excited to be part of this production!  She got her degree in Astrophysics from UC Berkeley, but suspects that her true passions lie with the theatrical arts!  Recently she has been acting at the Will Geer Theatricum Botanicum and the Zoo Theatre Company.Supporting ActorRafael Orduna, playing Oliver Webb. 1st show with the company. Originally from Laredo,TX. Liking us on Facebook, Follow us on Twitter, share us, retweet us, drop off fliers/promotional postcards to area hotspots, tell your friends, tell your enemies, and if you've ever wanted to work in the thrilling world of theatre, let us know! We would love to have you...we're a passionate and driven, but remarkably fun bunch!We are so grateful that you have spent some time with us on this page, and we hope you can help us out in making this beautiful show come to life.

story:
ABOUT PILVAX PLAYERS THEATER COMPANY AND THE JUNGLE BOOK

In our fifth year of producing as Pilvax Players Theater Company, we present a fresh look of our "Jungle" world through this Hungarian musical which is our first intercontinental production. Also this is our first show where our young actors, the new Hungarian American generation will be presenting their talents.

 Our Hungarian American theater company is located in New York but our cast and creative team is an international group. Some of our actors came from Hungary, studied acting in Europe. Others were born here just like our little Maugli (Márk Tárkány) or trained as an American actor, singer or dancer. All of them are really gifted and work really hard.

Artists at Pilvax Players envision a New York, New Jersey community where Hungarian Americans are recognized as both theater-makers and theater-goers. Our productions represent a new generation of voices in American theater that transcend the label of "Hungarian American" or "minority."  We believe to keep the Hungarian heritage alive is extremely important in the USA. We are happy to produce and create this international theater performance which is based on a classic story, The Jungle Book by Rudyard Kipling. However our show is totally contemporary.

ABOUT OUR HUNGARIAN JUNGLE BOOK

The Jungle Book from 1894 is a collection of stories which are fables, using animals in an anthropomorphic manner to give moral lessons. Because of its moral tone, it came to be used as a motivational book in many countries. In Hungary in 1996 the amazing The Jungle Book was brought to life. Since then it has been continuing to entrance audiences not only in Hungary but also in cities of Central and Northern Europe but not in the USA.

László Dés, the composer and jazz saxophonist, owns a precise sense of proportioning the elements of jazz with songs for the wider audience. His professional jazz talent was implemented in pop music creating a higher standard of the genre. Des’ extraordinary work has been acknowledged by numerous Hungarian and international awards.  

Péter Geszti is the co-author of this musical. He is one of the most well-known and acknowledged character of the Hungarian media and cultural scene.

Pál Békés (libretto) is a Hungarian writer, playwright, translator. He has a predilection for an experimental voice, his works are characterized by the grotesque and the ironic.

This adaptation of The Jungle Book may take place anywhere, in any jungle, even in a great city’s jungle. You can see the intrinsic qualities of the characters and the features we, humans attributed to them. This is why Shere Khan’s sings a demagogue blood-demanding rock song, the funeral entrepreneur vulture’s song cherishing their service reminds us of the show business, the dangerously coiling python, Kaa’s music is more Oriental and so on. The musical world of The Hungarian Jungle Book is undoubtedly colorful and diversified.

There is humor and irony in music as such as in our show itself. The music reflects the features of the characters.

Our very gifted musical director, Laura Angyal creates an extraordinary musical adaptation with a world premiere live jazz band on stage. 

Our director, Timea Zsedely has a very contemporary message with this new version of The Jungle Book which is very humanistic and artistic.

Our costume and set designers (Agota Hodi & Agnese Endresz) create an extraordinary visual imagination with a totally new interpretation.

WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT!

There are 5 important reasons to support this show.

1. YOU WILL HELP OUR US PREMIERE!

From 1996 more than 1000 performances were in Hungary and Europe but not in the United States. The show still continues to attract young and old, children and adults, families and singles. It’s time to show our absolutely new version of this play in New York and New Jersey than hopefully in more states.

2. YOU WILL HELP OUR HUNGARIAN LANGUAGE TO SURVIVE!

Hungarian language is not easy but very poetic and unique. We should protect and save our language and cultural values through this highly qualified production. We will keep the original Hungarian language on stage but there will be English subtitles. That moment when our US-born and not-US-born actors (children and adults) will create a great show together in the USA by using contemporary Hungarian language in an artistic way and perfectly, that must be a mesmerizing and revolving event even in our globalized world.

3. YOU WILL HELP OUR YOUNG GIFTED ARTISTS!

We are very proud to find and support our really talented young artists on stage.

We need your financial help to make the show and presents these young artists on stage.

4. YOU WILL HELP THE HUNGARIAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY TO BE MORE CREATIVE!

Your support for The Jungle Book will help promote more diversity and inclusion of Hungarian American artists and stories in the local theater landscape. With our latest show, we continue to further contribute to the New York and New Jersey community as we strive to create entertaining and challenging work that is accessible to anyone and everyone.

5. YOU WILL HELP TO SAVE WILDLIFE!

Our show is not only an artistic mission. There is a very deep moral issue in our adaptation of The Jungle Book. Theater is always about our surrounding world and often seriously critical. We believe in this moral issue of the theater and art works. With your help we will support and make donation to help ensure a future for the earth's most magnificent creatures and the habitats critical to their survival.

We will donate from our profit of The Jungle Book to help the main Rainforest Foundation and the Defenders of Wildlife.

MAKING GOOD THEATER IS EXPENSIVE

A creative process as working on custom and set design, the rehearsals, marketing and reaching our audience, having great technicians and an amazing rental space then finally making a great show on stage, it costs a lot.  

The typical budget for an Off-Broadway play can range from $50,000-$250,000. Thanks to the commitments from an extremely talented team who are all willing to work for less than their usual rates, we have been able to trim that down a bit.  But we still need to raise a total of $30,000 for this production.  We started to work (casting, rehearsals, design, marketing) and organize our show in order to get our goal but we need your help to rent the space and create the production on stage.

We would like to give a memorable, joyful and valued piece of art to our audience. We believe that money should be like a great energy. It can produce great art. You can help us to hit the target. It means so much for us.

Your help certainly will create wonderful international theater events in New York and in New Jersey.

Be a creative partner of our campaign! Please share this video with your friends. Your donations are very important for us and don’t forget it is tax-deductible. It helps to Pilvax Players continue to grow and develop and create a great show.

You can support us by credit card, by check or money order (10 Thousand Steps Inc., 516 E 11th Street, New York, New York 10009) and personally (Phone 646 484 5525 or Email: pilvaxplayers@gmail.com)! Follow us on our web site: www.pilvaxproductions.com or on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/PilvaxPlayers !

By the way… our perks are really exciting. Check them out!

With your generous tax-deductible donation, you will not only be supporting an exciting new piece of theatre and our mission of showcasing the talents of international theatre artists, you will also qualify for some exciting perks like Hungarian Folk tales audio CD in Hungarian, an elegant dinner in Manhattan with János Kulka, a multi-awarding Hungarian actor or even an invitation to the premiere cast party. Moreover you can have your own song or painting about yourself which you can order from our gifted artists (Laura Angyal, composer and Udita Leberg, fine artist).

No donation payments are processed until the end of the campaign.

Thank you for your support!

Köszönjük szépen!

story:
Short Summary

VERVE is a 90 minute musical about the power of friendship and the importance of accepting ourselves as we are.  It's a fun-filled journey mixed with  serious moments, all magically uplifted by Karena Mendoza's richly textured, very tuneful music. VERVE will have its first-ever workshop production at the Edge Off Broadway Theatre  in February as part of the 6th annual Chicago Musical Theatre Festival produced by Underscore Theatre.  It is an honor that VERVE was chosen to be part of the festival and an honor that this program is partially supported  by a  grant from the Illinois Arts Council Agency.  As the producer of VERVE as well as bookwriter and lyricist, it is my responsibility to raise funds to match the Arts Council Grant and meet other expenses.

VERVE had several staged readings early in its development, produced by the former Midwest New Musicals Workshop and the Chicago Writers' Bloc, a collective of established and emerging playwrights.  Audience feedback from these performances helped us develop the show further.

Composer Karena Mendoza died five years ago at age 52, always believing in this show and its potential to reach a wide, enthusiastic audience.  I promised Karena before she died that VERVE would one day have a full production.  That day is now and with your support, we can meet our expenses and make VERVE the best production possible. I hope you will be able to contribute to this effort.

 

What We Need & What

  • The total cost of this low budget, black-box production will be about $8300. That includes payment to actors, stage director, music director, choreographer and stage manager.  It includes theatre space rental, rehearsal space rental, props, costumes, publicity materials and design, online advertising, audio, and video expenses, and miscellaneous extras.
  • $4000 will be covered by the Illinois Arts Council Agency grant. We project ticket sales to net between $1000 to $2000.  We need to raise up to $3000 to cover the difference.
  • Perks for your generosity include:  Thank you in on social media and in  the VERVE program;  11 x 17 digital VERVE poster, a drink at Burke's Public House, appetizer at Pasteur Restaurant; tickets to VERVE;  VERVE T-shirt, 'psychedelic' brownie recipe and more. See  the Perks section for specifics.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us get the word out by sharing our campaign link and telling your friends and social media network about VERVE and the Chicago Musical Theatre Festival. 
  • Come and see the show! Performance are 8 pm on Feb 5; 3 pm on Feb 8; 8 pm on Feb 11; 7 pm  and 10 pm on Feb 14; 3 pm on Feb 16; and 8 pm on Feb 20.
