story:
About Our Campaign

Same Boat Theater Collective was formed by seven San Francisco Bay Area playwrights and theater artists seeking to unite our passions for theater and for the environment. We're raising funds to help us launch our first projects, including a collaboratively-written full-length play that we hope to present this August. Every dollar you donate will go directly toward the creation of brand new work for the stage with an environmental focus.

Our mission is to bring innovative, meaningful theatrical experiences about environmental issues to as diverse a local audience as possible, with the goal of generating a critical mass of individuals to act against environmental degradation. We aim to change the current narrative by telling stories about our bioregion, the Bay Area, for all species who live here.

Environmental threats like climate change can feel both overwhelming and abstract, which makes them hard to fight. We want to change that. With your help, we want to move audiences from passive observers to active environmentalists, and to bring to life the impacts of environmental degradation in a way that is theatrical, engaging, inclusive and immediately actionable.

You can learn more about us at http://www.sameboattheater.org. SBTC is grateful to be fiscally sponsored by PlayGround, a 501(3)(c) not-for-profit theater, as part of the Innovator Incubator Program.

Our Projects

We have a lot in the works for 2019-20! Your donations will help us get the following projects on their feet:

  • The Emeryville Horror, a full-length play about the effects of climate change and environmental degradation on underprivileged populations in the Bay Area. The play, currently being collaboratively written by SBTC playwrights in consultation with diverse local  communities, concerns the mysterious disappearance of the city of Emeryville, piece by piece. We hope to hold a staged reading in June 2019 with a production later in the year.
  • Site-specific performances, which will allow audiences to connect sensually and emotionally with the natural world in conjunction with exploring stories about that world.
  • EarthQuake, a celebration of new writing about the environment by artists throughout the Bay Area as we seek to raise awareness of environmental issues before the 2020 elections.

Why We Need You

Your donation will help us pay actors, designers, and other collaborators, rent performance and rehearsal spaces, and pay for our website and marketing efforts. In return, we're offering some fun and unique donor rewards, including tickets to our shows, Farm Fresh To You organic local produce, donations to American Rivers, The World Wildlife Fund, and Friends of the Urban Forest, coffee with scientists and and dinners with our playwrights. Every dollar counts, and we're grateful for your support at any level.

Risks & Challenges

There's always risk involved in bringing new theatre to life, but we're confident that with your support, SBTC will establish itself as an important part of the Bay Area theatre community. The members of our collective are ready to bring their extensive artistic, production, and management experience to meet the challenges ahead.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially at this time, please consider helping get the word out about SBTC and our campaign by sharing our Indiegogo page on social media, through email, or by word of mouth. Thank you!!!
story_txt:
About Our Campaign
Same Boat Theater Collective was formed by seven San Francisco Bay Area playwrights and theater artists seeking to unite our passions for theater and for the environment. We're raising funds to help us launch our first projects, including a collaboratively-written full-length play that we hope to present this August. Every dollar you donate will go directly toward the creation of brand new work for the stage with an environmental focus.
Our mission is to bring innovative, meaningful theatrical experiences about environmental issues to as diverse a local audience as possible, with the goal of generating a critical mass of individuals to act against environmental degradation. We aim to change the current narrative by telling stories about our bioregion, the Bay Area, for all species who live here.
Environmental threats like climate change can feel both overwhelming and abstract, which makes them hard to fight. We want to change that. With your help, we want to move audiences from passive observers to active environmentalists, and to bring to life the impacts of environmental degradation in a way that is theatrical, engaging, inclusive and immediately actionable.
You can learn more about us at http://www.sameboattheater.org. SBTC is grateful to be fiscally sponsored by PlayGround, a 501(3)(c) not-for-profit theater, as part of the Innovator Incubator Program.

Our Projects
We have a lot in the works for 2019-20! Your donations will help us get the following projects on their feet:


The Emeryville Horror, a full-length play about the effects of climate change and environmental degradation on underprivileged populations in the Bay Area. The play, currently being collaboratively written by SBTC playwrights in consultation with diverse local  communities, concerns the mysterious disappearance of the city of Emeryville, piece by piece. We hope to hold a staged reading in June 2019 with a production later in the year.

Site-specific performances, which will allow audiences to connect sensually and emotionally with the natural world in conjunction with exploring stories about that world.

EarthQuake, a celebration of new writing about the environment by artists throughout the Bay Area as we seek to raise awareness of environmental issues before the 2020 elections.


Why We Need You
Your donation will help us pay actors, designers, and other collaborators, rent performance and rehearsal spaces, and pay for our website and marketing efforts. In return, we're offering some fun and unique donor rewards, including tickets to our shows, Farm Fresh To You organic local produce, donations to American Rivers, The World Wildlife Fund, and Friends of the Urban Forest, coffee with scientists and and dinners with our playwrights. Every dollar counts, and we're grateful for your support at any level.

Risks & Challenges
There's always risk involved in bringing new theatre to life, but we're confident that with your support, SBTC will establish itself as an important part of the Bay Area theatre community. The members of our collective are ready to bring their extensive artistic, production, and management experience to meet the challenges ahead.

story:
Bring "Paani" to Life

"Paani" is a devised theatre piece about anti-muslim racism in North America.

  • Theatre can do so much, but much to our dismay, it is not free! Blowfish is run by students who are looking to bring new and exciting things to the Montreal stage, but we need your help to make it happen!
  • By funding us, you will be helping to defray the cost of costumes, props, sets, advertising, and more!

Our Story

Following the success of their first production, Matt & Ben, Blowfish Theatre Company presents "Paani". "Paani" is a devised theatre piece that chronicles experiences in, of, and around anti-Muslim racism in North America. It is a story that, in our current social and political climate, has to be presented and responded to. Catch the show’s premiere at the St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival 2017, opening on June 8th at Venue 11- Studio Multimedia du Conservatoire.

"Paani" is directed by Anurag Choudhury, who last directed Matt & Ben (Blowfish Theatre Company, September 2016). It is produced by Nikita Bala and Rana Liu, who co-founded Blowfish Theatre Company in the summer of 2016.

The play, being a devised piece, has been a collaboration between the entire production and performance team. An amalgamation of live music, dance, spoken word, mask, and storytelling - performed by members of Blowfish. We would be nothing without our company.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes, it's just not possible to give money! That's ok! Like the Blowfish Theatre Co. Facebook page, share our campaign, share our events with your networks, and come see the show!

  • Paani will be going up at Venue 11 (4750 av. Henri Julien, Montreal): 
    • 08 June, 18:00
    • 11 June, 13:15
    • 12 June, 19:00
    • 14 June, 18:00
    • 17 June, 13:00
    • 18 June, 21:15
  • Check out the Montreal Fringe page for information about the festival and other shows going on!

story:
What is justified when survival is on the line?

Winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Drama, Ruined tells the incredibly powerful story of a small group of women in the Democratic Republic of Congo. We follow the bustling life of Mama Nadi in her bar/brothel in a small mining town, experiencing the turmoil of war-torn DRC through the distinctive and gripping voices of the three women who work for her. Josephine - the daughter of a tribal chief who was taken by soldiers. Salima - who after being captured by rebels, spent five months in the bush as their concubine. And Sophie - "ruined" by sexual violence. We brush shoulders with Mama Nadi's customers and come to understand the war from many different perspectives.

Lynn Nottage is one of America's most important and compelling playwrights. Ruined, was born from a series of interviews she held with girls and women who experienced (and continue to experience) the traumas of war firsthand. It is a story of love, loss, self-sacrifice, and most importantly, hope.

By putting a human face on those caught in the struggle, we hope to raise awareness about what is happening in the Congo, and increase understanding and compassion for victims of sexual violence wherever they are.

Dark Glass Theatre exists to tell stories of people we might not otherwise meet, thereby decreasing judgement, increasing compassion, and fostering empathy. We believe one of the most damaging forces in our world is the demonizing of "the other". By coming face to face with another’s perspective, without judgement, we are able to break down barriers that separate us and celebrate our common humanity. As we see past labels and cultural differences, we are empowered to act in love. And that action can change the world.

Artistic Director, Angela Konrad is an award-winning director and educator who believes in the power of theatre as a force for good. Associate producer Jessica Garden is a freelance director and social justice advocate with a desire to make a difference through meaningful stories. They are grateful to Lynn Nottage for the gift of this remarkable play.

RUINED has a large cast and therefore a large budget. With a dozen people on stage, it's easy to see why we need your help making this happen! Our Indiegogo campaign is a vital part of our fundraising, a way for you to join us in bringing this important story to the stage. Your dollars go to actors' salaries, to costumes, to set, to props, to publicity. Check out the pie chart for more info. The bottom line is that our bottom line needs you!

We have assembled some fantastic perks to thank you for your donations. From jewelry and prints, to renderings and back stage passes, we want you to know how important you are to us. Choose the donation level and reward that fits you best. And then consider yourself a citizen of Dark Glass City.

If you throw the word "Congo" into Google, you will get news stories with today's date. News stories with titles like, "Rape in the DR Congo: An economic war on women's bodies" or "Visit with displaced women, children, touches Haley."

You will read how women in the Congo are working to dispel their country's image as the rape capital of the world and instead establish a new reputation as the "world capital of sisterhood and solidarity." You will also read how those working for change within the country risk their lives every day, and how many lose that battle. 

But despite the ongoing brutality of the conflict and the startling immediacy of the headlines, most in North America know very little about what is happening in this beautiful, ravaged country. Most have no sense of the extent of the conflict, the millions who have been killed, millions more displaced, the appalling poverty and starvation in such a wealthy country, the instability and of the illegitimate government, or the cost of this war on women. 

We want to do what we can to change that.

RUINED brings us face to face with those caught in conflict. It enables us to see their humanity and understand their pain. And it motivates action.

After each performance of RUINED, we will hold talkbacks with the cast, alongside special guest hosts who know something of the issues in the play -- the Congo, sexual exploitation, war, humanitarian aid... We will give voice to women who are oppressed and abused, in the Congo and here at home. And we will work together to be part of the solution.

This is an audacious project for a young company. It's a huge cast and a huge budget. Its set and costumes must evoke an actual world and a metaphorical reality. It has live music and real guns. But we have stepped forward in faith believing that this story must be told, believing in the incredible artists who have assembled to tell it, believing in the support and generosity of those around us. Prove us right.

We understand that not everyone is able to donate towards the campaign, however there are still many ways you can help! 

#1: Come and see our show! It runs January 25 - February 17, 2018. We'd love to see your friendly faces there. Tickets

#2: Share our campaign with your friends and family, telling them why you think it is worthwhile. 

#3: Familiarize yourself with the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, particularly the horrific toll the conflict is taking on women in that country. Find out what you can do to break the silence and stop the violence.

story:
Storyboard Theatre

Storyboard Theatre consists of graduates from Edinburgh Napier University's Acting & English and Napier and Queen Margaret University's Acting For Stage & Screen course.

Project and Aim

'The Shakespeares: Scenes From A Marriage' was the company's debut show at the 2017 Edinburgh Fringe, and we are taking our show to London to The Rose Playhouse, Bankside for a run between the 26-28th of October.

We're hoping to raise £975, which would go towards paying for the transportation and accomodation for 6 actors to London.

Over this trip, we're looking to help grow our company and bring our show to those outside of Scotland, and to showcase ourselves and our company with the hope of taking the show elsewhere if our London run is successful.

Going forward

Even if we don't meet our full goal, and funds raised would be extremely appreciated in even partially funding the trip. If we manage to surpass our goal, any money over and above the £975 for travel and accomodation for our London venture would go towards funding future productions.

story:
A kaleidoscope of mundanity and the surreal, 'Birthday in Suburbia' invites its audience to follow the descent of an average man into an extraordinary, ridiculous personal crisis. Inspired by the film, 'It's a Wonderful Life', Birthday in Suburbia combines a rich mixture of clown and dark comedy. The show combines spoken English with expressive and gestural body language, including elements of international sign language.

We are the Upstairs Brigade, an international theatre collective passionate about using physical theatre to tell stories that surprise and resonate long after the curtain call. We have the fantastic opportunity to take our devised show Birthday in Suburbia, first performed  in 2015, to one of the main Brighton Fringe Festival venues. At times side-splittingly comic, at times deeply tragic, this story reminds us that we all have a place in the world... we all belong. It is a story we care deeply about telling in a world obsessed with consumerism and celebrity perfection, and your support will guarantee that we can continue to tell it.

The members of our Brigade are Ami, Catherine, Joe and Jan, and our associate director Ally from England, Anja from Germany, Camilla from Italy, Nathalie from Sweden, Dawn from Finland and Canada, and Pawel from Poland. We met on an MA in Physical Theatre and combine disciplines including clown, storytelling, dance and puppetry.


What We Need & What You Get

  • Raising £250 will ensure we can transport our set to Brighton
  • Raising another £650 will guarantee us our place at the Brighton Fringe Festival by covering the registration fee.
  • Finally another £800 will allow us to rehearse in a space large enough for 9 actors and a big set and make our show the best it can be for our Brighton audience.

Whether you donate £5 or £100, your generosity will be invaluable to us! As a token of our appreciation, we have some lovely, festive rewards for you, that range from a personal video message from the cast, to being serenaded by us over dinner!

No contribution is too small: If we don’t make our full goal, all of the funds still go to the development of ‘Birthday in Suburbia' and our goal of going to the Brighton Fringe Festival. Anything we raise on top of our goal, will go towards making sure the show continues to live on, spreading its uplifting message. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a donation you can still contribute to the cause by spreading the word! Use the Indiegogo share tools or share our campaign on your Facebook and Twitter in order to encourage friends and family to support us. Please also join our Facebook page so we can keep you up to date with the latest information and visit our website:
https://www.facebook.com/BirthdayInSuburbia.
www.theupstairsbrigade.co.uk

And finally, come and see us perform so we can see your lovely faces in the audience and entertain you the way we know best! Details below.

VENUE The Warren: Main House, Brighton Fringe Festival

DATES 13th / 14th / 15th May (that's Fri/Sat/Sun)

TIME 8pm

Tickets: https://www.otherplacebrighton.co.uk/1997/birthday-in-suburbia

story:
What is the Alumni Company?

Each summer, the Shakespeare Academy @ Stratford invites former students to return to Stratford to create and perform a four-actor mobile production of a play by Shakespeare.

With support from Community and Educational Outreach Director, Tia James and the entire SA@S faculty and staff, the Alumni Company is tasked with creating, directing, performing and producing a play of Shakespeare. Putting the skills they gained during their time as students at SA@S into practice and gaining real-world experience in all aspects of theater making.

  • devising and staging a play by Shakespeare
  • collaborating as an ensemble
  • fundraising
  • producing
  • publicity
  • adapting Shakespeare's text 
  • planning and managing a tour
  • set, costume and sound design

Last year's Alumni Company has passed the baton onto a quartet of intrepid theatremakers: Kaitlyn Fowler, Bridget Wagar, Steven Miles, and Chandler Vance.  To support their residence in Stratford and the tour this summer, we hope to raise $2500. That breaks down to $700 for travel expenses, $500 for production costs, $800 for actor pay, and $500 to cover living expenses while in Stratford.

 

The Impact

Last summer, four actors (Mia DeLasho, Olivia Gregorich, Jacob Nurick, and Rebeka Rosales) took to the road with a trunk, a boombox, and their production of A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM. For two weeks, they travelled throughout the Northeast, making stops in Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Connecticut, and New York City. The Alumni Company began and ended their tour at the home of SA@S, the White House.  They performed at summer camps, art galleries, people's homes, and parks. Last year's Alumni Company not only grew as artists and collaborators, but they engaged with communities and local businesses to bring Shakespeare to people of all ages and walks of life. 

 

"One of the most rewarding parts of the experience (and also one of the biggest challenges) is creating a truly self-contained show. You have minimal sets and costume resources, just whatever you can pack into a trunk, the rest of the story really comes from yourselves as actors. You have to build the rest of that world with your bodies and voices, and the best part is when you can see the audience is in that world with you." -Mia DeLasho (Alumni Co. 2016)

 

"For company members, this is a unique opportunity to take ownership of our own theatre-making experience, experiment and explore collaboratively.  Confidence in choice making and cross-over in responsibility for production roles is the main benefit of this freedom--working on multiple aspects of one production expands the appreciation for the way those different threads interweave, and experiences as a director can feed one’s approach to acting and vice versa.  Theatre is a field where being able to generate, publicize, and produce one’s own work is an incredible asset. " -Olivia Gregorich (Alumni Co. 2016)

 

"The most rewarding part of the experience was when audience members stumbled upon the performance, like when we were at Short Beach in Stratford, CT... When kids would just sit completely rapt in the play and what we were doing. They got it. That's a pretty amazing feeling as an actor."- Kelly Letourneau (Alumni Co. 2015)

 

"I think the energy and imagination that comes from switching spaces so often was exciting for the actors as well as the audience—it’s no wonder that so many of the venues were immediately excited to be on the docket for next season’s performances. We got to perform for children groups (wonderfully excitable audiences) and put on free performances for a lot of people that otherwise would not be seeing theater, much less Shakespeare, at all. It was wonderful to have people show up for the shows (a couple even followed us to other venues to see it again) but there was also a certain magic in a person turning a corner from the modern world and chancing upon a classic story they weren’t expecting—something like Bottom into the world of the fairies." -Nate Currier (Alumni Co. 2015)

 

Risks & Challenges

Nate Currier of the 2015 Alumni Company put it best:

"Projects like these necessitate myriad risks and challenges. It is not easy to cut down Shakespeare and put on a show, without a director, four actors and serious budget constraints, with staging versatile enough to be done in any manner of spaces. There is a lot of ego on the line, trying to put forward something you can be proud of. There is the challenge of working with your peers and managing different skill sets and deficiencies. There is the challenge of trying to balance creativity with time management. And of course, there is the main risk that after all this work, simply no one will show up.

 But one amazing thing about theater is that often it is the risks and the challenges that lead to growth, to intrigue and to change. “Risk” is not a dirty word in theater. The truth is, we don’t watch movies and shows to be entertained. We see them to be challenged—our beliefs, our intellect, our convictions, our disbelief—and to overcome those challenges. Audiences see theater to challenge and learn about themselves. And if the actors are not challenged, how could the audience ever be?"

The Mighty Quinn Foundation, Inc. 

SA@S and its Alumni Company are a project of the Mighty Quinn Foundation, a 501(c)(3) charity dedicated to providing educational and theatrical experiences for young artists. A lifelong Stratford resident, Quinn Rooney grew up next door to the theater grounds and always hoped to see them revitalized. He passed away in June 2012 from a rare form of brain cancer at age 19, having led life to the fullest. SA@S holds the example of Quinn's great joy, utmost generosity, indefatigable spirit, and love for the fellowship of sharing theater with friends at the heart of its founding values.

Other Ways You Can Help!

Please help us continue to spread the word, both about the Shakespeare Academy @ Stratford and the Alum Co fundraising effort, by sharing with your friends, family, and the Stratford community. Read more about the Alumni Company on Facebook, Instagram, and our website. Stay tuned for information on this summer's tour!
story_txt:
What is the Alumni Company?
Each summer, the Shakespeare Academy @ Stratford invites former students to return to Stratford to create and perform a four-actor mobile production of a play by Shakespeare.
With support from Community and Educational Outreach Director, Tia James and the entire SA@S faculty and staff, the Alumni Company is tasked with creating, directing, performing and producing a play of Shakespeare. Putting the skills they gained during their time as students at SA@S into practice and gaining real-world experience in all aspects of theater making.

devising and staging a play by Shakespeare
collaborating as an ensemble
fundraising
producing
publicity
adapting Shakespeare's text 
planning and managing a tour
set, costume and sound design

Last year's Alumni Company has passed the baton onto a quartet of intrepid theatremakers: Kaitlyn Fowler, Bridget Wagar, Steven Miles, and Chandler Vance.  To support their residence in Stratford and the tour this summer, we hope to raise $2500. That breaks down to $700 for travel expenses, $500 for production costs, $800 for actor pay, and $500 to cover living expenses while in Stratford.
 
The Impact
Last summer, four actors (Mia DeLasho, Olivia Gregorich, Jacob Nurick, and Rebeka Rosales) took to the road with a trunk, a boombox, and their production of A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM. For two weeks, they travelled throughout the Northeast, making stops in Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Connecticut, and New York City. The Alumni Company began and ended their tour at the home of SA@S, the White House.  They performed at summer camps, art galleries, people's homes, and parks. Last year's Alumni Company not only grew as artists and collaborators, but they engaged with communities and local businesses to bring Shakespeare to people of all ages and walks of life. 
 
"One of the most rewarding parts of the experience (and also one of the biggest challenges) is creating a truly self-contained show. You have minimal sets and costume resources, just whatever you can pack into a trunk, the rest of the story really comes from yourselves as actors. You have to build the rest of that world with your bodies and voices, and the best part is when you can see the audience is in that world with you." -Mia DeLasho (Alumni Co. 2016)
 
"For company members, this is a unique opportunity to take ownership of our own theatre-making experience, experiment and explore collaboratively.  Confidence in choice making and cross-over in responsibility for production roles is the main benefit of this freedom--working on multiple aspects of one production expands the appreciation for the way those different threads interweave, and experiences as a director can feed one’s approach to acting and vice versa.  Theatre is a field where being able to generate, publicize, and produce one’s own work is an incredible asset. " -Olivia Gregorich (Alumni Co. 2016)
 
"The most rewarding part of the experience was when audience members stumbled upon the performance, like when we were at Short Beach in Stratford, CT... When kids would just sit completely rapt in the play and what we were doing. They got it. That's a pretty amazing feeling as an actor."- Kelly Letourneau (Alumni Co. 2015)
 
"I think the energy and imagination that comes from switching spaces so often was exciting for the actors as well as the audience—it’s no wonder that so many of the venues were immediately excited to be on the docket for next season’s performances. We got to perform for children groups (wonderfully excitable audiences) and put on free performances for a lot of people that otherwise would not be seeing theater, much less Shakespeare, at all. It was wonderful to have people show up for the shows (a couple even followed us to other venues to see it again) but there was also a certain magic in a person turning a corner from the modern world and chancing upon a classic story they weren’t expecting—something like Bottom into the world of the fairies." -Nate Currier (Alumni Co. 2015)
 
Risks & Challenges
Nate Currier of the 2015 Alumni Company put it best:
"Projects like these necessitate myriad risks and challenges. It is not easy to cut down Shakespeare and put on a show, without a director, four actors and serious budget constraints, with staging versatile enough to be done in any manner of spaces. There is a lot of ego on the line, trying to put forward something you can be proud of. There is the challenge of working with your peers and managing different skill sets and deficiencies. There is the challenge of trying to balance creativity with time management. And of course, there is the main risk that after all this work, simply no one will show up.
 But one amazing thing about theater is that often it is the risks and the challenges that lead to growth, to intrigue and to change. “Risk” is not a dirty word in theater. The truth is, we don’t watch movies and shows to be entertained. We see them to be challenged—our beliefs, our intellect, our convictions, our disbelief—and to overcome those challenges. Audiences see theater to challenge and learn about themselves. And if the actors are not challenged, how could the audience ever be?"
The Mighty Quinn Foundation, Inc. 
SA@S and its Alumni Company are a project of the Mighty Quinn Foundation, a 501(c)(3) charity dedicated to providing educational and theatrical experiences for young artists. A lifelong Stratford resident, Quinn Rooney grew up next door to the theater grounds and always hoped to see them revitalized. He passed away in June 2012 from a rare form of brain cancer at age 19, having led life to the fullest. SA@S holds the example of Quinn's great joy, utmost generosity, indefatigable spirit, and love for the fellowship of sharing theater with friends at the heart of its founding values.
Other Ways You Can Help!
Please help us continue to spread the word, both about the Shakespeare Academy @ Stratford and the Alum Co fundraising effort, by sharing with your friends, family, and the Stratford community. Read more about the Alumni Company on Facebook, Instagram, and our website. Stay tuned for information on this summer's tour!

story:
We want to produce this strange and beautiful play.

We need your help.

 

WHAT IS MOTH?

MOTH is a 90 minute play written by Australian playwright Declan Greene. 

The play follows Sebastian and Claryssa, two friends brought together by their mutual misfit status. They take a warped journey through their past, re-living their most horrifying memories. But this time, they take control of their story; impersonating their tormentors, parents and many others.

This play isn’t your standard kitchen-sink drama. 

It’s more like a wild fever dream on a playground. 

 

THE TEAM

Ben Lohrberg he/him/his (Director/Co-producer) is thrilled to be directing this imaginative and heartfelt play. As an actor, Ben has been seen at the Guthrie Theater, Ten Thousand Things, Park Square, Titan Theatre Company, Hope Summer Repertory, and Interlochen Shakespeare Festival. His directing work includes a world premiere adaptation of Cinderella at Hope Summer Repertory, his one-man clown play A Winter’s Hope, and assistant directing Sonnets for an Old Century at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Following a sold out run of his solo cabaret, Dream With Me, at Feinstein's/54 Below in NY, Ben released a vocal album of the same title. He is a proud member of Doghouse Ensemble Theatre, a multi-city based company dedicated to creating innovative and accessible works across the globe. Ben is a National YoungArts Winner and received his education from Interlochen Arts Academy, the University of Minnesota / Guthrie Theater BFA Actor Training Program, and Shakespeare’s Globe in London, England. benlohrberg.com

Sophina Saggau she/her/hers (Claryssa/Co-producer) is thrilled to be producing and acting in a play she loves with a group of like-minded artists. Sophina received her theatrical education from Interlochen Arts Academy, The University of Minnesota / Guthrie Theater BFA Actor Training Program, and Shakespeare’s Globe in London. Sophina is currently playing Jack Nimble in Cabal at Walking Shadow Theatre Company (which is currently accepting bookings through January). In the spring she will be playing Doerwynn in Sherwood at Yellow Tree Theatre. She will also be assistant directing The Hatmaker’s Wife at Ten Thousand Things (directed by Michelle O’Neill) in March. Some of her favorite past roles include Juliet in Romeo and Juliet at Arkansas Shakespeare Theatre, X in Sonnets for an Old Century at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and Cass in The Adventures of Tibby and Cass (a play she co-wrote, co-directed, and performed in for her senior project). sophinasaggau.com

Luke Myers he/him/his (Sebastian) is so excited to return to Minneapolis to work on this play with two artists he loves and admires. Luke is a graduate of the University of Minnesota / Guthrie Theater BFA Actor Training Program and PCPA-Pacific Conservatory Theatre's Professional Actor Training Program, and has since been living and working in California's Bay Area. Recent credits include Cabaret Cressida with Poltergeist Theatre Project, The Glass Menagerie with SLO Repertory Theatre, and Arcadia with PCPA Pacific Conservatory Theatre. He has worked with San Francisco Shakespeare Festival, Berkeley Playhouse, and Capital Stage Company, as well as Open Eye Figure Theatre and Full Circle Theater in Minneapolis. Upcoming film credits include This Is Your Song and It's Always Something. Luke is a recent participant of The Arctic Cycle's 2019 Arts & Ecology Incubator, and is eager to make accessible, affordable art centering on climate justice. Suggestions welcome. 

 

OUR GOAL: $3,500

The money you donate to MOTH will go toward paying our artistic team, performance rights, press materials, programs, advertising costs, props, costumes, and a minimal set.

Donate by clicking the "BACK IT" button at the top of this page. From there, you'll have the option to donate an amount of your choosing, or a suggested amount to claim one of the following perks:

 

$25 Donation:

  • Gain exclusive access to our MOTH inspiration playlist of over 30 songs.

 

$50 Donation:

  • Receive a hand-drawn MOTH Thank You Card by Sophina, designer of our MOTH logo.
  • Gain exclusive access to our MOTH inspiration playlist of over 30 songs.

 

$100 Donation: *SAINT STATUS*

  • Receive mention of “Saint Status” in our program.
  • Receive a hand-drawn MOTH Thank You Card by Sophina, designer of our MOTH logo.
  • Gain exclusive access to our MOTH inspiration playlist of over 30 songs.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Buy tickets! Come to our opening night! Bring friends! Share this campaign on your facebook, instagram, twitter, shout it from the rooftops, tell a stranger on the bus about it!

Tickets aren’t available for purchase yet, but when they are you can reserve them through the Bryant-Lake Bowl website (bryantlakebowl.com) or call their ticket and information line: (612) 825-8949.

 

MOTH by Declan Greene

Bryant-Lake Bowl Theater

February 28, 29 & March 1, 2, 6, 7

All performances @ 7:00 pm

 

*MOTH logo image designed by Sophina Saggau*

story:
A Word from Our Director

"Growing up in Newark, NJ as a African American Male definitely comes with a long string of challenges, however thanks to the determination of some of our community leaders there were windows of opportunity to become more than what my environment was teaching. Those opportunities were inside our community centers & arts programs. It took this very creative kid and allowed him to flourish in his craft around a positive and uplifting circle of peers. To become more than a statistic. Isn't that what we all aspire to become?

Two of my favorite creatives are Jacob & Wilhelm Grimm. They told these amazingly interesting stories in the most creative ways, however it always felt a tad un-relatable, outside of the fact that they were fictional. The fact that this little black boy from the city of Newark even knew the names Jacob & Wilhelm Grimm also made me stand out from others in my community. I thought to myself, "What if I was able to blend these two worlds together, helping to bridge the gap and open curiosity between the worlds of The Brothers Grimm Tales & the realities of towns like Newark. That's when I created RED.

RED follows a group of teenagers who, brought together by a web of life altering circumstances, try to stop their neighborhood community center from being closed by the new Mayor. Inspired by Brothers Grimm tales, RED takes us on a journey of friendship, bravery, and just how many colors life can bring us.

Now more than ever I think it's important to share this story with the world, at a time where our communities are most vulnerable and the future of America is dependent on the growth and security of it's youth."

~Lawrence Dandridge

What We Need?

Your Support!

From workshop to production is a huge step and we're looking to get your assistance to do so. Lawrence has already made the big Journey back from LA to NY after producing two highly successful Workshops for RED. Both showcases had sold out audiences and receive raved reviews. Now we're starting the process of putting together this years' production at The New York Theater Festival.

This will be Lawrence's second play submission to the NY Theater Festival. In 2016 Lawrence & his production team produced the musical called "Something Like A Fairytale", in which he was also the Writer & Director. The musical not only sold out it's performances but was also invited back for additional runs based on popular demand. "Something Like a Fairytale" won 6 out of the 7 categories it was Nominated for that year, including Best Director & Best Original Play. So, your donations not only support a well written and highly crafted play but it will also be backed by a Writer & Director with a proven success record.

Our overall goal is to raise $8,000 to produce this Summers production of RED. 

The 1st $1,000 of your donations will allow us to get the following things in order:

  • Obtaining rental spaces for readings & music rehaersals
  • Printing scripts for cast & crew 
  • Festival Registration Fees
  • & a Stage Manager

The Next $6,000 will cover:

  • Rental spaces for full cast rehearsals
  • Crew
  • Cast
  • Wardrobe
  • Props
  • Set Design
  • Insurance

The Last $1,000 will finish the finances needed for

  • Promotion & Marketing
  • Recording Performance
  • & Recording Music 

We've decided to put our first efforts in pushing to raise the first $1,000 here on Indiegogo, so we can build the visual result with our audiences. Making the donation process simple, easy, and quickly rewardable. The $1,000 will secure the basics of what's needed to get started. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes as much as we would like to give, we may not always have the funds to do so; however, to support our cause is not limited to only financial donations. You can always assistance RED by donating, lunch services, costumes, props, locations for rehearsals or even more by simply just Sharing Our Link and Spreading The Word.

Please feel free to email us if you think you may be able to help us in other ways outside of the Indiegogo donation link at redanewmusical@gmail.com. All support is welcomed.

story:
My name is Linda Alznauer and I am a theatre director. I am directing this production of "All My Sons" because it is near and dear to my heart. In 1999 I appeared in this play in New York City and had such a great experience that I jumped at the opportunity to direct it here in Los Angeles. "All My Sons" is a family drama, set after World War II, that touches on so many universal themes of morality and the consequences of the choices we make. This particular play couldn't be more timely with the current political atmosphere in our country (USA) now. The struggle between idealism and practicality is very much alive and well today. This play explores how one family deals with these issues and I feel our audiences will find an easy connection with the characters on stage. In order to tell this story, I need your help in raising the funds for the royalties to produce it.

We need $1,200.00 to pay the royalties for 12 performances; that's $100 per show. We as a company are not getting paid to play these roles. We are artists who take joy in bringing theatre to life. We love what we do, and we do it for nothing but the love of the art. 

Just because we aren't getting anything to perform, doesn't mean you won't get anything for your contribution. We have some great perks, including a special shout out in our program and through our social media outlets. Have a business you want plugged? We'll do that for you! We also have tickets to the show, as well as a meet and greet with the cast. Want to hang with them? We can throw a little soiree to thank you for your generous contribution!

If we don't reach the goal, you will still get the perks because we will still put the funds toward the show.

We have had some incredible luck in the past with some great productions thanks to the contributions we've received, so we're turning to crowdfunding once more in hopes of bringing another successful show to the stage.

Can't donate? No problem! You would be helping us greatly by spreading the word! Have friends who like theatre? How about Arthur Miller? Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or even SnapChat! Every bit of exposure helps us a great deal and we are very grateful for it.

Thank you for visiting our campaign and we hope you consider helping us with a donation or a shout out!

 

-Linda Alznauer

Director at The Group Rep Theatre in North Hollywood, CA

story:
FROM CATIE DAVIS'S PAPER, PROPOSING THIS PROJECT TO THE NYU FACULTY:

When I was seventeen years old, I decided I was going to going to direct musical theater for the rest of my life. At the time, the most edgy piece of theater I knew was RENT, and so I cofounded a theater company and directed an entirely teen production of RENT as an AIDS benefit. Looking back, I had no clue what it was like for the characters living in the east village of 1989 with a fatal virus, had no clue what it was like to fall in love, and truly don’t know where my confidence as a director came from, seeing as I had only been doing high school theater for three years and had never worked with a professional director. All I know is that the music inspired me, and I cared about sharing the messages of the show. In Passing Strange, the narrator has a moment where he turns to the audience and says, “You know, it’s weird when you wake up that morning and realize that your entire adult life was based on a decision made by a teenager." Looking back, I share Stew’s sentiment over the fact that a passionate teenager chose the path my life would take. I’ve never known where exactly that decision would lead me, nor do I know where I am headed next, but seventeen-­‐year-­‐old me knew that I wanted to make beautiful and socially relevant musical theater. At this point in my life, Passing Strange is the epitome of that goal.

Passing Strange is the journey of a young, black (composer and lyricist Stew resents the use of the term “African American” because, after all, not all dark-­‐skinned people are from Africa) musician from his LA home—haunted by mom, Church, terrible punk music, and the notion that he has to fill a specific community-­‐determined role—through the sensual, pot haze paradise of happy Amsterdam, to fiery Berlin’s art riots. Haunted by his racial roots, distant phone calls from home, and a desire to make meaningful music that sets him apart as an individual, the Youth searches for his identity and “the real” until his mother’s death brings him home. This homecoming forces him to finally see himself, and to look back on the mistakes that not only he, but all youth, make. He realizes that the most real thing in the world was right at his fingertips the whole time: love. For me, this piece is about so many things: how your roots define and influence you, what it means to be authentic, how we are shaped by our immediate surroundings, what it means to be young and what it means to be an adult, how to remain an individual without isolating yourself from love, and the power of art to heal. I find Passing Strange extremely relevant because these ideas are faced daily by artists and humans alike. 

I am passionate about the message of this musical; in an age where we are becoming more and more excluded from one another, the show’s theme that “only love is real” radiates, and proves that by reconnecting us, art can heal this malady. Passing Strange does just that: the music fills our souls and connects everyone in the room to its messages and to each other. 

 

THE PRODUCTION TEAM:

Catie Davis | Director

Sinai Tabak | Music Director

Jose Rivera | Choreographer

Kathleen Hefferon | Dramaturg

Frankie Oliva | Scenic Design

AC Gottlieb | Costume Design

Jenna Lloyd | Lighting Design

Frank Swann | Co Sound Design

Callan Hughes | Co Sound Design / Mixing

Caila Gale | Stage Manager

Korey-Elizabeth | Stage Manager

Tomi Tsunota | Faculty Mentor

 

THE CAST

M. Elijah Caldwell | Narrator

Dimitri Joseph Moise | Youth

Amy Leon | Mother

James Ross | Hugo / Christophe / Terry

Jelani Alladin | Mr. Franklin / Joop / Mr. Venus

Tatiana Wechsler | Sherry / Renata / Desi

Nicole Prothro | Edwina / Marianna / Sudabey

Brittany Arneo | Additional Vocals

When I was seventeen years old, I decided I was going to going to direct musical theater for the rest of my life. At the time, the most edgy piece of theater I knew was RENT, and so I cofounded a theater company and directed an entirely teen production of RENT as an AIDS benefit. Looking back, I had no clue what it was like for the characters living in the east village of 1989 with a fatal virus, had no clue what it was like to fall in love, and truly don’t know where my confidence as a director came from, seeing as I had only been doing high school theater for three years and had never worked with a professional director. All I know is that the music inspired me, and I cared about sharing the messages of the show. In Passing Strange, the narrator has a moment where he turns to the audience and says, “You know, it’s weird when you wake up that morning and realize that your entire adult life was based on a decision made by a teenager." Looking back, I share Stew’s sentiment over the fact that a passionate teenager chose the path my life would take. I’ve never known where exactly that decision would lead me, nor do I know where I am headed next, but seventeen-­‐year-­‐old me knew that I wanted to make beautiful and socially relevant musical theater. At this point in my life, Passing Strange is the epitome of that goal. 
Passing Strange is the journey of a young, black (composer and lyricist Stew resents the use of the term “African American” because, after all, not all dark-­‐skinned people are from Africa) musician from his LA home—haunted by mom, Church, terrible punk music, and the notion that he has to fill a specific community-­‐determined role—through the sensual, pot haze paradise of happy Amsterdam, to fiery Berlin’s art riots. Haunted by his racial roots, distant phone calls from home, and a desire to make meaningful music that sets him apart as an individual, the Youth searches for his identity and “the real” until his mother’s death brings him home. This homecoming forces him to finally see himself, and to look back on the mistakes that not only he, but all youth, make. He realizes that the most real thing in the world was right at his fingertips the whole time: love. For me, this piece is about so many things: how your roots define and influence you, what it means to be authentic, how we are shaped by our immediate surroundings, what it means to be young and what it means to be an adult, how to remain an individual without isolating yourself from love, and the power of art to heal. I find Passing Strange extremely relevant because these ideas are faced daily by artists and humans alike. 
I am passionate about the message of this musical; in an age where we are becoming more and more excluded from one another, the show’s theme that “only love is real” radiates, and proves that by reconnecting us, art can heal this malady. Passing Strange does just that: the music fills our souls and connects everyone in the room to its messages and to each other. 
 
THE PRODUCTION TEAM:
Catie Davis | Director
Sinai Tabak | Music Director
Jose Rivera | Choreographer
Kathleen Hefferon | Dramaturg
Frankie Oliva | Scenic Design
AC Gottlieb | Costume Design
Jenna Lloyd | Lighting Design
Frank Swann | Co Sound Design
Callan Hughes | Co Sound Design / Mixing
Caila Gale | Stage Manager
Korey-Elizabeth | Stage Manager
Tomi Tsunota | Faculty Mentor
 
THE CAST
M. Elijah Caldwell | Narrator
Dimitri Joseph Moise | Youth
Amy Leon | Mother
James Ross | Hugo / Christophe / Terry
Jelani Alladin | Mr. Franklin / Joop / Mr. Venus
Tatiana Wechsler | Sherry / Renata / Desi
Nicole Prothro | Edwina / Marianna / Sudabey
Brittany Arneo | Additional Vocals

story:
Mari Meade Dance Collective Goes to New Orleans Fringe!

Hello!

The Mari Meade Dance Collective started three years ago when Mari received the Kenan Fellowship at Lincoln Center Institute. Since then, this Brooklyn-based company has performed over 50 times in New York, Pennsylvania, and North Carolina.

MMDC will be performing the full-length version of Q & Unfinished Sentences, set to an original score by Dallas-based improvisational group BL Lacerta, as well as an excerpt of Spit & Skip. See our video clips of both pieces below!

Three of the company members are from the greater New Orleans area, and we are thrilled to go back there as dance professionals! We will be performing on the same stage Mari graduated on after Hurricane Katrina.

This is our first major tour, and we want to take advantage of this tremenduous opportunity. This is a major launching point for our young company, and we are ready!

 

What We Need & What You Get

A little more detail:

Your contribution will help us pay for flights (no more drafty Chinatown buses for us!), insurance, the venue, marketing, and per diem for six dancers and a stage manager.

You'll also become part of an emerging artistic community! We have a number of donation levels, each of which come with some pretty cool perks. You will be helping connect New York and its amazing arts community with New Orleans, a thriving cultural mecca. 

 

The Impact

This is our first major fundraising campign. We feel we have a strong group of constituents both in New York and New Orleans. Almost every show we've had for the past year has been sold out! We toured to Pennsylvania in 2009 for one day, and then to Asheville Fringe Festival in North Carolina in 2011 for four days, and now we feel New Orleans is the next step.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

               * Get the word out--use the Indiegogo share tool! Send to your email list. Post to your Facebook, your Twitter, and all social media.

               * Check out www.marimeadedancecollective.com 

 

Bonus Feature

We are having a Mardi Gras fundraising event OCTOBER 30th from 6-9 pm at TAMMANY HALL TAVERN! It's free, so come out, bring your friends, bid on some silent auction items, have a drink, and listen to some great live music, including Merrily Ruth Rosso from Merrily and the Poison Orchard!

 

Want to make a tax-deductible donation?

You can donate by check or credit card to The Field, with the memo "Mari Meade Dance Collective".

To donate by check:

Please make all checks payable to The Field.

Mail checks directly to:

Mari Meade Montoya
1038 Flushing Ave Apt 1R
Brookln NY 11237

To donate by credit card:

Go to the Contribute To A Sponsored Artist page https://www.thefield.org/ContributionToSA.aspx
Select Mari Meade Dance Collective from the list, click "Contribute," and follow the prompts


The Field is a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community. Contributions made to The Field and earmarked for Mari Meade Dance Collective are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 161 6th Avenue, New York NY 10013,(212)691-6969, fax: (212)255-2053, www.testing.thefield.org. A copy of The Field's latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
I'm working on my senior thesis for my Bachelor of Fine Arts in Experimental Theatre degree.  I am writing, directing, composing, and performing in a show and I need a little bit of help to buy costumes and tech needs (such as: cables for instruments, paint, props and set needs).  

The show is about a man and mechanisms in his home that manipulate him.  It is simultaneously about music and the way it manipulates our understandings of time and emotion.  It is silent.  For a better description, come see it!  It runs from May 9th to May 12th at The Shop Theatre, 721 Broadway 2nd floor.

 

Anything that you can give helps and I appreciate your generousity.  Thank you.

story:
Help the NHS Thespian Society and ¡Vamanos a Scotland! 

How often have you caught yourself singing in the shower, longing for a chance to shine in the spotlight, to be the center of attention with all eyes on you, to be...the star!?!?! Well no one gives two licks about you. I’m talking about the Nixon High School Thespian Society!!! We’ve just been invited to perform—not watch—PERFORM a play at the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh, Scotland this summer. Only 51 out of 2,300 nominated high schools were selected from across the country to be a part of the world’s largest arts festival. The point is, we all know high school students barely have lunch money, let alone are able to afford a trip to Europe!!!

A condensed history of our fabul-azing troupe 

For the past eight years, under the direction of Jose Flores, the Nixon High School Thespian Society has grown into one of the most successful theater programs in South Texas. Past members of the NHSTS have gone on to pursue successful theatrical and technical careers in New York and Los Angeles.  Now, after winning 5 consecutive District Championships, we have the opportunity to share our talent on an international stage!

Why throw your CASH at us? 

Unfortunately, for most parents in this district, paying for the entire cost of their child's trip is not possible. 97% of the students in LISD are considered economically disadvantaged.  When we reach our goal, we will be able to show the world that Laredo, Texas, in spite of our issues as a border town, has incredible theatrical talent and heart.

This life changing chance to perform on a European stage for this prestigious festival will help those of us seeking enrollment in a university to pursue theatrical arts as a career, give us the opportunity to travel outside of our small city, allow us to interact with students from all over the United States and Europe, and grant us the privilege of fulfilling a dream of exploring a world that until now has only been words and pictures in textbooks.

DOLLARS AND CENTS

We need a total of $100,000 to get to the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh, Scotland—about $4,400 for 20 student and 4 chaperones. The funds cover airfare, room & board, and meals. The total sounds like a lot of money, we know—so we have been raising funds for months and have about $24,000 saved up in our piggy bank (Thank you Joe for re-financing your house)! Today we are asking you to help us with a quarter of the total amount.

What's in it for you? 

For those of you with a deep desire to help us, your contribution comes with perks! Please read the contributing list to the left of this window describing our offers. Contribute all you can in support of not only Nixon High School’s theater students, but also our next generation of actors and technicians. The experiences we will gain might just enhance the already stellar theater movement in our city! 

If like many of us, you cannot contribute in a monetary fashion, you can still support us by sharing this site to every single person you have ever met and make some noise about our magnificent opportunity. You can also participate in our many fundraiser ventures (which will be announced as they take place) or by attending our performances in Laredo, Texas.

This is a lifetime opportunity that should not be passed up. Be a part of our growth as young artists and

                                                   ¡Vamanos a Scotland!

We promise we will not ask you to empty out your pockets ever again…(wink)

story:
Our Story

We are the Resident Artist Ensemble.  We have chosen to make Springfield, Missouri our home.  Located in the Ozark region of southwest Missouri, Springfield is experiencing exponential growth, accompanied by the ongoing emergence of a culturally rich, artistic community. In relation, we have discovered a need in the region for additional professional, AEA* sponsored, theatre. It is the Resident Artist Ensemble’s philosophy that the arts are a vital ingredient in the development of a vibrant, fiscally sound, community-centered city.  In response, we are laying the foundation for a permanent, resident artist ensemble, notably as a means to provide a long-term collaboration of regional professional theatre artists. Kicking off this new artist-led ensemble is the inaugural production of the Pulitzer Prize Winning play, Rabbit Hole, which features a core of founding members that includes three seasoned professional Equity actors, a beloved Springfield theatre veteran, and rising young local actor.  In order to produce Rabbit Hole’s inspiring portrayal of loss and forgiveness, we have partnered with the Springfield Contemporary Theatre at the Vandivort Center, a prolific, non-profit organization that has generously included us in their 16th season.  We are excited to present this award-winning play in a three-week run, opening September 9th 2011, and running through September 24th 2011.  It is our aim to utilize this inaugural production as a springboard for the development of the Resident Artist Ensemble as a long-term fixture in the southwest Missouri region.

 

*Actors' Equity Association ("AEA" or "Equity"), founded in 1913, is the labor union that represents more than 48,000 Actors and Stage Managers in the United States. Equity seeks to advance, promote and foster the art of live theatre as an essential component of our society.

 

Resident Artist Ensemble Founding Members:

 

Dr. Kurt Gerard Heinlein:  Kurt is a working member of Actor’s Equity Association (AEA), Screen Actor’s Guild (SAG), and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA). He is an organizational representative within the Association of Theatre Movement Educators (ATME) and is an active member of The Society of American Fight Directors (SAFD), Fight Directors Canada (), and the Stuntman’s Association. Kurt has performed and directed extensively since completing his in Acting from the Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music (CCM) with union performance credits that include New York, national tours, regional theatre, daytime drama, film, commercial print, and over 25 television spots, as well as directing credits that include New York, regional, and university theatre. His stunt and combat work have been seen in daytime drama, national commercials, and in the professional and educational theatre circuits. He is a specialist in ropes work and high falls. A lifelong environmental activist, Kurt completed his Ph.D. in theatre from Louisiana State University, and has earned several grants and awards for his work in Green Theatre. In 2008 he published Green Theatre: Promoting Ecological Preservation and Advancing the Sustainability of Humanity and Nature. He maintains a consistent dedication to environmental education, as noted by his volunteer work for The Nature Conservancy, The National Park Service, and the SAG sponsored BookPals Literacy Program. In 2010 he earned a Louisiana Service Award for work related to the development of his play Evangeline Drowning, which investigates wetlands disintegration in Southern Louisiana and the corresponding socio-emotional impact upon teenagers in the region.

 

Maggie Marlin:  Maggie is a performer, choreographer and director who has worked professionally in New York City, DC, Los Angeles, on national tours and with various regional theatres.  This summer Maggie has been invited to Belgrade, Serbia for a one-month residency at the DAH Theatre Research Center.  She received her BFA in Acting from the North Carolina School of the Arts and her in Theatre Pedagogy from Virginia Commonwealth University with additional research at the Eugene O’Neill National Theatre Institute and with the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford.  She is a working member of Actor’s Equity, the Association of Theatre Movement Educators and the North Carolina Stuntman’s Association.  Theatres she has worked with include the Kennedy Center, Second Stage, the Shakespeare Theatre, Washington Shakespeare Company, Woolly Mammoth, Theatre Alliance, Firehouse Theatre Project, Barksdale Theatre and is a member of Sonnet Repertory Theatre in NYC.  Favorite roles include Sally Bowles in Cabaret, Millie in Thoroughly Modern Millie (RTCC nomination for Best Actress in a Musical), Velma Kelly in Chicago, Mary Magdalene in Jesus Christ Superstar, Lisa in Boys’ Life, and Isabella in Measure for Measure.  Maggie has taught acting, mask and movement, and musical theatre at various institutions including Temple University, Hofstra University, National Theatre Conservatory in Denver, , and Young Playwrights Theatre of DC and is currently on faculty at Missouri State University.  She is most proud of her work volunteering with FreeArts NYC; bringing mentorship through the creative arts to the at-risk and underprivileged children of Harlem.

 

Sarah Wiggin: Sarah is a professional actor and director who has worked in Chicago, New York, and Washington, DC. Sarah earned her in Acting & Directing from the University of Arizona. Sarah continues working toward her professional certification in the Alexander Technique at the Urbana Center for the Alexander Technique where she is studying with Joan and Alex Murray.  Sarah is a proud working member of the Actor’s Equity Association (AEA) and the Screen Actor’s Guild (SAG). She has worked professionally with theatres such as The Shakespeare Theatre, Woolly Mammoth Theatre Company, Ford’s Theatre, Everyman Theatre, Washington Shakespeare Company, and The Folger Theatre. Her on-camera work includes Law & Order: and God’s and Generals, as well as independent film, industrial, and print work. Sarah directed professionally at Venus Theatre and assisted Aaron Posner in his Helen Hayes Award Winning production of The Two Gentlemen of Verona at The Folger Theatre. Her own production of Picasso at the Lapin Agile earned Baltimore City Paper’s #4 slot in their “Top Ten: the Year in Theatre” list.  Sarah is also a company member of New Agnes Orange, an ensemble theatre company devoted to using a collaborative process to build original performance material whose recent efforts have been focused on the production of Konrad, a theatre work based on Thomas Bernhard’s The Lime Works.

 

THE IMPACT

 

It has long been the stance of Actors’ Equity Association that the professional arts are a catalyst for economic development, quality of life, and civic pride in an urban community.  Studies in urban development strongly support this outlook. In contrast, studies also demonstrate how mid-sized urban centers facilitating growth in the absence of the professional arts commonly experience significant economic and population recessions in the decades that follow. In short, the professional arts are a core part of successful, long-term, urban growth. In relation, The Springfield New leader states, “Springfield will be recognized for its innovation and creativity-laden arts, culture and tourism as a catalyst for economic development, quality of life and civic pride -- all while maintaining its place as the cultural hub of the Ozarks.” With large polulations of Americans currently searching for financial stability alongside a high quality of family-centered life, the mid-sized city of Springfield and the surrounding Ozark region is growing rapidly. Accompanying this population growth is a significant increase in the city’s corporate activity, real estate development, and the emergence of shopping districts.  In line with the New Leader’s trajectory and the AEA philosophy, Springfield and the Ozark region is ripe for the creation of additional high-level, professional, AEA sponsored theatre.

 

The Resident Arist Esemble will serve as a key new ingredient in Springfield’s existing theatre and arts infrastructure. It will contribute significantly to the presence of professional theatre in the Ozark region and fuel Springfield’s development as a vibrant, fiscally sound, and community-centered city.


What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is critical in helping to cover our substantial production costs.  The money we raise here will be used for the following expenditures: Royalties & Scripts and PR/Marketing.  We are seeking additional funding from major local donors.

Breakdown of Estimated Production Costs:

*AEA SALARIES

Actor – Heinlein.................................................$2,425.50

Actor – Marlin....................................................$2,425.50

Actor – Wiggin....................................................$2,425.50

Stage Manager...................................................$2,841.30

                                                                                                $10,117.80

 

*As noted, it has long been the stance of Actors’ Equity Association that the professional arts are a catalyst for economic development, quality of life and civic pride in an urban community.  The presence of Actor’s Equity Association helps assure a community that its theatre will hold professional artisic values, contributing to the emergence of additional arts and the long-term presence of professional artists in the city. As a part of its mission on behalf of arts professionals, AEA also negotiates and mandates wages and working conditions and provides a wide range of benefits, including health and pension plans, for its members.

 

In relation, it is important to note that this production of Rabbit Hole, in affiliation with AEA and its guidelines, hold distinct budgetary needs that apply to AEA performer salaries. In our aim toward accomplishing the aforementioned mission, all Resident Artists Ensemble Equity members in this production of Rabbit Hole are contributing 100% of their AEA required salaries to company costs and development.  

 

ROYALTY/SCRIPTS

Scripts – 9 + shipping..............................................$75.00

Royalties..............................................................$3600.00

                                                                                                $3675.00

 

PR/MARKETING

Constant Contact....................................................$30.00

Handbills.................................................................$25.00

Community Free Press Ad......................................$65.00

News-Leader Ad....................................................$350.00

Website Development............................................$75.00

Posters....................................................................$90.00

Sandwich Board Posters.........................................$65.00

Playbills.................................................................$400.00

Opening Weekend Receptions..............................$175.00

Additional Advertising...........................................$500.00

                                                                                                $1775.00

TOTAL:  $15,567.80

Maggie Marlin:  Maggie is a performer, choreographer and director who has worked professionally in New York City, DC, Los Angeles, on national tours and with various regional theatres.  This summer Maggie has been invited to Belgrade, Serbia for a one-month residency at the DAH Theatre Research Center.  She received her BFA in Acting from the North Carolina School of the Arts and her  in Theatre Pedagogy from Virginia Commonwealth University with additional research at the Eugene O’Neill National Theatre Institute and with the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford.  She is a working member of Actor’s Equity, the Association of Theatre Movement Educators and the North Carolina Stuntman’s Association.  Theatres she has worked with include the Kennedy Center, Second Stage, the Shakespeare Theatre, Washington Shakespeare Company, Woolly Mammoth, Theatre Alliance, Firehouse Theatre Project, Barksdale Theatre and is a member of Sonnet Repertory Theatre in NYC.  Favorite roles include Sally Bowles in Cabaret, Millie in Thoroughly Modern Millie (RTCC nomination for Best Actress in a Musical), Velma Kelly in Chicago, Mary Magdalene in Jesus Christ Superstar, Lisa in Boys’ Life, and Isabella in Measure for Measure.  Maggie has taught acting, mask and movement, and musical theatre at various institutions including Temple University, Hofstra University, National Theatre Conservatory in Denver, , and Young Playwrights Theatre of DC and is currently on faculty at Missouri State University.  She is most proud of her work volunteering with FreeArts NYC; bringing mentorship through the creative arts to the at-risk and underprivileged children of Harlem.
 
Sarah Wiggin: Sarah is a professional actor and director who has worked in Chicago, New York, and Washington, DC. Sarah earned her  in Acting & Directing from the University of Arizona. Sarah continues working toward her professional certification in the Alexander Technique at the Urbana Center for the Alexander Technique where she is studying with Joan and Alex Murray.  Sarah is a proud working member of the Actor’s Equity Association (AEA) and the Screen Actor’s Guild (SAG). She has worked professionally with theatres such as The Shakespeare Theatre, Woolly Mammoth Theatre Company, Ford’s Theatre, Everyman Theatre, Washington Shakespeare Company, and The Folger Theatre. Her on-camera work includes Law & Order:  and God’s and Generals, as well as independent film, industrial, and print work. Sarah directed professionally at Venus Theatre and assisted Aaron Posner in his Helen Hayes Award Winning production of The Two Gentlemen of Verona at The Folger Theatre. Her own production of Picasso at the Lapin Agile earned Baltimore City Paper’s #4 slot in their “Top Ten: the Year in Theatre” list.  Sarah is also a company member of New Agnes Orange, an ensemble theatre company devoted to using a collaborative process to build original performance material whose recent efforts have been focused on the production of Konrad, a theatre work based on Thomas Bernhard’s The Lime Works.
 
THE IMPACT
 
It has long been the stance of Actors’ Equity Association that the professional arts are a catalyst for economic development, quality of life, and civic pride in an urban community.  Studies in urban development strongly support this outlook. In contrast, studies also demonstrate how mid-sized urban centers facilitating growth in the absence of the professional arts commonly experience significant economic and population recessions in the decades that follow. In short, the professional arts are a core part of successful, long-term, urban growth. In relation, The Springfield New leader states, “Springfield will be recognized for its innovation and creativity-laden arts, culture and tourism as a catalyst for economic development, quality of life and civic pride -- all while maintaining its place as the cultural hub of the Ozarks.” With large polulations of Americans currently searching for financial stability alongside a high quality of family-centered life, the mid-sized city of Springfield and the surrounding Ozark region is growing rapidly. Accompanying this population growth is a significant increase in the city’s corporate activity, real estate development, and the emergence of shopping districts.  In line with the New Leader’s trajectory and the AEA philosophy, Springfield and the Ozark region is ripe for the creation of additional high-level, professional, AEA sponsored theatre.




 
The Resident Arist Esemble will serve as a key new ingredient in Springfield’s existing theatre and arts infrastructure. It will contribute significantly to the presence of professional theatre in the Ozark region and fuel Springfield’s development as a vibrant, fiscally sound, and community-centered city. 



What We Need & What You Get
This campaign is critical in helping to cover our substantial production costs.  The money we raise here will be used for the following expenditures: Royalties & Scripts and PR/Marketing.  We are seeking additional funding from major local donors.
Breakdown of Estimated Production Costs:
*AEA SALARIES
Actor – Heinlein.................................................$2,425.50
Actor – Marlin....................................................$2,425.50
Actor – Wiggin....................................................$2,425.50
Stage Manager...................................................$2,841.30
                                                                                                $10,117.80
 
*As noted, it has long been the stance of Actors’ Equity Association that the professional arts are a catalyst for economic development, quality of life and civic pride in an urban community.  The presence of Actor’s Equity Association helps assure a community that its theatre will hold professional artisic values, contributing to the emergence of additional arts and the long-term presence of professional artists in the city. As a part of its mission on behalf of arts professionals, AEA also negotiates and mandates wages and working conditions and provides a wide range of benefits, including health and pension plans, for its members.

 
In relation, it is important to note that this production of Rabbit Hole, in affiliation with AEA and its guidelines, hold distinct budgetary needs that apply to AEA performer salaries. In our aim toward accomplishing the aforementioned mission, all Resident Artists Ensemble Equity members in this production of Rabbit Hole are contributing 100% of their AEA required salaries to company costs and development.   

 
ROYALTY/SCRIPTS
Scripts – 9 + shipping..............................................$75.00
Royalties..............................................................$3600.00
                                                                                                $3675.00

 
PR/MARKETING
Constant Contact....................................................$30.00
Handbills.................................................................$25.00
Community Free Press Ad......................................$65.00
News-Leader Ad....................................................$350.00
Website Development............................................$75.00
Posters....................................................................$90.00
Sandwich Board Posters.........................................$65.00
Playbills.................................................................$400.00
Opening Weekend Receptions..............................$175.00
Additional Advertising...........................................$500.00
                                                                                                $1775.00
TOTAL:  $15,567.80

story:
Short Summary

'I am No Bird' is a play in which a small cast of seven actors explore the lives of Emily and Charlotte Bronte and their novels, Wuthering Heights and Jane Eyre, throught movement and text.   This original devised work by Nicole Richwalsky and Marie Weigle, embarks on the themes of love, timeless characters, and the consequences of leaving things unsaid. 

'I Am No Bird' is produced in association with Alluvium Group.

'I Am No Bird' begins Friday January 25th. Performances are Friday and Saturdays at 8p.m. through February 9th.

What We Need & What You Get: How YOUR donations can help!

Our work is not wasteful; our needs are basic and important.

By funding our project you are helping to make this original production a reality. To help see where your donations go, we've included our budget breakdown: 

-goes towards our rehearsal space.

-provide us with costumes, our set and props

-gives us printing materials to make sure the house is full every night! 

-provides small stipends to our collaborators

Thank you so much for your time and donations and we hope to see you at the show!

Join us as we explore the characters, lives and stories of these two amazing women. 

'I Am No Bird' will be performed at The Bughouse Theatre.

 2054 W. Irving Park Rd

Cast and Production Team: 

Cast: 

Julia Rigby, Claire Biggers, Eric Duhon, Thea Richard, Cassandra Schillo, Adam Mack and Joseph Sultani

Directors&Writers:

Marie Weigle and Nicole Richwalsky

Producers:

Sarah Giamichael and Tony Santiago

Dramaturg: 

Lisa Kelly

Videographer:

Dave Giunta

*Music composed by Joseph Sultani
