story:
Who We Are

Hi!

Thanks for reading. We are Elly and Tanya of barking birds theatre and here is some info about our company and our mandate:

barking birds theatre was established in November 2010 by artistic directors Elsbeth McCall and Tanya Rintoul. Upon graduating from the Humber College Theatre performance program, McCall and Rintoul were inspired to create their own work from the foundation of their physical and devised theatre training and love of character driven storytelling. They are motivated by the stories of people from all time and place bringing them together as fragments from the neighborhoods, city, and world in which we live. They aim to create theatre that speaks to each individual and their main focus is the study of humanity.  Their work engages audiences in the experience of questioning life; examining the thoughts and desires we have each day: from fortune to fear. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

This summer barking birds theatre is producing Good Girl in the site specific catagory at the Toronto Fringe. We have been so lucky thus far and some incredible people have helped us out a long the way. We just need a little more help to take us all the way. Your donation will go to things like: posters and postcards, photography and film, lighting and sound equipment and the rental cost for our awesome site specific location Annex Pawn.  

Aside from the perks to your right, every single person who donates to this campaign will recieve a special thanks in our show program. Your support and the support of our commmunity are what make independant theatre in this city possible. So thank you. Whether you donate $1 or $100 thank you for contributing to our work. 

We are forever grateful.

Love,

Elly and tanya

story:
Help Kidd Pivot take The Tempest Replica on tour!

After a year-long sabbatical, Kidd Pivot is gearing up to take their most recent creation, The Tempest Replica, on a multi-city tour to Canada, the US, and the UK.  Kidd Pivot is excited to bring this work back to the stage, but we need your help to share it with new audiences on two continents.

A bit more about the project...

Created by internationally acclaimed choreographer Crystal Pite, The Tempest Replica has been called “a triumph” by the New Jersey Star Ledger and “an art work of astonishing beauty and thoughtfulness” by the New Yorker. Based on motifs from Shakespeare’s The Tempest, Pite stages a game of revenge and forgiveness, reality and imagination. The Tempest Replica explores these motifs in two contexts: a maquette of Shakespeare’s island as a metaphor for isolation, captivity and desire, and a nostalgic cityscape that evokes longing.

About the piece, Pite says “The Tempest Replica presents Shakespeare’s play in two parallel worlds...My hope for the viewer is that, armed with the plot points of a narrative, he or she is more deeply invested in the performance: the choreography becomes more than just a dance between two people – rather, it is imbued with a story we have all shared”. 

Eric Beauchesne, Jermaine Spivey, Jiří Pokorný, Peter Chu,  and Yannick Matthon, in The Tempest Replica. Photo by Jörg Baumann.

Across the pond and back again…

Taking The Tempest Replica across Canada, the US, to the UK is a big undertaking!  The company will come together in Vancouver, Canada for 4 weeks to rehearse the work, and make any needed set and costume repairs before taking everyone and everything on the road for 10-weeks of touring.

After opening in Vancouver, BC, Canada (March 6-8, 2014), in Kidd Pivot will travel fourteen people, and the full set to nine more cities for performances in:

Rockville, MD, USA (March 14-15, 2014)
Sherbrooke, QC, Canada (March 18, 2014)
Kingston, ON, Canada (March 21, 2014)
Kitchener-Waterloo, ON, Canada (March 25, 2014)
London, England (April 25-26, 2014)
Birmingham, England (May 1-2, 2014)
Toronto, ON, Canada (May 7-11, 2014)
Victoria, BC, Canada (May 21, 2014)
Quebec City, QC, Canada (May 29-31, 2014)

In some cities, the company will also offer master-classes and workshops to the local dance community.

All contributions received through Indiegogo will go directly to the costs of rehearsing and touring The Tempest Replica. By contributing you will be helping Kidd Pivot to bring this phenomenal work back to the stage!

Jermaine Spivey and Cindy Salgado in The Tempest Replica. Photo by Jörg Baumann.

Our ways of saying “thanks”!

We welcome contributions of any size – big or small, every gift will bring us closer to achieving our goal.  For a gift $25 or more you have the option to receive one of the special perks listed on this page – from personalized shout-outs to exclusive packages that include a printed photo, music download, personalized video thank-you, an invitation to a studio rehearsal, and even dinner with the company!

Do you live in Canada?

If you live in Canada, and would like to make a tax deductible contribution to Kidd Pivot’s The Tempest Replica tour project visit our website to discover ways to donate: http://www.kiddpivot.org/get-involved/donate/

Other Ways You Can Help

Spreading the word is another valuable way you can help Kidd Pivot:

·  "Share" this campaign on Facebook and Twitter! Email it to your friends! 
·  Follow us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/kiddpivot and twitter @kiddpivot


About the company

Integrating movement, original music, text, and rich visual design, Kidd Pivot’s performance work is assembled with recklessness and rigour, balancing sharp exactitude with irreverence and risk. Under the direction of internationally renowned Canadian choreographer Crystal Pite, the company’s distinct choreographic language – a breadth of movement fusing classical elements and the complexity and freedom of structured improvisation – is marked by a strong theatrical sensibility and a keen sense of wit and invention.

Crystal Pite has collaborated with celebrated dance artists, theatre companies and filmmakers in Canada, Europe, and the United States. Since 2002, she has created and performed under the banner of her own company. Her work and her company have been recognized with numerous awards and commissions. Kidd Pivot tours extensively around the world with productions that include The Tempest Replica (2011), The You Show (2010), Dark Matters (2009), Lost Action (2006), and Double Story (2004), created with Richard Siegal. Kidd Pivot is the recipient of the 2006 Rio Tinto Alcan Performing Arts Award, and was resident company at Künstlerhaus Mousonturm, with the support of Kulturfonds Frankfurt Rhein Main, in Frankfurt, Germany from 2010 to 2012.

Crystal Pite

Born and raised on the Canadian West Coast, choreographer and performer Crystal Pite is a former company member of Ballet British Columbia and William Forsythe’s Ballett Frankfurt.

Pite’s choreographic debut was in 1990, at Ballet British Columbia. Since then, she has created works for Nederlands Dans Theater I, Cullberg Ballet, Ballett Frankfurt, The National Ballet of Canada, Les Ballets Jazz de Montréal (Resident Choreographer, 2001-2004), Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, Ballet British Columbia, Alberta Ballet, Ballet Jorgen, and several independent dance artists; most recently Louise Lecavalier. Crystal is Associate Choreographer of Nederlands Dans Theater and Associate Dance Artist of Canada’s National Arts Centre in Ottawa. In November 2013 Crystal was appointed a Sadler’s Wells Associate Artist.

In 2002, she formed Kidd Pivot in Vancouver. Integrating movement, original music, text, and rich visual design, Kidd Pivot’s performance work is assembled with recklessness and rigour, balancing sharp exactitude with irreverence and risk. The company’s distinct choreographic language – a breadth of movement fusing classical elements and the complexity and freedom of structured improvisation – is marked by a strong theatrical sensibility and a keen sense of wit and invention.

Kidd Pivot tours nationally and internationally, performing such highly-demanded and critically acclaimed works as Dark Matters and Lost Action. Kidd Pivot’s residency at the Künstlerhaus Mousonturm in Frankfurt (2010-2012) provided her the opportunity to create and tour her most recent works, The You Show and The Tempest Replica, with her dancers and collaborators.

Pite is the recipient of the Banff Centre’s Clifford E. Lee Award (1995), the Bonnie Bird North American Choreography Award (2004), and the Isadora Award (2005). Her work has received several Dora Mavor Moore Awards (2009, 2012), and a Jessie Richardson Theatre Award (2006). She is the recipient of the 2008 Governor General of Canada’s Performing Arts Award, Mentorship Program. Most recently, she was awarded the 2011 Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award, the inaugural Lola Award in 2012, and the Canada Council’s 2012 Jacqueline Lemieux Prize.

“Pite is a true genius of dance.” – The Globe and Mail

“… her choreographies have their own language: mercurial and full of power and humor.”  – Journal Frankfurt

story:
Hodgepodge Dance Academy Owner, Katie Hodge, believes passionately in the value of arts education (especially dance) in life of children and youth. In these difficult  economic times in which we find ourselves, there have been and continue to be cuts made to our arts subsidy programs both in the public schools and in our private and personal budgets.

This fundraiser (for the enriching experience of dance) is to benefit the children and youth of the DuPont, Steilacoom, Lakewood and Lacey communities of southwestern Washington State as well as the military families of the Joint military Base Lewis-McChord, JBLM. There are over 8700 families in the DuPont community alone. We hope to encourage these families to avail themselves of this unique opportunity which, through your generosity, will subsidize tuition scholarships to dance.

It is tragic when a financial lack or undue personal burden deprives a child from developing a God-Given talent. We want to change this.

There are three (3) categories of giving:
- Dance Apparel fund:
  Uniforms/Costumes (tights, leotards,  shoes)
- Tuition Assistance Fund:
  Partial/Full scholarships/Membership  Fees
- Equipment & Operating Expenses Fund:
Dance Floor, Barres and Mirrors, Sound System, Insurance

All tuition scholarships will be dispersed to qualifying students in the name of the donor who will receive a thank you from or on behalf of the recipient.

In addition all donors/backers will be recognized on HDA's website and those backers who donate $100, $250, $500, or $1000, will be honored as: Family Circle Donors:

- $100 Bronze Circle
- $250 Silver Circle
- $500 Gold Circle
- $1000 Platinum Circle

Backers levels:
$5
$10
$20
$25
$50
$85
$100
$250
$500
$1000

Backers to indicate which fund they are supporting.

Thank you for helping us give the gift of Dance!

  -Katie Hodge
  Hodgepodge Dance Academy

story:
The Saint John Theatre Company

Hi there! Thanks for popping in. We're the Saint John Theatre Company, the largest theatre company in southern New Brunswick and we're proud to say, volunteer-run. 

We're the people in your neighbourhood and we're getting ready to put on a show! We launch our 2013-14 season with Annie:The Musical, November 14-16, 2013 and this year, we're going to need your help.

Auditions have already started and rehearsals will stretch through the summer – which means our costs have started too. Our total budget for Annie is about $75,000 and while tickets sales are our largest revenue source, it won't be enough to get us to centre stage.

Here's How You Can Help 

We want to raise $7,500 – 10 per cent of our total production budget – by reaching out to you, our friends, neighbours, admirers and soon-to-be fans.

Your contribution will help us with hard costs of our productions including:

  • set design;
  • costumes;
  • props; and,
  • theatre rental of the majestic Imperial Theatre – one of the greatest theatres in Canada. (We're not kidding, it's a gorgeous place to perform.)

We've got some fun perks that will introduce you to some of the real life characters who bring the Theatre Company's productions to life. So join our campaign; we bet our bottom dollar you're going to like it here.

As for when the sun is going to come out...we'll leave that for one of our perks.

Other Ways You Can Help

No cash? No problem, you can help us by:

  • Sharing our campaign through your social media networks such as Facebook, Twitter, Google+ and LinkedIn; 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools; and,
  • Visit our website www.saintjohntheatrecompany.com to find out more about the 2013/14 season and buy tickets to our shows!

Oh! Donors! Dear donors! We love you IndieGoGo donors! You're only a click away!

Thanks for your support! We couldn't do it without you!

 

The Saint John Theatre Company is a registered Canadian non-profit.

story:
Wir bitten um Eure Unterstützung!

SARG NIEMALS NIE

Ein Musical zum Totlachen

Der erste und letzte Teil der dreiteiligen Sarga 

!!! Limitierte Sitzplätze! Eine Spende ab 50€ garantiert ein Ticket !!!

Was ist lustig am Tod? Gar nichts. Es sei denn, man arbeitet im Bestattungsunternehmen Schneider. Dort hält man es nur mit Humor aus - mit schwarzem Humor.
Seit dem Tod seines Vaters muss David das bankrotte Familienunternehmen alleine führen. Nur die polnische Haushaltshilfe Dakmar steht ihm bei. Sein älterer Bruder Tim ist vor acht Jahren von der Familie abgehauen, um in Indien das Kamasutra zu studieren. Jetzt ist Tim pleite und kommt zurück nach Hause, um sein Erbe abzuholen. Doch es gibt kein Erbe.
David, Dakmar und Tim brauchen dringend Geld - eine Idee muss her.
Aus Versehen rauchen die Drei die Asche eines Verstorbenen. Herr Schmitt entpuppt sich als die beste Droge aller Zeiten. Tim hat die Idee, das Zeug zu verkaufen: Herrn Schmitt als Shit. Das Geschäft läuft prächtig, bis die Polizei hinter die Machenschaften der drei Hobby-Dealer kommt.
Ein sargenhaftes Musical für alle Hinterbliebenen.

 

Ein Musical von Dominik Wagner & Jörn-Felix Alt & Christoph Reuter

 

Idee: Dominik Wagner & Jörn-Felix Alt & Jennifer Wjertzoch

Musik: Christoph Reuter & Cristin Claas

Text: Dominik Wagner

 

Regie: Dominik Wagner & Jörn-Felix Alt

Musikalische Leitung: Christoph Reuter

Choreographie: Jörn-Felix Alt

Kostüm & Bühnenbild: Jennifer Wjertzoch

Produktionsassistenz: Olivia Schaaf

 

Aufführungsort: Neuköllner Oper Berlin (Kleines Studio), Karl-Marx-Str. 131-133, 12043 Berlin

Premiere (UA): 17. Juli 2013

Vorstellungen: 17.07., 25.07., 28.07.(2x), 01.08. und 04.08.2013(2x)

 

!!! Limitierte Sitzplätze! Eine Spende ab 50€ garantiert ein Ticket !!!

Die Spenden fließen zu 100% in die Produktion.

Bei Fragen zum Stück oder zur Kampagne wenden Sie sich bitte an: sarg-niemals-nie@web.de

story:
Twelfth Night At The Dell Stratford-Upon-Avon

Who We Are

We're Play The Fool Productions. We're a group of professional, trained actors aiming to produce FREE Shakespeare for the masses. Our first production is a Hollywood-themed version of TWELFTH NIGHT which will be performed as part of the RSC Summer Season at their Open-Air venue, The Dell, in Stratford-Upon-Avon.

We're not out to make money, we just want to perform high quality, enjoyable and interactive productions of the plays we all love, to a willing audience, for no charge, in Shakespeare's home town. 

We're putting everything together off our own backs, so naturally we need a little help from our friends, and that's where you come in!

With your help, you'll give us costumes, you'll give us a place to stay, and you'll give us a place to rehearse, to name just a few things. With your help we want to make this show the best we can, and we can't do it without you!

What We Need

The following are some of the specific things your generous donations will fund:

  • 2 Weeks of Rehearsal Venues.
  • The creation of our wonderful set, designed by Isabella Van Braeckel.
  • The hire of our ace Hollywood-themed costumes.
  • The costs of the few, exciting and essential props we need.
  • Our accommodation for the performances in Stratford-Upon-Avon (We're camping to cut down costs, plus it's fun).
  • Our Publicity (flyers and advertising for the show to spread the word.)

If we should surpass our target, we'll use any extra funds to produce the show in a London venue. So if you can't make it to Stratford-Upon-Avon, your donation will help us bring the show to you! 

What You Get Back

Here are some of the things we'll give to you to say thanks, depending on which of our perk packages you might go for:
  • Our eternal gratitude.
  • A Thank you on all social media.
  • A Postcard from the cast in Stratford-Upon-Avon.
  • A Signed photo of the Cast.
  • A Video message from the Cast recorded in Stratford-Upon-Avon
  • A Video of the Cast serenading you with your song of choice from Stratford-Upon-Avon. (Just 4 available)
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • It's you folks who can help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • The best way to do that is to use the Indiegogo share tools.

Thanks for listening and helping us to do what we love!

story:
Greetings, my name is Patricia Richardson. I’m a self published author. I’ve adapted my debut title “A Place for Ida into a “Stage Play, “IDA.” I produced it in September, 2012 at The Art Place, in Marietta, GA. I produced it on a shoe string budget because of my passion and belief in my work. “IDA” received great reviews however; my expenses were in the RED!

 

Since writing the first paragraph of “A Place for Ida” I envisioned it being a Movie, Stage Play and a Sequel. I started writing the sequel before completing “Ida.” However, I was not that successful in getting it on the “Big Screen” or the Stage. It took me fourteen years of listening to lies and promises from people that lifted my spirit, hoping that someone was finally going to help me live my dream, to no avail! So I produced it myself and I’m doing it again on a shoe string budget.

 

“IDA” is scheduled to be performed, August 3, 2013 at 7 pm at Saint Philip AME Church-Atlanta, GA. Again, I’m stepping out on faith; with God’s grace I’ll have a better return this time. Oh, did I mention that “IDA” is a Christian based play.

 

Please, no donation is too small. I don’t have fourteen more years for my dream to prevail. I’m 58 years old. Funding will be use to pay for: Venue, Cast, Wardrobe, Travel, Food and Advertisement.

 

Any support is appreciated. Please refer others to the Indiegogo share tools  to contribute.

 

Please visit: www.leapoffaithpublishing.com to review my titles and my bio.

 

Thanking you in advance.

 

God speed

 

Patricia

story:
v. Bap·tize(d) : To cleanse or purify. To initiate.

Accountability or Redemption?

Inspired by true events, Baptized examines the epidemic of corruption in our religious institutions. Abuse of power is a tale that plays out daily in churches and families across the country (check out some frightening statistics). Baptized is the story of one family in one church where silence allows the cycle to continue.

Baptized enjoyed it's first public reading on January 14, 2013 and will make it's world premiere at the 2013 New York International Fringe Festival (August 9th - 25th).

 

Who We Are

Baptized is an original, full-length play written and directed by Kristen Lishen, with a stellar cast featuring: 

Eilis Cahill*, Ricardo Davila, Abby Eletz, David M. Farrington, Glenn Leo,  Christopher McMahon*, Sabina Petra and Brandon Salerno.

Check out our website: www.baptizedplay.com, follow us on twitter: @Baptizedplay, and "like" us on facebook: Baptized the Play

 

What's A Fringe?

The New York International Fringe Festival has been instrumental in showcasing new theatre for 17 years.

From their website: The New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, with more than 200 companies from all over the world performing for 16 days in more than 20 venues.


Past Fringe success stories include Urinetown (winner of 3 Tony Awards), Silence! The Musical (still enjoying an off Broadway run), Evolutionary Tales, Triassic Parq and Matt and Ben (starring Mindy Kaling).

 

Why We Need You

Putting on a show is expensive! 

Here's where your funds will go:

  • Production Costs (Costumes, Prop Rental, Storage)
  • Stipends for Cast and Crew
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Equity Fees (we're a proud union show)
  • Marketing and Press - it doesn't matter how good a play is if nobody sees it.
  • Insurance 

Should we excede our funding goal (Praise Jesus!) all additional funds will go towards furthering the production in Fringe and beyond, including:

  • Full Video Production
  • Better Stipends for Cast and Crew (they're that good, they deserve it)
  • Greater Marketing Flexibility 

No dough? We also need folks to spread the word!  Seriously, share this campaign, pass along our twitter and facebook info ... get people talking! No contribution (of time, resources or -obviously- money) is too small.  We can't do this without you.  Go forth!

 

What's In It For You ...

We mean other than the thrill of contributing to live theatre. In addition to our heartfelt gratitude, check the sidebar for donation specific goodies.

 

Thank you for checking out our campaign. We know you'll love Baptized as much as we do. 

 

*Appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association

story:
Why Fund All's Well?

As far as we can tell, Shakespeare's "All's Well That Ends Well" has never been done in Chattanooga—and there's no time like the present. Shakespeare Chattanooga, founded in 2006, is the only company in town focused entirely on the classics. My goal in creating it was to bring a level of interpretation to Shakespeare's work that hasn't been seen here before, except in road shows.

This play's time has come. Long considered a "problem play" because its main characters and subject matter were unsympathetic to audiences of other ages, its themes and people will be very recognizable to the 21st century. We've assembled a super cast, director Stephanie Smith has a wonderful vision for the piece—now we just need your help.

Whatever you contribute will go one of two places: salaries for cast and crew, or productions costs. We keep things simple, but from the very beginning, have always attempted to compensate our company to some level at least.

What We Need & What You Get

• We're looking to raise $3,000 through Indiegogo. This won't pay for the whole show, but we are doing other forms of fundraising as well. We expect the show to cost about $5,000, because we have a donated space, the theatre inside Grace Episcopal Church, so won't have to pay rent.

• Here are the perks we are offering at various levels of donations...but donate whatever you can! No donation is too small.

Level 1 ($10): Shout-out in the program as "Bud of the Bard"
Level 2 ($25): 1 plus one free ticket to any "All's Well" performance (August 16-18 and 23-25)
Level 3: ($50): 1 plus two free tickets to any "All's Well" performance
Level 4: ($100): 1 plus four free tickets to any "All's Well" performance
Level 5: ($250): 1 plus 4 plus one free tuition to the next session of "Shakespeare for the Elizabethan Impaired" (value $175)
Level 6: ($500): 1 plus 4 plus 5 plus a one-time walk-on during the "All's Well" performance of your choice for you or your proxy
Level 7: ($1,000, limit 1): All of the above plus a private performance of "All's Well" at your home or the space you designate.

If we do not reach our entire goal, all funds raised will be divided equally between salaries to performers and crew and production costs.

The Impact

By helping us produce "All's Well That Ends Well," you'll be contributing in a big way to the growing arts community in Chattanooga. Shakespeare Chattanooga hopes one day to be able to create a Shakespeare Festival here, and so far, we've produced "Othello," "Twelfth Night," "Much Ado About Nothing" and "The Merchant of Venice," along with an original complilation, "Songs, Sonnets and Soliloquies", as well as doing workshops in schools, at the Main Library, and co-producing on projects with several other arts organizations.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute funds (and boy, do we sympathize!) please help us get the word out to as many people as possible about the show, and about this fundrasing campaign. We're also looking for volunteers to help work the show, so if you'd like to help that way, let us know!

story:
Twenty Something Theatre is proud to present Stephen Karam's Speech & Debate - Oct. 2-12 at Studio 1398 on Granville Island.

"A triumph…hilarious…cliche-free, and immensely entertaining" - The New York Times

"This play is an f-ing blast" - Time Out Chicago

Speech & Debate is a fiercely funny dark comedy unlike anything else gracing a Vancouver stage this year. Written by 2012 Pulitzer Prize nominee Stephen Karam, it is the story of three teenage misfits brought together by a sex scandal in their town, Salem Oregon. Secrets become currency, blogs are belted and the truth can imprison you just as easily as it can set you free. Expect singing, dancing, and dramatic interpretations of history.

The show takes place at Studio 1398 in Granville Island from October  3- 12, 2013 (Pay- what - you - can preview performance on October 2). 

Speech & Debate marks the Twenty Something directing debut of Associate Artistic Producer Brian Cochrane. The cast features Scott Button (Night Light, Green Thumb Theatre), Claire Hesselgrave (The Penelopiad, Citadel Theatre), and Alex Rose (The Merry Wives of Windsor/King John, Bard on the Beach). 

Our Company & Impact

Coming off an amazing 2012 that was led by the Jessie Award-Winning Bomb-itty of Errors (Outstanding Costume Design, Significant Artistic Achievement - Outstanding Ensemble Performance), Twenty Something is back with another amazing contemporary play that you won't want to miss!

Twenty Something is an award-winning independent theatre company dedicated to using a dynamic and exploratory rehearsal process to produce contemporary scripted plays that are provocative, edgy, and relevant to our generation. We aim to exceed expectations of what theatre and entertainment can be. We are committed to providing Vancouver's next generation of theatre artists with opportunities to pursue their craft and we strive to enhance Vancouver's theatre community with productions that entertain and evoke the lives of today's young people. 

Twenty-Something Theatre fills an important function in Vancouvers cultural ecology: it offers edgier scripts, including original works such as Sean Minogue's Prodigals, and even in its name attempts to appeal to a younger demographic. --Colin Thomas, Georgia Straight 

How can you help? 

In order to mount "Speech & Debate" we need to fundraise approximately $500 through individual contributions from people like you. We're asking for your support to make sure this is a memorable production. As a small independent theatre company, any amount you're able to contribute goes a long way in covering the cost of our rehearsal space. The rehearsal space is a vital part of the production's progress and you will be part of making this show the best it could be. 

In return, we're putting the "fun" back in "fundraising" - check out the unique perks we're offering! As "Speech & Debate" incorporates high school, song, and dance - we have created fun, sincere ways of showing our love for your support. All contributors will be recognized in the play's program. 

More than anything you can also help us spread the word! Tell all your friends, family, co-workers, strangers that you meet on the street, about this exciting production! You can follow along with our progress:

 Every little bit helps! 

More than anything you can also help us spread the word! Tell all your friends, family, co-workers, strangers that you meet on the street, about this exciting production! You can follow along with our progress: 

Blog, An Unidentified Production http://twentysomethingtheatre.blogspot.ca/

or on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/twentysomethingtheatre

or Twitter  https://twitter.com/theatre_20

No matter what, we hope you'll check out the production in October! 

From everyone involved in Speech & Debate, we would like to extend an enthusiastic thank you for all of your support!
story_txt:
Twenty Something Theatre is proud to present Stephen
Karam's Speech & Debate - Oct. 2-12 at Studio 1398 on Granville
Island.
"A triumph…hilarious…cliche-free, and immensely
entertaining" - The New York Times
"This play is an f-ing blast" - Time Out Chicago
Speech & Debate is a
fiercely funny dark comedy unlike anything else gracing a Vancouver stage this
year. Written by 2012 Pulitzer Prize nominee Stephen Karam, it is the story of
three teenage misfits brought together by a sex scandal in their town, Salem
Oregon. Secrets become currency, blogs are belted and the truth can
imprison you just as easily as it can set you free. Expect singing, dancing,
and dramatic interpretations of history.
The show takes place at Studio 1398 in Granville
Island from October  3- 12, 2013 (Pay- what - you - can preview
performance on October 2). 
Speech & Debate marks the Twenty Something directing debut of
Associate Artistic Producer Brian Cochrane. The cast features Scott Button (Night Light, Green Thumb Theatre),
Claire Hesselgrave (The Penelopiad,
Citadel Theatre), and Alex Rose (The
Merry Wives of Windsor/King John, Bard on the Beach). 
Our Company & Impact
Coming off an amazing 2012 that was led by the Jessie Award-Winning Bomb-itty
of Errors (Outstanding Costume Design, Significant Artistic
Achievement - Outstanding Ensemble Performance), Twenty Something is back with
another amazing contemporary play that you won't want to miss!
Twenty Something is an award-winning independent theatre company
dedicated to using a dynamic and exploratory rehearsal process to produce
contemporary scripted plays that are provocative, edgy, and relevant to our generation.
We aim to exceed expectations of what theatre and entertainment can be. We are
committed to providing Vancouver's next generation of theatre artists with
opportunities to pursue their craft and we strive to enhance Vancouver's
theatre community with productions that entertain and evoke the lives of
today's young people. 
Twenty-Something Theatre fills an
important function in Vancouvers cultural ecology: it offers edgier scripts,
including original works such as Sean Minogue's Prodigals, and even
in its name attempts to appeal to a younger demographic. --Colin Thomas, Georgia Straight 


How can you help? 

In order to mount "Speech &
Debate" we need to fundraise approximately $500 through individual
contributions from people like you. We're asking for your support to make sure
this is a memorable production. As a small independent theatre company, any
amount you're able to contribute goes a long way in covering the cost of our
rehearsal space. The rehearsal space is a vital part of the production's
progress and you will be part of making this show the best it could be. 
In return, we're putting the
"fun" back in "fundraising" - check out the unique perks
we're offering! As "Speech & Debate" incorporates high school,
song, and dance - we have created fun, sincere ways of showing our love for
your support. All contributors will be recognized in the play's program. 
More than anything you can also help
us spread the word! Tell all your friends, family, co-workers, strangers that
you meet on the street, about this exciting production! You can follow along

story:
FreeGeek Chicago

  • Is a community organization that refurbishes used computers and parts to provide functional computers to volunteers and the general public.
  • Is a provider of education in practical computing, hands-on job skills training, and an outlet for community service.
  • Recycles non-reusable materials in an ethical, safe, and environmentally responsible manner.
  • Works to create a strong participatory community by creating a safe space and welcoming environment for all.
  • Is an advocate of open source software and Free/Libre culture for the general public.
  • Is an autonomous, self-sustaining organization.

Learn more about FreeGeek Chicago at:
http://freegeekchicago.org/about

What are we Fundraising for?

<UPDATE>

The Internship Team has finished interviews and has come to a consensus: we are extending two offers to two excellent candidates. One offer is for a full 13 weeks, while the other is for 7 weeks with an opportunity to extend to a full 13 weeks based on FreeGeek finances and Community consent.

The 13 week position has been offered to Alex CG, an awesome candidate who applied for the 2012 position and made last year’s choice difficult. This year we hope to have Alex CG do some great work in organizing a variety of regular workshops and our now annual Software Freedom Day.

Our 7 week position has been offered to Alex Cox, another outstanding candidate who is currently a student at Colombia College. We hope that she will bring some great talent to helping us develop an online store and marketing materials.

A full profile of each intern will be released upon acceptance of their position.

We hope that you can help us get the support we need to extend Alex Cox for a full summer position: An additional $1200. Though our campaign will close tomorrow evening, any financial help now and after this deadline will get us closer this new goal. If you have already contributed, please share this request.

Many thanks!

</UPDATE>

FreeGeek Chicago will offer our third-annual, paid summer internship to an individual who can help expand our services to the community and our earned revenue sources. The intern will help lead our second-annual Software Freedom Day and:

  • Develop a regular program of educational workshops to be hosted at FreeGeek that will be open to the general public, OR
  • Research online marketplaces and develop a FreeGeek store for selling branded items (T-Shirts, Buttons, Stickers, etc.) and a vast array of odd-ball items that have value but can't be sold in our physical thrift shop, OR
  • Produce educational materials to take on-the-road and present to businesses, school groups, churches, civic groups, and other community organizations, OR
  • Create and accomplish an independent project or program that will help produce financial or other benefits for the FreeGeek Community.

In exchange, FreeGeek will pay our Summer Intern $15.00 per hour for 160 hours of work for a total of $2,400.

A full internship description is available on our Internship Application Page.

Campaign Goals

We have set our campaign goal this year at $2800.

  • $2,400 will be paid to the intern for 160 hours of work.
  • $400 will be retained by FreeGeek Chicago to cover staff time and expenses dedicated to the internship program (ex: Campaign fees will be about $150).
  • All donations that exceed the final published internship budget will go towards our general programming.

Why are we Fundraising?

The FreeGeek Community sees our Summer Intern program as a key investment in the growth of our organization. The intern will focus on projects that increase our service to the community and increase our revenue. As with all great investments, the financial pay-offs from an intern's work will come later while the costs will be up-front. Instead of applying for grants or loans, we are appealing to our diverse support network to help fund this program. Read more about this in our Statement of Funding.

Why Pay an Intern?

At FreeGeek, we strongly believe that those who put in effort above and beyond what is asked of regular volunteers be compensated in some way. In addition, unpaid internships are a luxury that many individuals, including many FreeGeek volunteers, can not afford. While a FreeGeek intern will receive incredible experience, we also want to ensure that they receive fair compensation for their work. Offering a paid internship will keep the program accessible to everyone and will give FreeGeek an even better pool of applicants.

Intern Successes!

2012 Intern

Our Summer Intern for 2012 was the wonderful Cecilia Calabria, who came to FreeGeek with a fantastic background in the open-source community as well as a ton of entrepreneurial experience. Originally from Argentina, Cecilia was establishing herself in the United States and FreeGeek's Internship gave her an opportunity to connect with the local FOSS community.

By the end of her internship, Cecilia produced a ton of fantastic work for FreeGeek including:

  • Translating of FreeGeek promotional materials into Spanish
  • Preparing for a variety of outreach events
  • Organizing the first FreeGeek-hosted Software Freedom Day event, drawing in over 65 participants.

2011 Intern

The first FreeGeek Summer Intern was Axel Rendon, a long-time volunteer. Axel had progressively increased his troubleshooting and repair skillset in our OpenBuild program and was a natural choice to work on our toughest problem at the time: getting laptops on the sales shelves. During his internship, he focused on:

  • Cleaning, organizing, and running our laptop repair area.
  • Working through a backlog of laptops to repair for sale.
  • Lending help to our sole paid staff member to keep the shop open.

Laptops are always in demand at FreeGeek and Axel's efforts produced some great summer revenue for the community.

We are still benefiting from all of the work these individuals accomplished and with your help, we can repeat this success with this year's summer internship program!

Other Ways to Donate

If you would like to make an anonymous cash donation, just come visit and ask any on-duty staff person to make a donation. Can't make a donation but want to help us reach our target? Let your friends and family know about our 2013 Summer Internship Campaign and check us out on:

  • Twitter
  • Facebook
  • Google+

Of course you can always support FreeGeek by donating your old hardware, especially used laptops.

As much as we need your money, we hope that you come in and donate your time. Being a member of the FreeGeek volunteer community can help just as much.

If you would like to make an anonymous cash donation, just come visit and ask any on-duty staff person to make a donation. Can't make a donation but want to help us reach our target? Let your friends and family know about our 2013 Summer Internship Campaign and check us out on:

story:
Hi all-

Thanks for stopping by our indiegogo page! We’re Johnny Lloyd and William Steinberger, but together we’re InVersion Theatre, a Philadelphia-based company started in 2011. Now in our third year of existence, we’re dedicated to exploring works that ask questions about the human condition. Past shows have included SHEPARD/BECKETT, The Dutchman, and Miss Julie.

This time around, we’re digging deep into the work of one of the most fascinating writers of the last 100 years, Caryl Churchill, with her play Owners. It’s a story about haves, have nots, and what it takes to attain and maintain control – all centering around a dispute between a landlord and her tenants. Sounds a little bit relevant? We thought so, too.

Of course, as a small theater company we’re always in the need of a little bit of support from our community.  Specifically, we need help with the following things:

1)      Space. We can’t have a show if we don’t have a venue!

2)      Compensating actors, designers, etc. We think the work our creative team members do is pretty rad, and while they like it when we tell them that, they like it even more (and can afford to do more rad work) when we’re able to give them a small stipend. It’s our way of letting them know we take them – and all artists – seriously, even if we’re a small company.

3)      Technical capacity. InVersion believes in creating a world for our audience, and in order to do that we need money – to build, to clothe, to light, to create.

4)      Marketing. When we’re proud of our work (and we certainly always aim to be), we want everyone to know. Donations go to helping us create press materials and get them all around Philadelphia.

Will and I will occasionally be in this space to give you guys updates, but before you donate we just wanted to say thank you for supporting us. Whether you’re a long-time supporter or a first-time donator, it’s good to know that we’re loved by our community and hopefully we can do you all proud in 2013.

So – take a gander at our sweet perks, check out our webpage and facebook page, and tell all of your friends about us. Thanks so much!

Best-

Johnny and Will

story:
Short Summary

The Water Dream is an award winning original new rock musical starring Anthony Rapp, star of the Tony Award and Pulitzer Prize Winning Broadway smash and blockbuster film Rent.

THE WATER DREAM has received seven years of non-stop development, and a dozen workshops, readings, and concerts, in New York City, Boston, and beyond, including Frye Island, Maine, The Drama Book Shop, The Bushwick Starr, The Irish Rogue, Shetler Studios, The Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Actors Shakespeare Project, and Shakespeare and Company in Lenox, Massachusetts, headlining its Studio Festival of Plays, and starring Anthony Rapp and other Broadway talents.
 
The cast and creative team have included many artists from Broadway, Film, Television, Cirque du Soleil and more. Produced by Royal Family Productions, THE WATER DREAM is an Official Selection of The New York Musical Theater Festival 10TH Anniversary Season 2013. Tickets www.nymf.org

What We Need

We need to raise an additional $5,000 to help pay for publicity costs, space rental and production expenses.

The Impact

Your contribution helps us take a few more giant steps forward, and lets us join one of the largest musical theatre festivals in the United States!

Anything you can contribute would be greatly appreciated!!

story:
WHO WE ARE

Mnemonic Theatre began as the brainchild of Caleb McMullen and Jordan Dibe: two young, naïve theatre makers. Over three years, it has evolved into a unique crucible of production, artists development and community outreach.  Through workshopping new works, producing emerging artist showcases, full scale productions and networking events, we have developed 4 CORE VALUES which speak to who we are and what we believe in.

  • INNOVATION progress doesn't happen by following suit.  We say no to the status quo.
  • ACCOUNTABILITY we insist on being held accountable to the quality of our work. Judge us please!
  • VITALITY we tell stories that are worth remembering.
  • COMMUNITY we're all in this together.

More information about us can be found at www.MnemonicTheatre.com 

ROMEO AND JULIET

This production is the first in what we hope will be a yearly celebrated offering of free Summer Shakespeare at Vancouver's Sunset Beach!

Romeo and Juliet at Sunset Beach is our take on Shakespeare in the Park. The Public Theatre's Shakespeare in the Park, founded by Joseph Papp, was intended to 'give back' to the community as an introduction to the things that drive theatre artists and to remove the economic barriers that consistently isolate and attenuate the community reached through the theatre.  It is in this same spirit that we're offering this FREE production.  

We have cast some of the most exciting emerging artists in Vancouver and have given them the opportunity to share their newly developed talent. The casting process allowed us to make some unconventional choices by casting women for the roles of Romeo and Mercutio (to play the role as women). We cast the best actors in the roles that they rightfully deserved.

Casting women as the two lovers was a happy accident, but also proves that the greatest love story ever told transends the limitations of sex, sexuality and gender. Love is love in all its forms.       

WE NEED YOUR HELP

We are doing this on a shoe-string budget (as we do most things). This is how our budget gets broken down:

  • Honorariums: $500
  • Sets: $150
  • Costumes: $310
  • Props: $50
  • Marketing: $300
  • Printing: $350
  • Misc: $100
  • TOTAL: $1,710

Our campaign goal on Indiegogo is set at $1000 since that is the minimum amount with which we could pull this production together. So, we come to you, our friends, family, peers, supporters and theatre enthusists. Your generousity will help us acchieve our funding goals and accomplish our artistic endevour.

THE IMPACT

We are proud of our track record of accomplishments.  When we decide to do something... it happens.  Follow-through is our speciality.  And Romeo and Juliet is no exception.  

Our rehearsal process has been incredibly exciting.  Supporting this project means you are also supporting a slew of incredibly talented and passionate emerging artists in Vancouver: recent graduates of both UBC and Studio 58.

Your contribution will also help to diversify the theatre scene in Vancouver.  The more quality theatre that is produced, the stronger our community becomes, the further we can push our mandate to diversify the artform.

But most of all, your contribution supports a project designed not for an indiviudal's or company's benefit. This project is designed to be a gift of free theatre.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We know what it's like to love something, to want to help something or someone out. But being artists, we also know what it's like to be broke... Have no fear.  

Want to help out?  Shoot us an email! Sometimes an hour of your time, or donating some of your skills can be worth more than any dollar amount.  We love meeting new people who share our values.

Most importantly, if you want to help out... COME OUT.  It's FREE, FUN, and FAST. Bring a blanket, your friends and your loved ones.  Tell your friends, post on facebook, share, like, tweet, tumbl, insta, snap etc!   

THANK YOU FOR YOUR TIME AND INTEREST IN OUR PROJECT!

For more information regarding Mnemonic Theatre, please visit

  • Our Website: www.mnemonictheatre.com

  • Our E-Magazine: www.theatreisforsuckers.com

  • Our Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Mnemonic-Theatre-Productions/140399789413646

  • Our YouTube Channel: http://www.youtube.com/user/mnemonictheatre

Most importantly, if you want to help out... COME OUT.  It's FREE, FUN, and FAST. Bring a blanket, your friends and your loved ones.  Tell your friends, post on facebook, share, like, tweet, tumbl, insta, snap etc!   
THANK YOU FOR YOUR TIME AND INTEREST IN OUR PROJECT!
For more information regarding Mnemonic Theatre, please visit


Our Website: www.mnemonictheatre.com


Our E-Magazine: www.theatreisforsuckers.com


Our Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Mnemonic-Theatre-Productions/140399789413646


Our YouTube Channel: http://www.youtube.com/user/mnemonictheatre

story:
Altru Young Actors are back again with their latest project - 'Missing?'

Based in Knowsley the group of 16-20 year olds are exploring what happens when someone goes missing and the lives of those left behind.  Performing in Liverpool in September the group have also have the opportunity to tour their show up to Scotland! 

We've been invited to perform at the National Festival of Youth Theatre in Fife in July. It's an amazing honour - we're one of only 13 young companies that will be taking part and we're the only organisation from the North West of England. We want to go and show Scotland the talent in the North West, and do our local community proud!

To get there we are fundraising - and you can be part of helping to make it happen!  All 14 young actors are working extremely hard to reach their goal. If you'd like to support us on this fantastic opportunity then every little helps! All donations go straight towards our trip to Scotland. You will be making 14 young people (and our community!) very happy!

We've set up some perks that you can claim with a big donation, but any donation at all will be gratefully received so please don't feel tied to donate £10! To help us get to Scotland -  every penny counts!

story:
"We congratulate Hudson Warehouse on their eleventh year presenting classics to the public in Riverside Park. We are thrilled that they have made their home with us and hope they will continue to enchant Riverside Park’s neighbors and all other guests with their theatrical mettle for years to come.”

             —Zhen Heinemann, the Director of Programming for Riverside Park, 2014


We are asking for $5,000 this year to help cover the costs of costumes, programs, publicity and the stipends to pay our  designers, directors, actors and production staff.


OUR 2014 SEASON

KING JOHN

By Wm. Shakespeare
Directed by Jerrod Bogard
Previews June 5th * Opens June 6th * Closes June 29th

The Importance of Being Earnest

By Oscar Wilde
Directed by Nicholas Martin-Smith
Previews July 3rd * Opens July 4th * Closes July 27th


The Winter’s Tale

By Wm. Shakespeare
Directed by Nicholas Martin-Smith
Previews July 31st  * Opens August 1st * Closes August 24th

story:
#MarishaGoGo: 
Hi, my name is Marisha Johnson and I am a recent graduate from The University of Iowa Department of Dance. I moved to New York to jumpstart my career as a choreographer, dancer, and arts administrator. This spring I have been selected to present my work at Blind Tiger at The Jack in Brooklyn and at Green Space Blooms Festival in Long Island City. My choreographic work is gaining momentum but I need your support! 

This is where you come in!
Renting dance space, paying dancers, purchasing costumes, & production are all  necessary costs in this incredible opportunity to build my career as a choreographer. Help me out by contributing to 3 different projects: a new work at Blind Tiger on Sunday, March 2nd, the New York City premiere of "discrepancies of self" at Green Space Blooms on Sunday, April 13th, and a future new project, which includes a creation of a new duet as well as application fees to future festivals. Please give #MarishaGoGo a shout out by sharing with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media platforms. 

About Me: 
As a dancer, choreographer, and arts promoter, I seek to communicate and engage the world through different media. I use my body, my movement & vision, and digital images & phrases to engage with others and create a dialogue of sharing. As a choreographer, I have a passion for exploring shared human experiences through movement. I want to use my choreography to investigate all the layers of these experiences to create dance that audiences can access and respond to. I moved to New York City to pursue these three passions. Currently, I am dancing on scholarship at Jennifer Muller/The Works and as a freelance dance artist, creating new works, and working for KEIGWIN+COMPANY as their Marketing Associate.

See My Full Bio Here!

A Heart Felt Thank You:
Thank you for investing in my work, my future and the dance community. You are giving me the resources to support my creative process, to have space to create movement, to compensate talented movers, and to continue to create & produce dance in hopes of inspiring others. There are no words to describe the gratefulness I feel in my heart for your support. I thank you for your deep generosity and support.

story:
We've hit our initial campaign Goal! Thank You! BUT, we need to keep going! 

We set our original goal at a modest $2500 to get us to the "Happy Days" opening night, so the production WILL HAPPEN, thanks to you!   But, we need more help to cover our full production costs through closing and assure our continued existence beyond this production of "Happy Days."  

Help us revive & continue Sledgehammer_ by contributing to our campaign now!

Read the San Diego Union Tribune's coverage here.


“...Sledgehammer is a verb.”

American Theater magazine cover story on “The Bad Boys of Sledgehammer Theater”

The Story

Sledgehammer Theatre was founded in 1985 by three UCSD graduates dissatisfied with the decrepit state of American theater at the time. Born to take a sledgehammer to conventional theater, the company earned a reputation for “creatively carving theater out of the void” (SD Theater Critics Special Award, 1987), doing site-specific work in abandoned warehouses, storefronts, and parking lots in and around pre-gentrified downtown San Diego.

In 1992 Sledgehammer landed its own 150-seat theater space, St. Cecilia’s Playhouse, and, jumping on the season programming treadmill, created over sixty productions of work ranging from imaginative deconstructions of the classics (Hamlet) to groundbreaking premieres of new American plays such as Charles Mee’s The War to End War, and original operas like The World Is Round, by Scott Feldsher and Pea Hicks.

In 2005 Sledgehammer was forced out of its theater as a result of new seismic regulations, affording the company an opportunity to return to its original mission of defying boundaries and creating one-off, interdisciplinary projects in surprising spaces, such as the multi-media art installation Beckett3 a collaboration conceived and written by Artistic Director Scott Feldsher, developed with sculptor Becky Gutten and composer Tim Root, and presented in a repurposed furniture warehouse.

After collaborating with Eveoke Dance Theatre and Jeff Cotta to open the new 10th Avenue Arts Center, Sledgehammer, like many groups, found rough sledding in the difficult economy and in 2008 took a hiatus to regroup, restructure, and recharge.  

With your help, this production of Happy Days, by Samuel Beckett, opening May 14 at the 10th Avenue Arts Center's Studio Theater, will mark the first production of Sledgehammer’s new era, sans “Theatre” in its name. Sledgehammer_  stakes our claim as an art-making, rather than exclusively a theater-making, organization.  

Our future work will take many forms, but we are starting off, with your help,  playing to our greatest strength: theatrical collaboration. Three longtime Sledgehammer_ collaborators, San Diego acting legend Dana Hooley, music legend Francis Thumm, and Sledgehammer Founding Artistic Director Scott Feldsher, will team up to bring a unique, funny and visually striking production to a new generation of San Diego audiences.  


Happy Days: A Vaudeville For the End Of Time


After the success of Waiting for Godot and Endgame, Samuel Beckett's wife requested he write something "happy," so he penned Happy Days. With its indelible image of Winnie buried to her waist in the earth, rummaging through her travel bag, reminiscing with her long suffering partner Willie, Beckett penned yet another haunting meditation on memory, time and love. His works are pure theater and defy conventional description. To see one is to contemplate the rarest of gems in the Western canon.

Of course, being Irish and a fan of the music hall and silent films, Beckett could not help but infuse his work with off-color gags, songs, and visual puns to enliven the proceedings. Luckily, off-color gags, songs, and visual puns are Sledgehammer_'s stock in trade!


"Sledgehammer gives [Samuel Beckett's] Endgame a more lasting image than JoAnne Akalaitis' at BAM [Brooklyn Academy of Music]."

Jan Breslauer, LA Weekly, 1988


What We Need & What You Get

We need your support to make this production happen! Every cent of your contribution will find its way directly onto the stage. We have no administrative costs in this budget; every dollar will go to a performer, a designer, a costume or a can of paint. It will all be in front of you! Our budget is small but, as always, our ambitions are huge. And, as always, we can only do it with your help!

What you get is the most valuable thing we can give you: FRESH ART. All gifts of $25 or more will receive tickets to the production. At higher levels of giving, your tax deductible contribution will give you access to the artists and other like-minded supporters at a special Post Show Reception and/or Our Sledgehammer Revival Meeting (Party) at 10th Avenue's roof-top terrace. 


The Impact

Currently, Sledgehammer is only a memory—and a dream to live again. We can't make this comeback without your support. For those of you who have already been sledgehammered, you know you are going to get some of the most powerful, beautiful and surprising art in Southern California. For those of you who have only heard of us, this is your chance to find out what all the fuss has been about for over 25 years.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word, share this campaign with your friends!
  • Like us on Facebook!
  • Follow us on Twitter (@sledgetheatre) and YouTube!
  • Come see our show!

All gifts of $25 or more will receive tickets to the production. We can't make this comeback without your support. For those of you who have already been sledgehammered, you know you are going to get some of the most powerful, beautiful and surprising art in Southern California. For those of you who have only heard of us, this is your chance to find out what all the fuss has been about for over 25 years.Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, share this campaign with your friends!


Like us on Facebook!


Follow us on Twitter (@sledgetheatre) and YouTube!

Come see our show!

story:
Storyline

Transformatique is a series of eight vignettes that each represents moments of personal transformation within a larger journey of growth, fulfillment, reconciliation, and a sense of integration in a broader collective. Based on a confessional short story and the paintings it inspired, the piece incorporates theater/performance, dance, movement, music, and visual art as it explores the ways in which life can be transformative, even in the simplest of moments.

Co-creators Greg Serebuoh & Travis Tyler Brimner bring you a story of conscious transformation from spiritual isolation to a heightened awareness of self.

Creating Work for NY Artistic Community

Although the creative process for this piece began over a year ago, Transformatique is buzzing with energy right now as we’re taking all of our ideas and breathing life into them. We have 8 incredible actors, a technical crew, and a creative team to pay, rehearsals to hold in rented rehearsal space, and costumes and sets to be dreamed up and brought to reality. The money we raise is going directly to those individuals and activities so that we can premiere this work that we are so excited about on December 4th at Dixon Place in Manhattan. This production directly supports the creative community of New York City.

The Difference Your Contribution Makes

One of the things that makes New York City an awe-inspiring, vibrant, and vital cultural mecca for people around the world is its incredibly broad creative offerings.  Most of us were drawn to New York City by the diverse spectrum of creative experiences for which it has always been known. Performance art, Off-Broadway theatrical works, and independent productions like Transformatique form an important part of that spectrum.  Without them, there would be a major dynamic missing in this magical city. Since we are not backed by big production companies, we look to art lovers and supporters to help us fund our project and share our creative vision.  This is the difference your contribution makes to our production and to New York City - it helps to keep the city’s diverse artistic spirit alive.

What’s Next?

We plan to use the premiere as a launching point for turning this production into a regularly running show. This will be no small feat, but we are enthusiastic about the piece and are dedicated to continuing to build it.

Other Ways YOU can Support

While this production directly supports the creative community of New York City, we understand if you just aren't able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't support us:

  • Please get the word out to your friends and communities - make some noise about our campaign!
  • You can share our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Visit the Dixon Place site (follow "Website" link below) and purchase tickets to the show!

Thank you for your time and your support!
Greg Serebuoh & Travis Tyler Brimner

story:
The FadaDance Youth Company is raising funds to attend the 2015 Dance and the Child International (daCi) conference in Copenhagen, Denmark from July 5-10, 2015.

The FadaDance Youth Company is made up of 30 kids ranging in age from 12-18 and are studying dance under Artistic Director Misty Wensel and FadaDancers Heather Cameron and Fran Gilboy.

I'm sure at this point you have a few questions.

“FadaDance? What's that?”

“FadaDance” means a few things. There's the FadaDance performing company, comprised of the three founding members of FadaDance (Misty, Heather and Fran). These three ladies have been performing together as FadaDance for 10 years and have become a vital piece of Regina's arts community.

FadaDance is also probably the coolest dance studio in Regina. With almost 325 students who range in age from 2-50, FadaDance encourages creativity and participation while still focussing on technique, flexibilty and discipline.

And, finally, the FadaDance Youth Company, 30 awesome kids who train at the studio, many of whom have attended previous daCi conferences and need your help.

For more information about FadaDance, look here: http://fadadance.ca/

It's not an easy or inexpensive thing to get 30 kids plus teachers and chaperones from the Canadian prairie to the north of Europe. All of the kids and parents are working very hard, fundraising for this trip. Those kids who have attended previous daCi conferences can (and will, if you let them) tell you what amazing experience meeting, learning from and dancing with kids from all over the world is. It's not just a dance education, it's an education education.

“DaCi? Explain, please.”

DaCi, or Dance and the Child International, is an international conference which happens every three years, each time in a very different part of the world. Our kids will have the opportunity to meet, learn from and dance with kids from every corner of the globe. They will perform work that they have helped create for an international audience of dancers, dance teachers and enthusiasts. It is, quite simply, the chance of a lifetime.

For more information about daCi and what they do, look here: www.daci.org

And for more information about the 2015 conference, look here: http://www.daci2015.dk/

“Is this the only thing you're doing to raise money?”

Of course not! The Fada community is a creative bunch of folks. We've done steak nights, bottle drives, flower sales, and arts camp, performances of ALL kinds, and have quite a few other things up our sleeves before we fly.

story:
Book by: Rick Kunzi & Justin Zeppa

Music by: Rick Kunzi & Adam Barnosky

Lyrics by: Rick Kunzi

"This ain't your great, great, great, Grand Pappy's kind of musical..."


What is BAYONETS OF ANGST?

BAYONETS OF ANGST is an original musical comedy set to a bluegrass soundtrack and narrated by the last remaining veterans of the American Civil War. These old codgers detail the behind the battlefield exploits of President Lincoln, the madness of General Tecumseh Sherman, and the pickled promiscuity of Gen. U.S. Grant, in a dizzying spell of events that changed the course of history.  And because they were the ones who was there - you just listen and hush up ‘bout it! 

BAYONETS OF ANGST is an Official Selection of the 2014 New York Musical Theatre Festival.  We will be putting up a full scale Off -Broadway production this July in New York City.  

Every dollar we raise with this campaign will go towards our production this summer at NYMF. Even the ones we find on the street...

How it came to be...

In 2005 Justin Zeppa and I shared a small cozy apartment in Astoria above the Grand Central Parkway.  We didn’t have cable nor internet just a bunch of cawfee, books and time on our hands.  Eventually, our creativity took over our boredom and we both started separate projects that would later define our futures.  I wrote my first musical BRUNCH that would go on to perform an Off-Broadway showcase and Justin wrote a screenplay called BAYONETS OF ANGST.  

Years later, Justin and decided to collaborate and bring BAYONETS OF ANGST to life by adapting it for the stage.  We then brought Adam in to put his musical stamp on the project and things began to take off.  In 2012 we were able to record our first demos with Ann Arbor, Michigan's finest Bluegrass band Wayward Roots and it was then that we realized the true potential of our project...

Join the Ranks!

BAYONETS OF ANGST is finally hitting an Off-Broadway stage and we could use all the fundraising help we can get! 

Putting up a show in NYC can be a pricey endeavor and we appreciate every dollar that comes our way.  With your generous financial support, we will be able to put together a top notch creative team full of Directors, Designers and Managers.  This will also allow us to fill our Cast and assemble our Bluegrass Band.  After that, your contribution will go towards our rehearsal space, costumes, lighting, sound and props. 

The New York Musical Theatre Festival takes pride in not only providing a launching pad for the next generation of musicals but also creating a developmental environment to nurture and ensure the continued vitality of America's greatest art form.  

In an age of theatre where it is more convenient to remake a movie into a musical or revive a show that’s been seen again and again, it’s refreshing to know that there are new and exciting musicals still being created for the in-satiated public.  By supporting BAYONETS OF ANGST- you’ll not only be supporting our show but also the ideal that we need to continue the progress of new works of young directors, playwrights and producers in an ever changing Broadway landscape.

To truly show how much we appreciate your support, we are offering a varied list of unique rewards that will not only make you a part of our BAYONETS OF ANGST regiment but you'll also be directly involved with the insides of our production - kind of like a spy... Yes, a spy...

Militaristic Exploits

After three years of rigorous readings and workshops, BAYONETS OF ANGST has grown in popularity and our army of supporters has swollen in numbers.  Last summer, a short excerpt of the show entitled BAYONETS OF ANGST: The Story of Lincoln and McClellan became a finalist at the Ken Davenport 10 min play festival and went on to perform at Davenport Theatrical Studios. 

Since then the creators of BOA have been nothing short of ecstatic on the momentum that has carried this show into this year's New York Musical Theatre Festival.

Our Commanding Team of... Commanders

RICK KUNZI (Book, Music and Lyrics) is a playwright, director, actor and lion-tamer (self-proclaimed).  His musicals and plays have appeared throughout New York, most notably “BRUNCH - The Musical” which played at the American Theatre of Actors as an Off-Broadway Showcase. He recently recorded his first album with cohort Adam Barnosky entitled “Kunzi & Barno - Just Hits,” soon to be released on iTunes.

ADAM BARNOSKY (Music) is a Boston based attorney and monthly business & legal contributor for Performer Magazine.  He is co-creator of “BRUNCH - The Musical” and credited with writing music for “BAYONETS OF ANGST.”  Other works include the co-creation of the musical “Welcome Week” and the newly recorded album “Kunzi & Barno - Just Hits” soon to be released on iTunes.

JUSTIN ZEPPA (Book) is a writer and musician who focuses on whimsical tales that charm you to the core.  He is a co-creator of “BAYONETS OF ANGST” as well as the author of the soon to be released Young Adult novel, “The Creeps.” A veteran musician, his latest stints being highlighted by such bands as “Flatfoot” and “The Roar.”

Sound the Buglers!

It takes a village to put up a show on a larger scale, so we could use all the help we can get on spreading the good word.  Share this campaign site with your friends and family via Facebook, Twitter, email or CAN ON A STRING!  We even recommend you shouting it from the ROOFTOPS!

Alas...

Please read the rewards carefully to determine those that are location or date specific, or subject to limited quantities. Specific event information will be posted at www.BayonetsOfAngst.com and you will contacted personally via email. We will not be able to change any date/time to fit individual schedules.

• Must be over 18 or accompanied by a parent or legal guardian to attend all events.
story_txt:
Book by: Rick Kunzi & Justin Zeppa
Music by: Rick Kunzi & Adam Barnosky
Lyrics by: Rick Kunzi
"This ain't your great, great, great, Grand Pappy's kind of musical..."
What is BAYONETS OF ANGST?BAYONETS OF ANGST is an original musical comedy set to a bluegrass soundtrack and narrated by the last remaining veterans of the American Civil War. These old codgers detail the behind the battlefield exploits of President Lincoln, the madness of General Tecumseh Sherman, and the pickled promiscuity of Gen. U.S. Grant, in a dizzying spell of events that changed the course of history.  And because they were the ones who was there - you just listen and hush up ‘bout it! 
BAYONETS OF ANGST is an Official Selection of the 2014 New York Musical Theatre Festival.  We will be putting up a full scale Off -Broadway production this July in New York City.  
Every dollar we raise with this campaign will go towards our production this summer at NYMF. Even the ones we find on the street...
How it came to be...

story:
FSM explores the 1964 Free Speech Movement at UC Berkeley as lived then and seen now by participants on all sides, just in time for its 50th anniversary.

Call it the anti-HAIR and the anti-BIG CHILL: these kids have haircuts and their later selves are not chilled – just older, maybe wiser or maybe a little world-weary.  FSM takes 60’s politics seriously.  It celebrates the joy, moral purpose, newborn freedom and occasional absurdity of being young, part of a movement and passionately political, from a distance that takes account of the consequences.

The show - produced by Stagebridge Senior Theatre - has had some great support from the Bay Area theatre community.  FSM was developed through a workshop at the 2013 Bay Area Playwrights Festival and the 2014 Ground Floor program at Berkeley Repertory Theatre, 

We've had help from the National Endowment for the Arts, The Rex Foundation, the East Bay Fund for Artists, Fleishhacker Foundation, The Mario Savio Memorial Fund of Tides Foundation, and Stephen M. Silberstein. But we're still short of what we need, so we're turning to you, dear friends: please help us bring the show to our community this Fall! Your donations help us support our team of talented artists.


Book by Joan Holden

Music & Lyrics by Bruce Barthol & Daniel Savio

Directed by Erin Merritt

Scrumbly Koldewyn, Musical Director 

Performances:

September 20 & 21 at Brava Theater Center in San Francisco 

September 27 & 28 at The Thrust Stage at Berkeley Repertory Theatre 

Tickets available at www.brownpapertickets.com.

For more information, visit www.stagebridge.org/fsm.

story:
*Hedwig In Montreal

"Help HIM Rise" An Introduction to our Performers:

YITZHAK ~ Peggy Hogan is a Montreal-based multi-disciplinary performing artist. Her practice is dedicated to expansion of genres and community building through lyrical and aesthetic content. Her two main projects, the three piece Peggy Hogan and the solo hip-hop Hua Li, explore themes of sexuality, race, feminism and interpersonal communication all the while maintaining a firm grasp on musicianship and tradition in her songwriting.

HEDWIG - Andrew Jamieson is the creator and Artistic Director of the House of Grizzly Andrews.  He is a Montreal-based artist, writer, performer. He Muses: “It is my passionate, personal and egocentric belief that our age is the apex of western civilization. I maintain that Art provides a virulent resistance to this decline, simply by instigating new questions."  Andrew's first book, "Tell Me No" will be available late 2014. 

The House of Grizzly Andrews is not a collective, rather a kingdom, a safe haven for the Artist, who may enjoy the benefit of both patronage and community.  The House, as an entity, generates revenue through creative projects in order to support the individual Artist, removing the need to spend countless, valuable hours on branding, marketing and financial planning. With the absence of these obstacles, Artists may create with freedom and focus.

What we are doing? 

We have a hand tweezer'd array of unparalleled individuals, beginning with a sassy  burlesque # via miss sugar shack herself Frenchie Jones, then an odd gentleman indeed who prefers to go by the work friendly and colloquially condensed alias, Popfucker... especially whilst prancing about about a shady room singing (reminiscent of Serge Gainsbourg). Then to induce a little spine-tingling & tendril tension, there's the pulse creeping, teeth gnashing monster mash musical rants of ¡FLIST! = Charlie Twitch is a producer, composer & visual artist operating out of Montreal, Qc. Twitch has had his work featured in Fantasia, Kino Mtl, Objet Sonore, Bouge d’Ici & Pop Montreal.

All of this leading up to the unveiling of HIM.  Simultaneously a performance and a ritual featuring songs from Hedwig & the Angry Inch with original material driving the show. A little shock and a little humanity, and a whole lot of entertainment.

What We Definitely Desire & What You May Require

The donations from the campaign are contributed to the production costs of mounting the show, such as the fees for the musicians and other artists involved in the production.  This includes hair (wigs!) and makeup, costumes, technical crew, as we have a full video element to the show itself & leading up to it. Any help from you also benefits our camera operators, who are making fresh content weekly to upload new footage of our rehearsals and catty banters. We'd love to be able to guarantee a few staff members on board to help with the technicalities of organizing all of the web elements we want to bring to you and keep our social media updated...  as well as help subsidize the cost of advertising; the flyers & posters, even the tickets.  


  • REMEMBER FOLKS - We're in this for your Support, any kind, so feel free to shout out, sing along with us, cry in our drinks, we'll hold your hair back in the bathroom as you tell us your Hedwig Stories, send us your verve & enthusiam in ANY way imaginable, this is the one time where it's the little things that counts
  • We won't shed any tears if we don't make our budget, but we're really hopeful that you'll stay with us as we prep to mount HIM @ the Wiggle Room.

What a difference an Inch can Make to HIM...

  • We've been involved with a few other campaigns in the past, from graphic novels to cd launches, to operas... & this has got to take the INCH on the cake, it's a psychosexual melodrama with a 4 part harmony that the audience can sing along to... 

Other Ways You Can Help HIM Out? 

  • Get the word out on the streets and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Don't forget: use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the news to your people.
  • and remember...   EVERY LITTLE INCH HELPS!

story:
Our Mission:

Have you ever been made fun of for being who you are?

Our goal is to bring awareness to the current epidemic of bullying, hate crimes and suicide that is running rampant amongst young people. In addition to other fundraising opportunities, if we meet our fundraising goal we will be able to donate an entire night's worth of ticket profits to Bully-Free Florida Network. Fundraising and awareness efforts to support this cause will be intertwined with our show.

Utilizing iconic characters that we all know and love, our staging aims to push the boundaries of social identification. Through CB’s existential journey, we put the audience back into the uncomfortable stage of teenage adolescence. Utilizing realistic dialogue, circumstances and peer pressure, audience members revisit the awkward phases of figuring out who they are and who they want to be vs. who everyone else tells them they should be. We're not all “written”  to be a certain way. Our production challenges what others think of us in an effort to be the best version of ourselves, even in the face of adversity, all in an attempt to become a little less... predictable.

By funding our show you are not only supporting local arts you are standing up for everyone who has been bullied, pushed-around and put down. We are a local production, striving to provide community art and entertainment that has a heart and a message. We showcase talented young people aspiring to follow their dreams through the performing arts.

 

Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead

Written by Bert V. Royal
Directed and Produced by Devon D. Lucia
Produced by Hi Eugene Productions

DOG SEES GOD has not been authorized or approved in any manner by the
Charles M. Schulz Estate or United Features Syndicate,
which have no responsibility for its content.

Performance Information:
March 14 - 16 at 7:00 p.m. and March 16 at 2:00 p.m.
The Venue - 511 Virginia Dr., Orlando, FL 32803

Dramatist Overview - This show is not recommended for children:

"When CB's dog dies from rabies, CB begins to question the existence of an afterlife. His best friend is too burnt out to provide any coherent speculation; his sister has gone goth; his ex-girlfriend has recently been institutionalized; and his other friends
are too inebriated to give him any sort of solace. But a chance meeting with an
artistic kid, the target of this group's bullying, offers CB a peace of mind and
sets in motion a friendship that will push teen angst to the very limits. Drug
use, suicide, eating disorders, teen violence, rebellion and sexual identity
collide and careen toward an ending that's both haunting and hopeful."

-Dramatists
Play Service, Inc.

Our Company:

CB - Matthew Hughes
Beethoven - Isaac Bannasch
CB's Sister - Jordan Irvine
Van - Jonathan Jimenez
Van's Sister - Dannon Lucia
Matt - Adam Ressa
Tricia - Christina Carmona
Marcy - Lindsay Taylor

Our Team:

Director & Producer - Devon D. Lucia
Assistant Director – Brian Gutierrez
Executive Producer – Dannon Lucia
Production Manager – Heather Mowad
Communications Manager – Steven Calamusa
Event Manager – Chris Meushaw
Graphic and Set Designer – Samantha Sanders
Set Construction - Dan Mende
