story:
This all started with a trip to see the children's pantomime "Aladdin" with my little boy one Christmas. We had such fun and I walked out of there inspired to write my own "panto" - but one with a Canadian theme. And I did. 

The result was "The Million Dollar Shot" - the story of a young Vancouver boy, Bobby Orr Finn,  who loves hockey, and enters an essay contest on why your mom is the best hockey mom. Bobby's essay is chosen as the best, and he wins a trip to Toronto to watch the Leafs battle the Canucks. His prize includes an opportunity to shoot the puck from centre ice at intermission... for a million dollars. 

The catch? Bobby is being raised by a caring yet comical single dad, who was the inspiration for Bobby's hockey "mom" essay. But it is not until they reach the airport that they discover, according to contest rules, the winner must be accompanied by... his mom. 

It's a good thing dad packed a dress. 

Hilarity ensues as Bobby and his dad attend the NHL game all while trying to keep their secret that "mom" is really Bobby's dad so Bobby can indeed have his Million Dollar Shot. 

Now, I am no song writer. But I could not ignore the fact that traditional British pantomimes include songs.  The Million Dollar Shot, therefore, includes song. One song. Entitled "This Is Not a Musical".  I enlisted the help of fabulous singer-songwriter Camille Miller (http://camillemillermusic.blogspot.ca) who produced a song far beyond my expectations. 

Finally, I have chosen a special date for the premiere of The Million Dollar Shot. February 14th, 2015 is "Hockey Day in Canada" - a special day celebrating hockey, community, and family across this country and a fitting time to unveil this special project.  I hope you can share in it and help make it happen. 

Clive Scarff,

Writer, The Million Dollar Shot

story:
Who is Spark?

Spark is a new theatre ensemble committed to sharing the complexities and richness of language through performance and workshops while making the work resonate with a new audience - finding our truth in the text.

As well as developing an open door policy for students and the wider community giving them the opportunity to join us for rehearsal, workshops and training sessions, we want to give creatives an opportunity to keep building skills with training and an in depth rehearsal process.

We are passionate about education and inspiring young people to recognise all the skills they have within themselves and at their disposal so we are also developing an education program to aid with the current Literature and Theatre studies curriculum. 

We are very excited about the team we have gathered for our first production including Sarah Brett as producer, Perri Cummings as director, Kristina Benton as musical director, Anna Boulic as voice coach, Felicity Steel as combat coach, recent VCA graduate Jaz Tweeddale as our designer and a talented Melbourne cast of 14. Together our production team have extensive experience in creating and producing theatre locally and around the world.

All cast and crew are volunteering their time to create a fresh take on this witty classic, drawing from our own experiences to create a fast and funny production that speaks to a new audience. 

The production with be stripped right back, concentrating of the story and the relationships but we still need a performance and rehearsal venue, costumes, lighting, props, publicity material and the materials for our education program. Any donation, big or small is greatly appreciated and will go directly toward the costs of putting on this production.

With your generous help we will be able to stage this production and create a high quality experience for all audience members, helping us gain the momentum to build a company dedicated to enhancing skills for both professional creatives and for the community while producing fun and thought provoking theatre shows that push the envelope.

And if anyone is interested in the company and what we have planned, please visit the website where you can contact us, we are very interested in hearing from you! 

http://sparktheatre.weebly.com

 

What We Need & What You Get

Where the money will be going and what you will receive:

  • rehearsal venue $950
  • theatre hire $900
  • costumes and props $980
  • lighting and chair hire $500
  • festival fees  $380
  • workshop expenses $600
  • posters, printing and admin $350

You will receive

  • We have an exciting range of workshops on offer for students
  • Access to our professional development workshops for actors and creatives
  • Beautiful rehearsal images taken my Sasha Bradbury
  • Tickets to our show
  • Subscriptions to our 2015 season
  • Become part of our community, on line, in rehearsal, workshops and social media
  • Extensive gratitude from our team
If we don't reach our entire goal the funds will go towards putting on the play As You Like It this year.  Venue hire is our most important expense. It will mean however we may not be able to continue with as many workshops or as much of the education program as we would like to offer.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that not everyone is able to contribute financially but there are many other ways you can:

    • Join our Facebook page and tell all your friends about us 
      • www.facebook.com/sparktheatrecompany
    • Follow us on Tumblr and share our videos and messages 
      • https://www.tumblr.com/blog/sparktheatreco
    • TELL EVERYONE YOU KNOW
    • Come to the show and make sure to say hello to us, we'd love to meet you.
    • Come to rehearsals and get involved with all our community events (to be advertised on our website 
      • http://sparktheatre.weebly.com

    • Use the indiegogo share tool and share our campaign with as many people as possible
    • Send us a message through our website or Facebook letting us know what you think!

Who is Spark?


Spark is a new theatre ensemble committed to
sharing the complexities and richness of language through performance and
workshops while making the work resonate with a new audience - finding our
truth in the text. 
As well as developing an open door policy for
students and the wider community giving them the opportunity to join us for
rehearsal, workshops and training sessions, we want to give creatives an
opportunity to keep building
skills with training and an in depth rehearsal process.

We are passionate about education and inspiring
young people to recognise all the skills they have within themselves and at
their disposal so we are also developing an education program to aid with the current Literature and Theatre studies curriculum. 

We are very excited about the team we have
gathered for our first production including Sarah Brett as producer, Perri Cummings as
director, Kristina Benton as musical director, Anna Boulic as voice coach,
Felicity Steel as combat coach, recent VCA graduate Jaz Tweeddale as our
designer and a talented Melbourne cast of 14.

story:
Doctor by Seth Klusmire

Doctor is an original play written by a student, put on in the community in collaboration with alumni. It's not something that's been done before in the CSU theater community, and it provides the chance to experience theater in a new environment not only for audiences, but the cast and crew of the production of Doctor.

The show will be playing May 7th-10th at 7:00pm at the 

Community Creative Center in downtown Fort Collins, CO.

"I have been working on this play since freshman year of college and I have always dreamed of staging it. The idea came to me my junior year of high school while I was in the hospital for 2 months recovering from abdominal surgery. I felt as if I was losing my mind during my time there and I wanted to focus that feeling toward something positive and creative instead of it looming in my head. I am fortunate to have found such fantastic people who have taken an interest in this play."- Seth Klusmire

Synopsis

In 1955, a woman named Lory at Agnew's State Mental Hospital in San Jose, California needed a operation to save her sanity and will only allow her husband, Dr. Ivan Ivanovich, to perform the dangerous procedure. The story is told through Lory's memories and through Jazz musician Cab Calloway. As her thoughts and feelings begin to distort, and with the looming procedure coming closer and closer, no one is as they seem.

Why We Care

The production will be taking place in May, Mental Health Awareness Month, and the students involved with this production of Doctor would like to show our support.

Mental health issues are on the rise on college campuses across the country. Better and accessible screenings as well as earlier diagnosis of mental health conditions are critical to getting quality treatment and improving one's quality of life. This has allowed more students with mental health conditions to go on to college and be successful. Everyone involved in Doctor is passionate about supporting treatment and awareness of mental health diseases, especially on college campuses.  

All proceeds of the production will be donated to Mental Health America and the National Alliance on Mental Illness if we are able to reach our goal!

Tickets

Performances will be in The Carnegie Building- Beet Street and tickets are FREE! They can be pre-ordered at http://doctor.brownpapertickets.com or at the door if shows are not sold out. Donations will also be accepted at the time of the show.

Cast

Lory Sanderson: Lily Bolduc

Ivan Ivanovich: Tim Werth

Clint Verlust: Clint Pendley

Smith Sanderson: Karl Perry

Donny Richardson: Tucker Lehman

Brenda Richardson: Megan Chambers

Smokey Joe: Mitchell Dow

Nurses: Taryn Gawronski, Emma Kimball, Emana Lukac, and Kaylee Wieczorek

Crew

Director: Roger Miller 

Scenic Design/ Stage Management: Amy Garland

Lighting Design: Andy Killion

Sound Design: Emma Kimball

Costumes/Make up Design: Vicky Arias

Projections Design: John Erickson

Public Relations/Production Manager: Emma Schenkenberger

For more information on the cast and crew as well as other aspects of the production such as Cab Calloway and the Agnew's State Mental Institution please visit our website!  http://www.doctorproduction.squarespace.com/

story:
Brelby Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non‐profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Brelby Theatre Company must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax‐deductible to the extent permitted by law


Brelby Theatre Company Nurtures New Works/Artists

Brelby Theatre may be a relative newcomer to the Phoenix metro’s West Valley, but we have established ourselves as a vital member of the theatre community and an incubator for new works. Since moving into our new studio  in the heart of downtown Glendale, Brelby has produced two world premiere musicals, six world premiere plays as part of our “Studio Series” and an original holiday show written by Brian and Shelby Maticic, founders of Brelby, and Luke Gomez. We are also making a name for ourselves cultivating the future of art in Arizona by providing high quality classes and workshops for all ages in a wide range of theatre disciplines.  Brelby is ready and poised to take the next step as we grow, increasing production value, reaching a wider audience, providing more opportunities for working artists, and expanding our classes, but we need your help to improve the vitality of the arts in the west valley!


What we need and what you get

We need to raise $10,000 this spring to fund our spring and summer productions and classes. We hope to raise $5,000 of that from our IndieGoGo supporters, but of course more would be very helpful and appreciated.

Your donation will help further our mission of encouraging playwrights, composers, and collaborative artists to bring new works to life. Beyond new works,your donation helps provide education and training for children, teens and adults in performance, playwrighting, improv, and technical theatre and design.

To show our appreciation of your generosity, we will be offering some lovely, splendid, and amazing perks including: the warm fuzzy feeling of supporting the arts and small business, a wink and a smile, hugs, Brelby swag, free tickets, program mentions and much more!

The Impact

More than just an opportunity to perform, artists need a place to grow. Actors need experiences that push them to be better, Directors need a chance to develop their skills, and new playwrights need someone willing to take a chance on them in order to get their debut production. Brelby is a place where all that happens, and the West Valley- even the entire Phoenix metro area- needs a place where the performing arts can not just exist, but be nurtured.

Help us to keep this unique company on track to develop and showcase new works, while offering quality performances of the classics and contemporary theatre.

Other Ways you can help:

No amount is too small (or too big!), but we understand that making a donation is not possible for everyone. You can still be a huge help to us by simply spreading the word about our campaign and sharing our video on Facebook and Twitter. You can use the IndieGoGo share tools to make this easier. And check out our website to learn more about our company, members, workshops and productions: www.brelby.com . You can also follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube. Thanks!


Thank you for your support!

story:
Background

Zarzuela is not just a delicious Catalonian seafood stew. It is also the name for Spain's operetta tradition. It alternates between music and dialogue, and usually has several dance numbers. It is heavily influenced by Spanish folkloric styles. Zarzuela is very popular in Spain and other Latin American countries, but has been mostly unknown in the United States. Thanks to the efforts of famed singer Plácido Domingo, zarzuela has recently raised curiosity and gained recognition in the U.S., especially in cities like L.A. and Miami. Like Mr. Domingo, I find zarzuela to be a marvelous art form that needs to be performed more often in the U.S., which has led me here to this campaign.

The Show

I am collaborating with Main Street Opera and Casa Italia Italian Cultural Institute of Chicago in producing our very first zarzuela, "La Dolorosa", by José Serrano. Zarzuela is rarely performed in Chicago, and this will be the Chicago premiere of "La Dolorosa."

In "La Dolorosa", Rafael, a novice monk, secludes himself in a monastery after being disappointed in love. There, he comes across the woman that he once loved and undergoes a terrible spiritual struggle between duty and love  Serrano's work is an excellent example of zarzuela at its eclectic best. It has drama, comedy, dance and romance - all in a neat one hour package. It is a show that can be enjoyed by anyone- one of zarzuela's great qualities.

Furthermore, what makes our show so special is that it is perhaps one of the only, if not the only, zarzuela performed in Chicago in the original Spanish language. By honoring the original language, we have kept the witty libretto by Juan José Lorente intact. We have also catered this to a Spanish speaking audience, a community that is a very present entity in Chicago. Non-Spanish speakers can still enjoy the show as there will be English supertitles. The shows will be August 22nd at Casa Italia and September 19th at the Cervantes Institute.

The Campaign

We need to fund raise $500 for this production. We have already paid for cast, crew, music, royalties, and promotional materials. We now need extra funds to purchase costumes (monk robes, shoes, aprons, etc), props (easel, paint, chairs, etc), and set pieces (shrubbery, desk, etc.) 

Our deadline for the campaign is August 9th, but we urge folks to contribute as soon as they can so that we have time to purchase these items as soon as possible before our first show. If you cannot contribute, please reach out and spread the news about this campaign to 5-10 of your contacts. Let them know to do the same so that we can reach many people. 

Not only are you helping Chicago's arts community by contributing, you are also giving young talented performers a chance to show their stuff, an opportunity that is becoming rarer in Chicago because of the financial crisis. Plus you can also qualify for one of our nifty perk awards!

To hear more about this show and this campaign, check out the video above!

 Adios y gracias!

story:
PAST SERIES: 4th Potpourri World Women's Work, The Drama Book Shop NY-

POTPOURRI # 5 - CALENDAR OF EVENTS




Dear Friend to the Arts!

Kim Weston-Moran/RHYTHMCOLOR Associates, Voza Rivers/ New Heritage Theatre Group, The Drama Book Shop, ICA/Dwyer Cultural Center, Medgar Evers College and Tekoa Hash will present the 5th POTPOURRI! World Women Works Series. The Series opens Monday, March 10th and runs through Sunday, March 30, 2014, at various venues around New York City in celebration of International Women’s Month.

We are requesting your financial assistance to help cover costs for Honorariums for approximately 45 Performing Artists, the Administrative Team, 8 Directors, 4 Stage Managers, 3 Dramaturges, 2 Technicians, duplication of scripts, Press & Marketing Materials and the Series Program. Total expenses are projected at $17,177.  A budget has been attached for your review. The Series will continue to be presented under the tax-exempt umbrella of the New Heritage Theatre Group, Inc. and contributions are tax-deductible in accordance with NY State law.

This opportunity allows you to participate in the creative process and development of new cutting edge works by making a difference from the ground up.  Today, it is so important for the arts community to partner with each other as well as the business, civic and educational communities. Culturally diverse expression is an inspiration which fuels and propels growth in society, on many levels; as well as transforms energy. POTPOURRI! World Women Works Series is our contribution to a balanced marketplace

We invite you to collaborate with us by donating to our Indiegogo Campaign. Deadline for Camera Ready Artwork is March 3, 2014.  Poster and DVD Perks shall be mailed by April 30, 2014.

Your support makes a difference between a writer being able to develop and showcase new works or not.

Thanking you in advance for your consideration and participation.

Sincerely,

Kim

-------------------------------------------------


The mission of POTPOURRI! World Women Works Series is

  1. to highlight the collective links and bonds of women globally and to build cross-cultural understanding through theatre-arts;

  2. to offer a supportive professional environment to develop, nurture and give voice to new works by women playwrights; and

  3. to develop audience by including the community in aspects of the creative process to open dialogue and foster critical thinking.


Each writer will have the opportunity to work with a professional director, actors and receive group feedback and individual mentoring. Writers will be coupled with a dramaturge who will also moderate a Q&A directly following each reading. The audience participation is an invaluable tool in this process.

_______________________________

 
POTPOURRI! 
Five Months [11/2013 - 4/2014		 BUDGET
   
EXPENSES PROJECTED ($)
   
Administrative/Clerical                   6,000
Honorariums [Readings]                   2,525
Actors [40 @ $25.00]                   1,525
Directors [7 @ $50.00                      450
   & 1 @ $100.00]
Stage Managers [8 @ $25.00]                      200
Dramaturgy                      350
Office Supplies.                      220
Color Print Cartridges (3)                      210
Paper                        10
PRINTING
Scripts (40 @ $5.00)                      200
Cards/Posters                      400
Festival Program Book [1,000]                       800
Postage                        37
Graphic DESIGNER                      250
VIDEOGRAPHY [Taping & Editing]                   1,100
SPACE RENTAL                      600
RECEPTIONS (3 x $200]                      600
   
TELEPHONE [cell]  [Dec 2013 - April 2014]                      300  
INTERNET [Nov 2013 - April 2014]                      200  
WEBSITE Create/ Update / Maint.                      900  
   
MISC – Transportation /                      300  
             Unexpected Expenses  
TOTAL                 17,177  

RHYTHMCOLOR Associates  is a creative service company which looks forward to utilizing its innovative visions to build an organization with you that will present works that transform people, nurture artists, be a bridge to the community, by engaging them in the creative process and inspire critical thinking and conversation. RHYTHMCOLOR Associates supports the performing and visual arts with a focus on Women and Black Arts.

thinking and conversation. RHYTHMCOLOR Associates supports the performing and visual arts with a focus on Women and Black

story:
Story

★★★★★ "Physical Theatre at its finest. Unmissable!...The hairs on the back of my neck, all the way down my spine and along my arms stood straight up” Everything Theatre.

Ephemeral Ensemble is an international physical theatre company. Combining the skilled physicality of the performers, playful stage craft and original music, Ephemeral Ensemble strives to create original, sincere and ambitious work that is inspired by human stories.Corporeal mime technique is at the centre of our devising process. We seek harmony on the stage that comes from varied voices from different backgrounds during our process. The ensemble was founded in 2016 by Eyglo Belafonte and Ramon Ayres.

OFFSTAGE responds to the subject suicide, which is often hidden behind the curtain in public life, not being treated with the respect that it deserves. A subject surrounded by stigma that usually enables people to talk openly about it, and to recognise and respond to suicidal behaviour. Using onstage and backstage as a metaphor for public and private lives, OFFSTAGE takes a look behind the curtain at loneliness and depression in a sensitive and timely  exploration of suicide. In a universe, where theatre is life and life is a dream we find two performers, Harley and Pedro. We capture their joys when they are onstage, facing the public with masks, hats and a beautiful smile on their faces. Out of the spotlight however, the mask comes off and they face their struggles. They do whatever they can to help each other through their show night after night.
We interviewed those affected by suicide. People who have had contemplated suicide, suffering alone with thoughts or feelings of hopelessness. We also spoke to people, who went through the heartbreak of losing a loved one to suicide. 
Ultimately, our piece is about the fragility of life and the loneliness of those who suffer alone.

After the success of the rough first outing of the show, we have been given the opportunity to take OFFSTAGE to Edinburgh, where we'll be able to showcase it in the best possible environment with a daily slot at the prestigious PLEASANCE THEATRE. The donations gathered through this site will help us with our accommodation in Edinburgh, transportation of the team and set as well as our marketing during the Fringe Festival.
 

@ephemeralens | Insta: ephemeral_ensemble | www.ephemeralensemble.com

 

Support so far 

Funded by Arts Council England through Grant for the Arts

Supported by :

PAPYRUS -  Prevention of Young Suicide
L.A.S - Life After Suicide
SOAS Social Anthropology professor David Mosse
Pleasance Theatre
Haringey Council

 

What we need

This campaign's goal is a crowdfunding contribution towards our total fundraising target. We have already raised money in other ways, as well as putting money in ourselves.
We want to leave the impact of our work with the audience and show the work to as many people as possible, sharing the subject of suicide sensitively with the respect it deserves. 
The financial support will help us to take the work to the festival where the work will grow in quality and visibility.

Your contribution will go towards:

ACCOMODATION:
It’s a long way from home so we need somewhere to rest and keep warm during those long (and famously wet!) Scottish Summer nights. Your contributions will help us pay for a  base for our team during the run.

MARKETING AND PR: 
With over 3,000 other shows going on at Fringe, marketing and PR are key to raising awareness and standing out from the crowd during the Fringe. The money you donate will go towards registration fees, advertising, posters and flyers helping us to build a strong presence.

TRAVEL: 
There are over 400 miles between London and Edinburgh, money raised will help pay for the train fares of company members, as well as transportation for our set.

 

Any help you can give, however big or small, is incredible and helps this production to make a difference in the festival. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the message by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and any other person, who could possibly help. As well as promoting our shows through word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and any other way you can possibly think of!

Similarly, if you have any other resources that you feel could help us, please get in touch. Contributions in all forms are valued!

Thank you so much for reading this and please do come to see the show. Tickets are on sale now at https://www.pleasance.co.uk/event/offstage/performances

 

Much love,

 

Ephemeral Ensemble

#Offstage

story:
The Story of an Author and the Work

Greetings and good tidings dear viewers!

Back when I was performing “Romeo & Juliet” during my time at Salt Lake Community College, I was struck by a novel idea: what if you replaced Romeo with Hamlet?

The more and more I worked on this story the more and more I knew it was a story worth telling. After spending YEARS working on the script I am utterly confidant that this is the project that will proves my worth as a writer and director to the world. “The Romance of Wind & Fire” is a dramatic romance unlike any you have seen before! Watch how these timeless characters and timeless tale change from how the world knows them so well.

Our Goals

There are a couple levels to this:

  • Raise the $1200 necessary to fund the project for the festival performances.
  • Generate enough positive buzz to parlay that into a viable interest in seeing the full 5 act stageplay produced following our initial performance on our festival run.
  • Have a successful and strong fundraising campaign to encourage future fundraising efforts. The more we can raise the better footing we will have moving forward.

The Impact

This might be the pivotal moment of several aspiring careers here..

  • A success here will be the stepping stone to much grander things.
  • Tis not an understatement to call this my life’s passion.
  • you will never see this story in the same way again

Roll of the Dice

As with all art, it’s a roll of the dice. Let us prove to you, and the world, that we know how to come out ahead.

  • We have the passion, the focus, the determination, and the talent to see it done.
  • There is not much financial benefit from being our benefactor...at the present moment, but this is not our ultimate end goal. Join our efforts now and be remembered when do shine.

How to Help

There’s more ways to contribute than just money:

  • Like and share our posts on social media.
  • Spread a good word to your friends and family
  • support of fellow artist by attending other shows at the Great Salt Lake Fringe Festival!

story:
Who We Are

Waspish Theatre Company was set up in 2018 by an all-female creative team, each with a passion to give a voice to the vulnerable. 'Ideology and Hair Gel', written by Lizzie Corscaden and directed by Bethany-Ann Wilkinson, is Waspish Theatre's first full-length production, and examines the effects of political turmoil on the young and powerless.

The Edinburgh Fringe is the perfect place to showcase this politically-charged piece and launch Waspish Theatre into the spotlight, so that we can continue to give a voice to the unheard.

'If I be waspish, best beware my sting'- The Taming of the Shrew by William Shakespeare

What We Need & What You Get

While the Edinburgh Fringe is the perfect place to showcase new work, it is also expensive. Your money will go towards registration fees, accommodation, venue hire, sets, props, costumes and much much more. We believe that theatre has the power to create positive change, and even the smallest donation will go along way towards making that happen.

But there are benefits for you too! By donating, you could get anything from a social media shout out, to free tickets for the show, or even your own personalised photobook, signed by the entire cast and crew! Check out our perks for more details.

Meet the Waspish Team

Artistic Director - Bethany-Ann Wilkinson is a director from Royal Holloway University, in her final year of studies. Bethany-Ann’s credits as a director include Shakespeare’s King Lear, Measure For Measure, A Midsummer Nightmare and The Nether by Jenifer Haley. Bethany enjoys creating moments of theatre out of everyday objects such as torches and sheets; having already workshopped some light play, she is extremely excited for audiences to experience what our workshop cast have created.  She is also interested in creating feminist, political theatre and so is extremely excited to take on the challenges of Ideology and Hair Gel. The play has some wonderful moments that emphasise the integrity and vulnerability that young women possess in a changing world. She can’t wait for you to watch this brilliant play!

Associate Playwright - Lizzie Corscaden had her first play produced in 2007, when she was only twelve years old (it was about an irritating donkey). Since then, she has written and worked on many pieces for the theatre, as well as training at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama and becoming a published author of short fiction. Much of her work explores themes of mental health and wellbeing, and the effects of society upon the vulnerable. The idea for Ideology and Hair Gel first came to Lizzie seven years ago, and is based on a number of true stories that she has been aching to share with the world. Lizzie is thrilled to be working with the Waspish team on this production, and can't wait to see where Bethany-Ann's vision takes it.

Creative Development Manager - Eleanor Rutter has past experience in directing, dramaturgy, producing, stage management and deputy stage management. Between the ages of four and eighteen she was a performer, with her interest in theatre beginning when she was four years old as a ballet and contemporary dancer. Her main interests in theatre are early modern drama, British and American contemporary dance and drama, musical theatre and poetry in performance. She loves Ideology and Hair Gel because it is a wonderful blend of history and drama. This production is important to her as it will be her first professional production outside of an amateur or university environment.

Technical Manager - Emily Wilkinson has previously worked as both a stage manger and deputy stage manager, but is particularly excited to be taking a show to the Edinburgh Fringe for the very first time. Ideology and Hair Gel  has an interesting concept and Emily has enjoyed seeing it come to life through research and development workshops. She can’t wait to see what it will become.

Company Producer - Eleanor Ball has previously worked with York Theatre Royal to direct and produce her first short film, and has experience in performance, directing, stage management and deputy stage management. This has included working with Ealing Studios and Pilot Theatre, where she first experienced political theatre performing in ‘Everything is Possible: The York Suffragettes’. Her interest mainly lies in the relationship between historical politics and theatre and is loving exploring the dynamic present in Ideology and Hair Gel. She is excited to expand her knowledge of theatre-making and travel to Edinburgh with the Waspish Team.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Here at Waspish Theatre we understand that a financial contribution isn't a viable option for everyone. But you can still support this project! Why not try one of the options below?

  • Share this page with your friends and family!
  • Follow us on: Facebook - Twitter - Instagram
  • Pop along to one of our fundraising events (See our social media pages for details)
  • Come and see the show, and bring everyone you know!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page with your friends and family!
Follow us on: Facebook - Twitter - Instagram

Pop along to one of our fundraising events (See our social media pages for details)
Come and see the show, and bring everyone you know!

story:
WHAT WE BELIEVE & WHY: We believe that there is nothing more vital to our evolution than inspiration.  It is what fuels man kind to acheive the miraculous and to break boundries.

Wilderbe is inspired to lift the veils of this stagnant reality and to remind people that this world is malleable. That we have the power and courage to create the realities that we wish. That the hologram that we live in, we can shift into our greatest dreams, presenting the existing notion of alchemy…of magic…of bewilderment.

WHAT WE DO: Wilderbe is a Los Angeles Based theater company that uses bleeding edge technolog, digital art, live performance and music to create unbelievable and surreal worlds that unfold before your very eyes.

WHAT WE AIM TO DO: Currently we have the available technology to have digital art and live humans interact in a 3 dimensional space. Where real people can dance with 3D projection imaged faeries.  Where surreal worlds are not bound to screens and where art can live in a 3 dimensional space, with a life of it's own, moving in real time with humans. We are creating a hybrid between theater, movies and video games and working to have them all live together on the same plane.  Where we can create virtual portals on earth...completely immersing you into a fantasy world.

WHAT WE NEED:
In order to master this fusion between different mediums of art, we need to be able to research and develop these technologies.  We have HOW to do it and we have all the right members in place to make it a brilliant new take on entertainment.

What we don't have, are the materials it takes to develop the concepts to best showcase this technology.

Materials

  • (2) 12k projectors @ $14,000 each
  • (1) Screen @ $2,000

We know it's a lot and it's scary trying to find that much money! But we believe in this project. We believe that it will change entertainment and that we can shift reality by creating virtual portals!

Any extra money will go to finding a studio space and paying our hard working artists!!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please spread the word! These are tax deductible donations. Please share it with corporations and businesses! Thank you :)

story:
THE FIVE

CHARMING, FABULOUS, SULTRY, WITTY, NAUGHTY.

The Five invite you to an intimate night of glamour and performance.

The Five is a unique group of performers collaborating for the first time in New York City where they are planning a series of concerts during September 2013.  

The Five met while touring worldwide with the renowned KOOZA by Cirque du Soleil.  Finally, they are reuniting to create a reimagined Rat Pack with a modern twist. This group of talented performers will entertain the night away with song, dance and comedy.  Each will represent their very own distinct presence, personality, and talent. 

All performances will feature special surprises and a +1 (celebrity guest performer).

Where do your donations go?

Putting together a show is difficult, yet energizing and inspiring.  The Five are coming from the four corners of the Earth to rendezvous in New York City.  Here's your chance to be a part of it all.  Why donate?  These five artists know how to do a show, and do it well.

Our official updates will keep you informed of our progress during the creation process.

Your donations will help us create:

  • Our exquisite performance venue
  • Breathtaking costumes
  • Lush musical accompaniment
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Programs
  • Lighting/Sound
  • Production
  • PR
  • To make the night unforgettable and everything it's meant to be.

  

Paying It Forward

The Five's performances will not only be memorable evenings of class and splendor - but will make a significant impact in benefiting those in need.  A portion of the proceeds will go to benefit the following charities:

  • The Phyllis Newman Women's Health Intiative of The Actor's Fund
  • charity: water

 

Who are THE FIVE?

Jason Berrent  -  Charming.

Mr. Berrent, a native of Washington, D.C., is an American actor and producer best known for his work with the world-renowned Cirque du Soleil.

Mr. Berrent has toured internationally with Cirque du Soleil for 8 years, beginning in 2003 with Alegría.  In 2006, Jason's talents were discovered by writer and director David Shiner (Tony Award winner for Broadway’s Full Moon). Shiner invited Berrent to create the lead role of ‘The Trickster’ in Cirque du Soleil's multi-million dollar spectacle, KOOZA.  The character quickly became a Cirque favorite amongst fans and artists alike.  Jason received stellar reviews for his performance which can be seen on the live DVD recording of the show.

Other stage appearances include Nicky Silver’s Fit To Be Tied (Los Angeles), The Cohen Project (San Francisco) and Alegría by Cirque du Soleil (Int'l Tour).  Jason has appeared in commercials and ads for Adidas Originals, The Sundance Channel, Beatles Rockband, xBox Dance Central and Infiniti Motors.

Earlier this year, Mr. Berrent completed his second run with Cirque du Soleil's Kooza at The Royal Albert Hall in London.

www.jasonberrent.com

Cinda RamSeur  -  Sultry.

Ms. RamSeur's sound has evolved into one that is rooted in pop, R&B and Jazz.

Ms. RamSeur's music is straight up, no gimmicks, no heavy sequencing.  She invited the listener into her world putting her heart and soul into her lyrics and vocal delivery.  The result is reminiscent of a quiet fire - gentle, yet powerful.

Ms. RamSeur's voice embodies pure strength, purity and elegance.  She has long been respected among her colleagues in the music industry and has toured with many of the brightest stars of pop, R&B and jazz including Stevie Wonder, Diana Ross, Whitney Houston and Herbie Hancock to name a few.

Ms. RamSeur has appeared on Broadway with Dreamgirls and The Lion King.  Most recently she was the lead singer of Cirque du Soleil's spectacle, Kooza.

Ms. RamSeur calls Los Angeles home, but frequents the greatest city in the world, New York.

www.cindasings.com

Joshua Ryan Zehner  -  Witty.

Hailing from Los Angeles, Mr. Zehner was an original cast member and writer for Cirque du Soleil’s Kooza. He also was Director & Writer of Cirque Berzerk’s: Beneath. The show was loved by audiences and critics and was placed on The Los Angeles Times list of summer must-sees.

With ZEHNER/BERRENT, he has directed performances for some of the top entertainment companies, including Cirque du Soleil, NBC/Universal, Walt Disney, Subtopia, The Second City, The Late Show with David Letterman, Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey, FunnyBones, and Manegen Entertainment.  Mr. Zehner has personally performed in over 10,000 live performances.  His work has been performed internationally, in Great Britain, Sweden, Japan, Germany, Switzerland, Spain, Norway, Mexico, and throughout the United States and Canada.

Mr. Zehner has been teaching improvisation and physical comedy since 1998, as a private instructor and at institutions including the Ecole Nationale de Cirque, Manege Center for Circus, Music Hall & Street Performance, The Second City Training Center and Camp Bravo.

www.joshuazehner.com

Christian Fitzharris  -  Naughty.

Mr. Fitzharris has entertained audiences the world over in almost every performance venue known to man.

Making his debut in the hit family film, "Sister Act 2: Back in the Habit" as the class nerd, Tyler Chase he moved on to conquering family entertainment on cruise ships with Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines.

Mr. Fitzharris made his New York debut transliterating Shakespeare into hip hop in 2005 for a musical off-Broadway version of Titus Andronicus called, "Titus!" Later he honed his physical comedy skills performing nightly in Las Vegas at the MGM Grand. This lead him to creating Cirque du Soleil's ,"KOOZA" with Jason Berrent and Joshua Zehner under the watchful mentoring of David Shiner.

Gelsey Laurie  -  Fabulous.

Born in Riverside, CA, Ms. Laurie is a one of a kind dancer, singer, aerialist and all around artist.

Ms. Laurie began her career dancing for Disney.  She has spent the past two years amazing crowds on the high seas with some of the most exclusive cruise lines in the world.  She has danced numerous times alongside friend and colleague, Jason Berrent.

Ms. Laurie resides in the lovely New York, NY.
story_txt:
THE FIVE
CHARMING, FABULOUS, SULTRY, WITTY, NAUGHTY.
The Five invite you to an intimate night of glamour and performance.
The Five is a unique group of performers collaborating for the first time in New York City where they are planning a series of concerts during September 2013.  
The Five met while touring worldwide with the renowned KOOZA by Cirque du Soleil.  Finally, they are reuniting to create a reimagined Rat Pack with a modern twist. This group of talented performers will entertain the night away with song, dance and comedy.  Each will represent their very own distinct presence, personality, and talent. 
All performances will feature special surprises and a +1 (celebrity guest performer).


Where do your donations go?
Putting together a show is difficult, yet energizing and inspiring.  The Five are coming from the four corners of the Earth to rendezvous in New York City.  Here's your chance to be a part of it all.  Why donate?  These five artists know how to do a show, and do it well.
Our official updates will keep you informed of our progress during the creation process.
Your donations will help us create:

Our exquisite performance venue
Breathtaking costumes
Lush musical accompaniment
Rehearsal Space
Programs
Lighting/Sound
Production
PR
To make the night unforgettable and everything it's meant to be.

  


Paying It Forward
The Five's performances will not only be memorable evenings of class and splendor - but will make a significant impact in benefiting those in need.  A portion of the proceeds will go to benefit the following charities:

The Phyllis Newman Women's Health Intiative of The Actor's Fund
charity: water

story:
THE GAY HERITAGE PROJECT

World Premiere!

November 17-Dec 8, 2013

The GHP Collective in association with Buddies In Bad Times Theatre, Toronto.

“Three of our country’s most gifted creator/performers set out to answer one question: is there such a thing as gay heritage? In their search, they uncover a rich history not often shared, shine new light on contemporary gay culture, and fantasize about the prospect of legacy. The result is a hilarious and moving homage to the people who came before us and the events that continue to shape our lives.”            -- www.buddiesinbadtimes.com

 

What’s the GHP?

The Gay Heritage Project Collective was formed in 2008 by the three of us: Damien Atkins, Paul Dunn, and Andrew Kushnir. We are all three award-winning theater artists who, in our early careers, created and performed solo plays that investigated growing up gay in our respective contexts.

Now in our thirties, we wanted to develop a theater piece that could reflect a more evolved perspective on queerness, history and community. As queer people, what is our relationship or connection to other queer people? Is there history we ought to know, but don’t? Are there things we shouldn’t forget? What sort of theatrical experience could we create to inspire an authentic and personal sense of togetherness – no matter what your sexual orientation or cultural background? Gay playwright/activist Larry Kramer’s imperative from The Tragedy of Today’s Gays rang in our ears: “GET OUT THERE! DO SOMETHING FOR EACH OTHER!”

We started to look at the concept of HERITAGE -- and not heritage as a noun, but heritage as a kind of verb. How do you search for heritage? We got excited about heritage being a live thing: a dialogue between individuals and community, between past and present, and in our case, between “storyteller” and “audience”. Heritage is a concept typically used to describe a particular cultural nationality – we wanted to create a piece of theatre that asks: is there a kind of nationhood among queer people? If yes, what does it look like? If not, can we imagine one together?

 

The Show

The GHP Collective has been developing the show in residence at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre, the world’s largest and longest running queer theatre. What we’ve come up with is a kinetic, surprising, kaleidoscopic journey through the past, present and future. The play looks at everything from the Toronto bathhouse raids to homonationalism to Michel Foucault to the secret gay language of Polari to Canadian and international LGBT heroes. We take a good look at our own personal experiences and pasts. And naturally, a healthy look at The Wizard of Oz.

The play is by no means a comprehensive or conclusive articulation of gay heritage for anyone and everyone to adopt. For us, it’s about demonstrating what can happen when you embark on a personal search for things like lineage, shared history and legacy.  On November 17, 2013, The Gay Heritage Project will have its World Premiere as part of Buddies’ 2013/14 season. It will also mark the “coming out” of a new Toronto collective that is interested in exploring the queer experience through a bold, theatrical lens.

The GHP Collective needs your help to make this world premiere possible! Your donations will help us communally affirm the importance of manifesting, preserving, and passing on the ghosts, the stories, and the challenges of queer people that have walked before us. You will help us investigate, question, and celebrate aspects of the contemporary queer experience. You will help us illuminate our own particular strand of history and culture – not in order to emphasize it above other strands, but weave it into the human fabric with as much vitality and honesty as it demands and deserves. Your support will help create an engaging, entertaining and affirming piece of art.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The Gay Heritage Project is a co-production between Buddies and the GHP Collective. That means the GHP Collective has to contribute our half. We are not an institution, we are three guys. And though we’ve been aggressively fundraising, the GHP Collective is $5000 shy of our overall budget.

Every single dime raised through this Indiegogo campaign is going towards covering the cost of building, rehearsing, and running The Gay Heritage Project for the fall of 2013. Funds raised will go towards covering:

  • the design, materials and construction of our set and costumes
  • the rental of a rehearsal hall
  • artist fees (that includes equitable rates for actors, a director, lighting/set/costume/sound designers, a projection designer)
  • the fee for a stage manager
  • renting projecting equipment

$5000 might not seem like a lot but it makes a huge impact on the realization of The Gay Heritage Project. $5000 means our designers can achieve the full extent of their design vision – that sum can cover both the cost of materials and the construction of our set. That $5000 lets us book a good rehearsal hall for the number of hours we need to get this play on its feet, it helps us launch a strong marketing/publicity campaign for the show. Perhaps most importantly, $5000 makes the difference between us affording a complete rehearsal process, or having to abridge our rehearsal period to save money. This $5000 will ensure that The Gay Heritage Project comes together in the way we dreamed it would and has the best possible premiere.

If we don’t reach our entire goal, whatever you’ve generously donated will go directly into covering costs for the show. Every dime counts and every dime helps. We hope that everything from our Big Gay Thank You to a pair of Opening Night tickets (and a fruit pie!) are enough to entice you to give whatever you can. You are helping a group of artists serve their community in a singular and compelling way. 

 

The Impact

The Big Gay Dream is to eventually tour The Gay Heritage Project nationally through Canada, and internationally to whoever will have us. This play examines LGBTQ narratives within a global context and we have a great interest in seeing our “community” beyond Church Street, beyond Toronto, even beyond Canada. We are committed – as three writer/performers who have been politically active and publicly “out” since the very beginning of our careers – to art that is rigorous, inclusive, and socially pertinent.

Gay history, gay culture, gay ideas don’t typically get passed on by blood relatives the way other cultural heritages do (be it Italian, Jewish, or even Canadian). We feel a particular responsibility to the young queer people and hope that our personal journeys through The Gay Heritage Project can inspire and educate. Again, it’s not that our version of heritage is in any way definitive. What we hope is that people from all walks-of-life get something out of witnessing three artists searching for a heritage.

We look forward to partnering with various Toronto-based LGBTQ organizations during the run and provide space at the theater for their promotion and outreach. We plan to follow select performances with Q&As with prominent Canadian LGBTQ figures. We plan to hold a creation workshop with Buddies’ queer youth group to offer some tools for putting their stories on stage. We hope to make this production a true community event.

 

The Team

Written and performed by Damien Atkins, Paul Dunn, and Andrew Kushnir

Director: Ashlie Corcoran

Set/Lighting/Costume Designer: Kimberly Purtell

Sound Designer: Thomas Ryder Payne

Projection/Video Designer: Cameron Davis

Research Dramaturg: Paul Halferty

 

“Paul Dunn is a creative force to watch out for.” (of Offensive Shadows, torontostage.com)

“Damien Atkins is a real live talent…” (of Real Live Girl, NOW Magazine)

“Andrew Kushnir is simply delightful.” (of Habitat, See Magazine)

“It takes an actor of profound depth to capture this, and Atkin handles it beautifully.” (of I Am My Own Wife, Forth Worth Star-Telegram)

“Kushnir's range is remarkable from the ethereal and pristine airs of a feminine idealist to the convoluted and dark truth of the vituperative satirist.”                    (of King Lear, coloradodrama.com)

“Dunn acts it marvellously; he is unpatronizingly witty, vulnerable without being anybody’s puppy dog, and all-around appealing.” (of BOYS, National Post)

“When we think of LGBT history, there are often numerous gaps in between say, Stonewall in 1969 and the Toronto bathhouse raids and riots of 1981. Creators Paul Dunn, Andrew Kushnir and Damien Atkins elucidate our near and distant past with their latest offering, The Gay Heritage Project.”  (Advance press, In Toronto Magazine)

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if you can’t make a financial donation. But there are other ways to help get The Gay Heritage Project up and running.

1. Please let all your friends and family know about this Indiegogo campaign. Tweet about it. Facebook about it. Email away. Use the Indiegogo share tools and help us spread the word.

2. If you’re a Toronto business owner and you’d like to get involved in some way – whether it be taking an ad in the program or donating pastries for the opening night party, get in touch with us at gayheritageproject@gmail.com

3. Please come see the show! We run from November 17-December 8, 2013 and we’d love to share the piece with you.

4. If you’re affiliated with an agency working with or within the Toronto queer community, get in touch! We’d love to find a way to give you some visibility during our Fall run and provide you with group ticket rates for you and your clients.

5. If you’re interested in having The Gay Heritage Project come to your community, get in touch! We can be emailed at gayheritageproject@gmail.com

FOR MORE INFO, VISIT www.buddiesinbadtimes.com

story:
Our Story

c2c theatre is presenting Art by Yasmina Reza and we need your help! In order to put off this amazing comedy we need to raise funds to offset the production costs, namely the venue rental, performance rights and set materials. With these expenses covered all additional revenue can go right into the pockets of the artists involved. Since these professionals are donating their time we want to raise whatever we can! The artists involved are: Neil Butler, Rory Lambert, Dave Sullivan, Nicole Rousseau, Brian Bishop and Kirsti Mikoda. With your support we can bring their talents to the stage and offer St. John's this award winning comedy just in time for spring. 

 

About The Play

 

 

 

The story revolves around three friends—Serge, Marc and Yvan—who find their previously solid 15-year friendship on shaky ground when Serge buys an expensive painting. The canvas is white, with a few white lines. Serge is proud of his horribly expensive acquisition, fully expecting the approval of his friends.

Marc scornfully describes it as "a piece of white shit," but is it the painting that offends him, or the uncharacteristic independence-of-thought that the purchase reveals in Serge?

For the insecure Yvan, burdened by the problems of his impending doom (wedding) and his dissatisfaction at his job as a stationery salesman, their friendship is his sanctuary...but his attempts at peace-making backfire. Eager to please he laughs about the painting with Marc but tells Serge he likes it. Pulled into the disagreement, his vacillations fuel the blazing row.

Lines are drawn and they square off over the canvas, using it as an excuse to relentlessly batter one another over various failures. As their arguments become less theoretical and more personal, they border on destroying their friendship.

 

 

 


SHOWTIMES

March 29th-April 1st at 8pm with a Pay What You Can Performance on March 31st at 2pm

VENUE

Arts and Culture Centre Basement Theatre

TICKETS

Available at the Arts and Culture Centre Box Office, by calling 709 729 3900 or booking online at www.artsandculturecentre.com

FEATURING

Neil Butler, Rory Lambert and Dave Sullivan

Directed by Nicole Rousseau with Lighting Design by Brian Bishop and 

Stage Management by Kirsti Mikoda

 

The Impact

With the theatre community growing each year, c2c theatre seeks out challenging opportunities for theatre professionals working in the city of St. John's. We program contemporary theatre from around the world in an effort to showcase this city's talented artists and bring the world stage a little closer to home. While we continually work towards keeping expenses low and artist fees high, we depend on the support of municipal and provincial funding as well as members of the community. Small donations of $20-$50 go a long way to making a production like this possible and worthwhile for the artists involved. We've set our goal at $2000 but the more we raise the better we can produce this fantastic piece.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

To realize this production, we need to cover the costs of the venue, the performance rights, and the materials for our set. Every dollar we raise is one dollar less we need to cover expenses, meaning we can put more back into the community by supporting a great cast of professional actors and an amazing creative team. In return for your contribution we'll reward you with some great perks including tickets to the opening night, an original painting from the show or a special dinner with wine pairing! Read the full list of perks to find out more.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and come to the show! The more tickets we sell to this production the closer we get to our revenue goal. So if you can't make a contribution here, get some friends together and come see Art at the Basement Theatre. Don't forget that we'll be serving the traditional c2c turkey at the opening night reception! 

 

Thank you for your support!

 

Photo Courtesy of Tyler John
story_txt:
Our Story
c2c theatre is presenting Art by Yasmina Reza and we need your help! In order to put off this amazing comedy we need to raise funds to offset the production costs, namely the venue rental, performance rights and set materials. With these expenses covered all additional revenue can go right into the pockets of the artists involved. Since these professionals are donating their time we want to raise whatever we can! The artists involved are: Neil Butler, Rory Lambert, Dave Sullivan, Nicole Rousseau, Brian Bishop and Kirsti Mikoda. With your support we can bring their talents to the stage and offer St. John's this award winning comedy just in time for spring. 
 
About The Play
 
 
 
The story revolves around three friends—Serge, Marc and Yvan—who find their previously solid 15-year friendship on shaky ground when Serge buys an expensive painting. The canvas is white, with a few white lines. Serge is proud of his horribly expensive acquisition, fully expecting the approval of his friends.
Marc scornfully describes it as "a piece of white shit," but is it the painting that offends him, or the uncharacteristic independence-of-thought that the purchase reveals in Serge?
For the insecure Yvan, burdened by the problems of his impending doom (wedding) and his dissatisfaction at his job as a stationery salesman, their friendship is his sanctuary...but his attempts at peace-making backfire. Eager to please he laughs about the painting with Marc but tells Serge he likes it. Pulled into the disagreement, his vacillations fuel the blazing row.
Lines are drawn and they square off over the canvas, using it as an excuse to relentlessly batter one another over various failures. As their arguments become less theoretical and more personal, they border on destroying their friendship.
 
 
 

SHOWTIMES
March 29th-April 1st at 8pm with a Pay What You Can Performance on March 31st at 2pm
VENUE
Arts and Culture Centre Basement Theatre
TICKETS
Available at the Arts and Culture Centre Box Office, by calling 709 729 3900 or booking online at www.artsandculturecentre.com
FEATURING
Neil Butler, Rory Lambert and Dave Sullivan
Directed by Nicole Rousseau with Lighting Design by Brian Bishop and 
Stage Management by Kirsti Mikoda
 


The Impact
With the theatre community growing each year, c2c theatre seeks out challenging opportunities for theatre professionals working in the city of St. John's. We program contemporary theatre from around the world in an effort to showcase this city's talented artists and bring the world stage a little closer to home. While we continually work towards keeping expenses low and artist fees high, we depend on the support of municipal and provincial funding as well as members of the community. Small donations of $20-$50 go a long way to making a production like this possible and worthwhile for the artists involved. We've set our goal at $2000 but the more we raise the better we can produce this fantastic piece.
 


What We Need & What You Get
 
To realize this production, we need to cover the costs of the venue, the performance rights, and the materials for our set. Every dollar we raise is one dollar less we need to cover expenses, meaning we can put more back into the community by supporting a great cast of professional actors and an amazing creative team. In return for your contribution we'll reward you with some great perks including tickets to the opening night, an original painting from the show or a special dinner with wine pairing! Read the full list of perks to find out more.


 
Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word and come to the show! The more tickets we sell to this production the closer we get to our revenue goal. So if you can't make a contribution here, get some friends together and come see Art at the Basement Theatre. Don't forget that we'll be serving the traditional c2c turkey at the opening night reception! 
 
Thank you for your support!
 
Photo Courtesy of Tyler John

story:
We are art & lies productions!!!

We are based in Toronto, and our mandate is focused on stylized and physical theatre, with a bent for the absurd.

art & lies productions  commits itself to heightened and stylized approaches to theatre creation. Inspired by early twentieth century artistic experimentation, including the Theatre of the Absurd and its canon of artists and scripts, art & lies productions thrives on the spectacle, precision and messaging inherent to those traditions.

IN ADAGIO! THE CAMPAIGN:

We are seeking funds to help our production of the Toronto premiere of In Adagio, a new play creation by one of our core company members. The piece ran to wide acclaim at the Winnipeg Fringe, and the CBC there said "This one will knock your socks off with its exquisite singing and precise performances. ***** Classical opera meets Traditional Portugese Fado, in a spectacle of style and raw energy!


In Adagio, will launch our second season in Toronto! This campaign and your support is so important to us, as it will help us continue to kick absurdist butt in the community!

In supporting us, you will help bring this production to a new audience, to help us spread the word on our company, and to help four strong, smart, determined women, see their hard work escalate to its next professional step.

YOUR SUPPORT!

We operated our first season out of our own pockets, and ran three sold out shows, with great reviews. But, we need your help to stay strong and keep going. Your support will help us cover rental costs for the theatre, and marketing costs to help us spread the word on art & lies productions!

THE PERKS

You will be supporting stories that many are too afraid to tell, and a group of artists, not afraid to tell them.

You will be facilitating a timely movement in theatre practice, where style and true theatricality is celebrated, where new artists are encouraged, where the past informs the present, and all are woven in a whirlwind of art & lies.

IF WE DON'T REACH OUR GOAL 

We still reach part of our goal! Part of our purpose is to get the word out on art & lies productions, and to attract new audience members.

If we don't receive our full funding, we will reduce our overall production costs, and keep fighting to spread the word!

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP!

Spread the word about In Adagio, and about art & lies productions! We would love your help to share our work with the world!

www.artandliesproductions.com

Don't forget to use Indiegogo share tools please!

story:
The Play

Cruisin' with Sexual Healing is a pair of interwoven solo performances written by and starring Courtlin Fields and Donald Calliste.  Developed through the reknowned Slices of Lives theatre program, the play tells the story of the lives of Marvin Gaye and Smokey Robinson.
 
The play will be opening for an 8 week run in New York City this July 2012.

The Money

Why $4850?  Well, things add up fast and we're committed to giving you an excellent experience.

Printing (programs, etc.) - $550

Costumes, sets and props - $1000

Public Relations  - $1600

Website, Photography, Graphic Design - $700

The Cast, The Crew, and other folks working behind the scenes - $1000

All the money received will go towards the production and its 12 week run.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand today's harsh economic times and realize some people would like to donate but can't; however, there are ways you can still support our production and make it successful. Please help us spread the word by telling your friends and family about the show. Share this Indiegogo link with your social network. Most importantly, pray for us. Seriously. Pray that we will reach and surpass our goal. Pray that the actors will give phenomenal performances that will enlighten, entertain, and engage the hearts of many as they portray these incomparable musical icons. We appreciate any and all support you can give us. Come out, see our show, and bring your friends! God bless you and thank you in advance.

story:
Rock Bottom Movement 

"No stage, no lights, no gimmicks, no problem. We've hit rock bottom so we might as well dance." The motto for this emerging dance company, started when a frustrated dance major student decided that enough was enough. Building upon the foundation that no two people are alike, the work of Rock Bottom Movement introduces the interpretors as artists and individuals celebrating unsual personality qualities and movement that is as much a personal investigation for the dancers as it is for the audience. Frustrated with not having enough opportunity to perform or to share her artistic vision, fourth year Ryerson Dance student Alyssa Martin, being her true stubborn self hopped on a bus and picked up her Toronto Busking Lisence, rounded up a few of her extremely talented yet gritty dance friends and started creating Rock Bottom Movement's first piece, "plaything in two movements." In June, they travelled around Toronto for many afternoons performing in parks, squares and ferry docks accompanied by a live saxophone quartet. Later that summer, the gang celebrated Canada Day with DES(S)ERT SESSIONS, a new work, while busking on Front Street accross from CanStage. In September, Rock Bottom Movement had their first gig. A piece for all females, "venUS in furs" was performed at the Cabbage Town Festival. Despite the cold rainy weather and the fact that the stage was the size of an IKEA kitchen table, the dancers threw their sneakers and sweaters on and performed the piece on the wet pavement rolling around in puddles and rain. Most recently, the group performed as part of Venetian Ball performing alongside acts such as Frankie Avalon in front of 800 paying guests. Rock Bottom Movement is an initiative to create fresh contemporary movement which can appeal to dance audiences and non-dance audiences alike.

The Nutcracker

Honesty is the best policy so here it is - we need your help to make our first show possible. We have started from nothing, literally collecting money in a busking bucket, designing a website, networking on Facebook and Tumblr, talking to friends and mentors and throwing parties. This tour involves transportation, costumes, lighting, space rental, etc! Your help is so greatly appreciated! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about The Nutcracker and about Rock Bottom Movement! Like our Facebook page www.facebook.com/rockbottommovement and keep in touch with us! We appreciate all and any kind of support!

story:
Who We Are

At Millikin University in Decatur, Illinois is the Omega Xi Cast of Alpha Psi Omega. This spring semester at Millikin University, there is a new pledge class who are in the process of becoming active members of the Omega Xi Cast at Millikin. Part of being a pledge of Alpha Psi Omega it putting up the Alpha Psi Omega theatre formal every semester. This formal is a chance for the actives and pledges at Millikin to get to know each other and hang out. This semester the formal's theme is "A Night At The Tonys" and occurs on April 13th, from 7 to 10pm. The pledges are trying to put up the a great event but need the funds to do so. Along with doing tons of fundraisers, they're creating this IndieGoGo to reach out to donors off campus. 

What We Need & What You Get

To put up an amazing formal, this pledge cast needs $500. The money will go directly to putting up the best formal Millikin's Alpha Psi Omega has ever seen. With the theme being "A Night At The Tonys," the money will go to the purchase of food, decorations, party favors, and the ingredients for mocktails. 


Any money not put toward the formal will go directly to Alpha Psi Omega's service programs and helping bring guest artists to Millikin.


With the small donation of $10 dollars you get a complimentary ticket to this formal event. But donating what ever amount of funds you can, from $1 to $500, helps these pledges put up this formal and helps Alpha Psi Omega bring and do great things for the Millikin University campus and Decatur community.

History of Who We Are (Alpha Psi Omega)

In the early twentieth century, interest in the dramatic arts grew tremendously on college and university campuses. By 1920, most colleges had a dramatic organization staging plays annually for the campus and the community at large. Also around this time, little theatre productions and dramatic workshops began taking place. This furthered the interest in theatre on campuses everywhere, especially in the western part of the country. At this time, several honororary groups were formed to recognize and reward exemplary student participation in those productions.

In 1921, at Fairmont State College in Fairmont, West Virginia, college theater took root. A faculty director was hired in 1923, and the Masquers were formed. The Masquers were charged with presenting a season of 4 to 5 major productions per year for students and the general public. In 1924, the Masquers began searching for a national honorary organization to join. As there was no truly national organization, Elinor B. Watson, Robert Sloan, and Fairmont faculty director Paul F. Opp researched forming such a national organization.

As a result of their research and work, a proposed national constitution was drawn up, and, on August 12, 1925, the first cast of Alpha Psi Omega members, drawn from the Masquers, was initiated. It was then decided that each chapter was to be called a "cast," and Fairmont College became the Alpha Cast. Soon after, Marshall College in Huntington, West Virginia, expressed interest in chartering a cast of Alpha Psi Omega; they founded the Beta Cast. A member from Huntington suggested the name "Playbill" for the national magazine, which was thereafter adopted.

Throughout the country, Alpha Psi Omega has sponsored the formation of theatre honor societies in high schools and junior colleges, with the aim of encouraging dramatic production at every step in a person's academic career. In 1929, after significant interest on the junior college level, Delta Psi Omega was formed. In 1936, at the Alpha Psi Omega Grand Rehearsal, Delta Psi Omega was officially recognized as the junior college division of Alpha Psi Omega. Today, there are over 350 Delta Psi Omega casts.

Alpha Psi Omega has enjoyed continuous national growth and, with over 600 casts, is the largest national honor society in America. Colleges and universities of recognized standing, having an established theatre program or theatre club for the purpose of producing plays, will be eligible for membership.

Our Mission

The purpose of this, the Omega Xi Cast of Alpha Psi Omega, is to stimulate interest in dramatic activity at Millikin University, to secure to the college all the advantages and mutual helpfulness provided by a large national honorary fraternity, and by electing student to membership, serving as an honor for their efforts in theatre while at Millikin University. In addition, Alpha Psi Omega strives to bring quality theatre to the Decatur Community, as well as to our own scholastic home. Our motto â€œseek a life useful,â€ is executed through bringing our knowledge of theatre to others.

Other Ways You Can Help

If donating money isn't your thing, just pass this link onto someone else you think might be willing to help an Alpha Psi Omega pledge cast. We appreciate anything!

story:
“500 mg of something” is the first “professional” short film by writer/director Brent Stevens, using SAG actors and shot entirely on the Red Camera(E.R., The Knowing). The film is finished but the festival submissions are impending, and require entry fees. For those of you not familiar with the process, a short film like “500mg of something” is made as a calling card for the director, to get their work seen. There are few outlets for short films to be publicly seen, especially dramatic ones, so film festivals are primarily where any recognition is received.

No donation is too small(or too large), every bit helps. The more festivals the film is submitted to, the better chance it has of being accepted and possibly even winning an award.

Some stills and on-set photos can be seen here:
http://www.facebook.com/album.php?aid=16217&amp...

The film stars Ray Santiago(Meet The Fockers, My Name is Earl, Dexter) and Josh Wingate(General Hospital, Justified, Medium), with Amy Lucas(Sabrina the Teenage Witch, Undressed), Benjamin Ciaramello(Friday Night Lights, Greys Anatomy, Private Practice), Laura Walker and Brandon Lim supporting.

www.brentstevens.net
