story:
Dear Friends, 

Two years ago, we came to you for help to send Sylvani on her very first summer ballet intensive, because though I am able to support her, love her through her difficult moments, and help her find her best path to what she wants, and though her father can drive her to ballet lessons, physical therapy, and rehearsals, we cannot afford all that it takes to train a ballet dancer to a career in ballet. Summer intensives are very expensive, but also incredibly valuable to a young dancer's development. Two years ago, you all came through and it was so humbling to know how much you support Sylvani's dream.  The activity on this campaign also caused it to rise on the Indiegogo "Go Go Factor" which pushed her to the top of the search engine. This attracted the attention of a very sweet sponsor who was able to give Sylvani all financing for last year's summer ballet intensive--she returned to Whitman Summer Dance Lab for 5 weeks, on a partial tuition merit scholarship (!), was selected by audition for apprenticeship with a professional modern company for the Walla Walla Dance Festival, and learned so much--coming back stronger, more skilled, and ready to take on even more difficult dance in her current regular year.
That sponsor, though he was contributing to her dance education right up until Thanksgiving this past fall, has "disappeared"--he has always kept his anonymity with us, communicating only through email, and sending support through Paypal, and has been very kind and communicative in our email exchanges. He has simply stopped communicating at all, and we are very, very worried about him. 
Still, for Sylvani, the show must go on!  We are hoping this wonderful man will contact us to let her know what happened, but even if he doesn't, she needs to go to her summer Intensive--this time she has chosen Texas Ballet Theater, which has offered her 90% tuition scholarship!  But there are many more expenses to get her there. 
So we are coming to you once again for help.

Please read her new campaign, Help Sylvani Dance 2.0, here!

Here's a picture of Sylvani in Oregon Ballet Academy's Spring Concert: 

Our Story

What makes Sylvani Dance?  Love! To Sylvani, Love=Dance
I'm Sylvani's mother. Since she was 3, Sylvani has wanted to “be a ballerina”. What little girl doesn’t? Most take a few classes, wear a tutu for awhile whenever they can, and change their minds later.  But she is now nearly 13, and I have never known anyone so dedicated. Still loving ballet profoundly, dance has been her favorite thing to do for 9 years, no matter how much work, no matter how many hours a week.  Sylvani says when life is hard and overwhelming, the one thing that helps her is dance class.  She says she "forgets everything else, lets the music fill her, and just dances".  So even when the steps are difficult, her pointe shoes hurt, or she is tired after a full day of school and dance class, she wants more. Everyone who sees Sylvani dance can see the gift she has, and comments on her talent. 

Sylvani's Got "It"!

Sylvani has had many blessings in her life: 

  • Serendipity to have John Grensback (NYC Ballet, Joffrey
    Ballet, and principal with the Houston Ballet) and his wife
    Megan Murphy (Houston Ballet), open the Oregon Ballet Academy just as Sylvani was ready to begin her training.  There is no better school for developing her talents in a spirit of support and cooperation, combined with all the professional knowledge to bring young students to their highest level. Their motto is "Serious Dance. Serious Fun!" Sylvani has been working with John as her primary ballet teacher since she was 6, and at the school since she was 3.
  • Destiny to have one grandmother who danced and still teaches dance, and the other grandmother, of Romanian Jewish heritage, who passed on her graceful lithe beauty.  It's in her genes! She has the talent and the "look".
  • Kismet that each of Sylvani's parents also have musical talent and training that allowed us to recognize Sylvani's musicality from birth.  Sylvani has always had our support and we are determined to help her take this as far as she wishes to go! 

John Grensback says, she "has all the ingredients"--talent, musicality, the right look, and love.  From a man who danced under such ballet phenomes as George Ballanchine and Robert Joffrey, this is high praise and predictive of Sylvani's chances for success.  

The Next Step.  Moving to pre-professional level training...
Each summer, many ballet companies around the world offer summer dance intensives for serious students wishing to improve their form, round out their training, and maybe find their way into a company one day. This year, Sylvani auditioned for the Summer Dance Lab at Whitman College in Walla Walla, WA, the oldest such intensive in the country, and the American Ballet Theater Summer Intensive.  The audition tours go all around the country, auditioning thousands of students.  Since she is so young, and it was her first time auditioning, in a highly competitive environment against older and more experienced ballet students, we thought this would just be a good "trial run" to help her learn to audition. We were thrilled when she opened her response emails from BOTH and was accepted!  After careful consideration, Sylvani has decided that the 2-week Summer Dance Lab at Whitman College is best for her first experience.  

The Biggest Challenge...What else? $$$

These programs cost much more than our family can afford.  The Summer Dance Lab costs $2397 for tuition, room and board, plus transportation and other costs estimated at $1000 to get her there and back. I am supporting a whole family on one income, including many costs for two college students, Sylvani's older sisters. While I would happily do so if it were possible, I just can't afford to pay for this myself.

Will You Help Please?
Sylvani has worked so hard to achieve her dream and shows so much promise!  Dance is the most important thing in her life. I don't want to see her miss this chance because I am unable to afford it. So, we are turning to you, our friends and family, patrons of dance and the performing arts, and supporters of dreams of all kinds!

Just think how you will feel when, one day, you see Sylvani on a major dance stage and know that you helped get her there!

 


The Goal= $3000
All money earned through this campaign will go directly towards the tuition ($1389), the administrative fee ($35) and housing ($973) costs for Summer Dance Lab, as well as transportation costs (estimated at $1000) to get her there and back. Sylvani actually needs $3397 to meet the projected costs, but to make it easier to reach our goal, and have more of your money go to her project, we set the amount here at $3000. Please feel free to donate more. If she raises more than she needs, we will put any additional funds into a "dance support" account for Sylvani's future dance needs, such as leotards, shoes (one pair of pointe shoes costs $85), and additional classes. We aren't stopping here. We are also approaching local businesses for donations, holding a garage sale, and possibly putting on a dance benefit.

(Just in case this campaign doesn't meet it's goal, any money will still be kept in a fund to help Sylvani attend extra summer classes closer to home)

Your donation will all go to Sylvani's dance education.

Check out the great perks Sylvani is offering! When Sylvani danced for her godfather and godmother's wedding, their photographer, Roots, took this beautiful photo of her. Sylvani's Uncle Lawrence, a graphic designer, made it into an 11"x17" poster. (Printing services donated by Premier Press, in Portland, OR).

If you donate $30 or more, Sylvani will send you a signed copy of this poster as a thank you gift.

Other Ways You Can Help

The best other way you can help, after you donate of course, is to spread the word!!!  Tell your friends about Sylvani, and ask if they would like to help a young girl reach her dream of becoming a professional ballerina.  They could be contributing to the next great ballet star!  You can easily "share" that you donated by using the tools on this site.  Post the link on your Facebook page!  Put it on your friends' walls!  Send a Tweet!  And remember the power of positive thinking!  Go to see a ballet and visualize Sylvani dancing on that stage and that you are helping her get there!
story_txt:
Dear Friends, Two years ago, we came to you for help to send Sylvani on her very first summer ballet intensive, because though I am able to support her, love her through her difficult moments, and help her find her best path to what she wants, and though her father can drive her to ballet lessons, physical therapy, and rehearsals, we cannot afford all that it takes to train a ballet dancer to a career in ballet. Summer intensives are very expensive, but also incredibly valuable to a young dancer's development. Two years ago, you all came through and it was so humbling to know how much you support Sylvani's dream.  The activity on this campaign also caused it to rise on the Indiegogo "Go Go Factor" which pushed her to the top of the search engine. This attracted the attention of a very sweet sponsor who was able to give Sylvani all financing for last year's summer ballet intensive--she returned to Whitman Summer Dance Lab for 5 weeks, on a partial tuition merit scholarship (!), was selected by audition for apprenticeship with a professional modern company for the Walla Walla Dance Festival, and learned so much--coming back stronger, more skilled, and ready to take on even more difficult dance in her current regular year.That sponsor, though he was contributing to her dance education right up until Thanksgiving this past fall, has "disappeared"--he has always kept his anonymity with us, communicating only through email, and sending support through Paypal, and has been very kind and communicative in our email exchanges. He has simply stopped communicating at all, and we are very, very worried about him. Still, for Sylvani, the show must go on!  We are hoping this wonderful man will contact us to let her know what happened, but even if he doesn't, she needs to go to her summer Intensive--this time she has chosen Texas Ballet Theater, which has offered her 90% tuition scholarship!  But there are many more expenses to get her there. So we are coming to you once again for help.Please read her new campaign, Help Sylvani Dance 2.0, here!
Here's a picture of Sylvani in Oregon Ballet Academy's Spring Concert: 
Our Story
What makes Sylvani Dance?  Love! To Sylvani, Love=DanceI'm Sylvani's mother. Since she was 3, Sylvani has wanted to “be a ballerina”. What little girl doesn’t? Most take a few classes, wear a tutu for awhile whenever they can, and change their minds later.  But she is now nearly 13, and I have never known anyone so dedicated. Still loving ballet profoundly, dance has been her favorite thing to do for 9 years, no matter how much work, no matter how many hours a week.  Sylvani says when life is hard and overwhelming, the one thing that helps her is dance class.  She says she "forgets everything else, lets the music fill her, and just dances".  So even when the steps are difficult, her pointe shoes hurt, or she is tired after a full day of school and dance class, she wants more. Everyone who sees Sylvani dance can see the gift she has, and comments on her talent. 


Sylvani's Got "It"! 
Sylvani has had many blessings in her life: 


Serendipity to have John Grensback (NYC Ballet, Joffrey Ballet, and principal with the Houston Ballet) and his wife Megan Murphy (Houston Ballet), open the Oregon Ballet Academy just as Sylvani was ready to begin her training.  There is no better school for developing her talents in a spirit of support and cooperation, combined with all the professional knowledge to bring young students to their highest level. Their motto is "Serious Dance. Serious Fun!" Sylvani has been working with John as her primary ballet teacher since she was 6, and at the school since she was 3.

Destiny to have one grandmother who danced and still teaches dance, and the other grandmother, of Romanian Jewish heritage, who passed on her graceful lithe beauty.  It's in her genes! She has the talent and the "look". 

Kismet that each of Sylvani's parents also have musical talent and training that allowed us to recognize Sylvani's musicality from birth.  Sylvani has always had our support and we are determined to help her take this as far as she wishes to go! 

John Grensback says, she "has all the ingredients"--talent, musicality, the right look, and love.  From a man who danced under such ballet phenomes as George Ballanchine and Robert Joffrey, this is high praise and predictive of Sylvani's chances for success.  
The Next Step.  Moving to pre-professional level training...Each summer, many ballet companies around the world offer summer dance intensives for serious students wishing to improve their form, round out their training, and maybe find their way into a company one day. This year, Sylvani auditioned for the Summer Dance Lab at Whitman College in Walla Walla, WA, the oldest such intensive in the country, and the American Ballet Theater Summer Intensive.  The audition tours go all around the country, auditioning thousands of students.  Since she is so young, and it was her first time auditioning, in a highly competitive environment against older and more experienced ballet students, we thought this would just be a good "trial run" to help her learn to audition. We were thrilled when she opened her response emails from BOTH and was accepted!  After careful consideration, Sylvani has decided that the 2-week Summer Dance Lab at Whitman College is best for her first experience.  

The Biggest Challenge...What else? $$$
These programs cost much more than our family can afford.  The Summer Dance Lab costs $2397 for tuition, room and board, plus transportation and other costs estimated at $1000 to get her there and back. I am supporting a whole family on one income, including many costs for two college students, Sylvani's older sisters. While I would happily do so if it were possible, I just can't afford to pay for this myself.
Will You Help Please?Sylvani has worked so hard to achieve her dream and shows so much promise!  Dance is the most important thing in her life. I don't want to see her miss this chance because I am unable to afford it. So, we are turning to you, our friends and family, patrons of dance and the performing arts, and supporters of dreams of all kinds! 
Just think how you will feel when, one day, you see Sylvani on a major dance stage and know that you helped get her there!
 
The Goal= $3000All money earned through this campaign will go directly towards the tuition ($1389), the administrative fee ($35) and housing ($973) costs for Summer Dance Lab, as well as transportation costs (estimated at $1000) to get her there and back. Sylvani actually needs $3397 to meet the projected costs, but to make it easier to reach our goal, and have more of your money go to her project, we set the amount here at $3000. Please feel free to donate more. If she raises more than she needs, we will put any additional funds into a "dance support" account for Sylvani's future dance needs, such as leotards, shoes (one pair of pointe shoes costs $85), and additional classes. We aren't stopping here. We are also approaching local businesses for donations, holding a garage sale, and possibly putting on a dance benefit. 
(Just in case this campaign doesn't meet it's goal, any money will still be kept in a fund to help Sylvani attend extra summer classes closer to home)
Your donation will all go to Sylvani's dance education.
Check out the great perks Sylvani is offering! When Sylvani danced for her godfather and godmother's wedding, their photographer, Roots, took this beautiful photo of her. Sylvani's Uncle Lawrence, a graphic designer, made it into an 11"x17" poster. (Printing services donated by Premier Press, in Portland, OR).
If you donate $30 or more, Sylvani will send you a signed copy of this poster as a thank you gift. 


Other Ways You Can Help
The best other way you can help, after you donate of course, is to spread the word!!!  Tell your friends about Sylvani, and ask if they would like to help a young girl reach her dream of becoming a professional ballerina.  They could be contributing to the next great ballet star!  You can easily "share" that you donated by using the tools on this site.  Post the link on your Facebook page!  Put it on your friends' walls!  Send a Tweet!  And remember the power of positive thinking!  Go to see a ballet and visualize Sylvani dancing on that stage and that you are helping her get there!

story:
What I do:

My name is Camryn Zelinger and I founded a new youth theatre company LOLA MAE PERFORMING ARTS. This summer I am launching a summer conservatory aimed to give youth the necessary tools to build confidence, character, creativly express, and rise to their full potential. Whether the kids want to go on and perform professionally one day or just stand a little taller when presenting a speech in class, I allow them to find their voice.

 

Why a Campaign?

I am doing a campaign so that I can keep tutition costs at a minimum for every child that would like to be involved. I understand that times are tough and I do not want a child left out of this opportunity because of tuition costs. It takes a lot of money to put on a 5-week summer conservatory and mount a full length musical at the end. ANYTHING you can contribute to help me with this endevor to get it off of the ground would be so very appreciated. I will not be making ANY profit during this program. All the money (goal reached or not) will go to rehearsal and performance venues, sets, costumes, lights, musical rights, scholarships and staff (musical director/choreographer/stage manager). Your generosity will not go unnoticed!

 

Summer Plans:

During the 5-week summer program we will be also rehearsing for the musical STARMITES!! A fun upbeat rock and roll musical that's OUT OF THIS WORLD. We will be performing it at the ROSE CENTER THEATRE in WESTMINISTER and show dates are Aug. 10, 11, and 12.

A little more about me:

I am a graduate of the American Musical and Dramatic Academy. I had the wonderful opportunity to study, perform and live in New York City for over 4 years. Youth theatre was always my number one passion and while living in the big apple I started my very own youth summer theatre camp. I traveled back to Southern California every summer to teach my beloved students everything from Musical theatre to commercial and t.v. acting. Last summer I had the privilage to not only Artist Direct but Direct and Choreograph Saddleback Civic Light Opera's brand new Youth Summer Program MAINSTAGE KIDS to sold out crowds. After holding many intensive workshops, master classes, and camps it was time for me to start my own Youth theatre company. I am over the moon that this dream has finally become a reality. Now, all I need to do is make it affordable for ALL KIDS! Please HELP Me!!!

story:
ARI GOLD's BASHERT: An Autobiographical Homotheatrical Multi-Media Musical

Growing up in the Bronx, circa the 1980’s, religious, closeted, and thrust into show-biz at age five after singing at his brother’s bar mitzvah, Ari Gold comes out and comes of age—as America’s first openly gay pop star. With an eclectic, stellar group of mentors including Diana Ross, Jem & the Holograms, and his principal guide, his Jewish grandmother “Fairygodbubbe,” Ari searches for his “bashert”—what’s “meant to be”—in this electro-pop behind-the-musical memoir of identity, sex, religion, family, and show business.

The issues around identity, sexuality, religion, visibility and human rights has always been a huge part of my work, and something I feel so passionatly about, which is why I am particularly excited about venturing into theater.  Telling untold stories in a different medium that includes my music allows me to delve deeper into these issues and continue a vital cultural conversation. I do believe that music, art and theater heals--there's something transformative for an audience when they are entertained, laugh and moved at hearing someone's personal story told well. All money I raise will go to the production costs and fees of this show.

Getting accepted into a prestigious festival like NYMF is only the first step.  Developing and producing a theater project has certain fixed costs.  For example, the substantial fee that NYMF requires you to pay, as well as technical and material needs (theater costs, equipment, sets, lighting, costumes, mics, etc.).  Many people who have been passionate about my project have alread starting working by donating their time.  However, the director, actors, company manager, stage crew, lighting / sound guys, projectionists, etc. all need to be paid.  There are 3 workshop performances happening at NYMF: Wednesday, July 11th at 8pm, Saturday July 14th at 10:30pm, and Sunday July, 15th at 4:30pm. 

This is going to be a staged reading/workshop that includes some of the multi-media aspects of the full production.  This is an important step in the development of this show.

There are exciting gifts I am offering for people who donate at every level including my entire signed discography, producer credits, backstage access and even a chance to be in my show vis a vis video. But most importamntly, you will be a vital part in making this dream come true.

If you are interested in donating and you would like a tax deduction you can donate directly to NYMF: https://www.nymf.org/Donatetobashert Same perks apply whether you donate here or to NYMF.

I am honored and humbled that you would contribute to my most important project to date.

Sir Ari Gold is a Billboard Top 10 Recording Artist, Grand Prize USA Songwriting competition winner, an Independent Music Award Winner, 2x Outmusic Award Winner, one of the OUT100 and was knighted by the Imperial Court of New York.

story:
Mary Norwood has been our strong independent voice on Atlanta City Council representing all of the citizens of Atlanta.  She knows Atlanta – we know her. 

Let’s re-elect Mary Norwood.

In her eight years as your city council person, she was a “hands on” representative for Atlanta.

In our communities – seeing firsthand what was going on - and working to improve our safety and our quality of life in our city.

A vote for Mary means that once again, we will have a strong, visible, independent council person who'll be watching out for us – addressing our needs – and working to improve our quality of life. 

Visit marynorwood.com for more information

story:
About Akynos & her campaign

Dear Friends! Have you heard about the crisis in Sweden? As it turns out Sweden, the country that has brought you Ikea is Black boobs deprived! Yes! that's right. And every now and then a hero is born that can save such countries from their ill fate. This year, I am THE ONLY BLACK PERFORMER in the Stockholm Burlesque Festival! Yes I have been chosen to save Sweden and show them how Black boobies jiggle! But I need your assistance in order to save them from the doom they face...an all White stripper burlesque show! I urge you to ACT NOW and donate to my campaign before time runs out!!! If all else fails, spread the word! You know, you think you are so blessed and live in the greatest country in the world, and then something like this comes up and you realize that even here -- yes, even in America -- there are people who get by without these basic things. Don't let the Stockholm Fest go another year without Black breasts! Use #helpsavesweden on twitter! Help spread the word!!!


BIO: A show stopping entertainer, The Incredible, Edible, Akynos has headlined, guest starred and performed in festivals and showcases from New York to Canada. She's curated ensembles in New York and in her hometown of Jamaica, West Indies. Performing burlesque since 2007, she was a dance major in High School and performed on local stages for some time before starting her performance art endeavors. This 4'11" powerhouse is a sex worker activist who served as the Arts Track Coordinator for the sexual health and education conference Desiree Alliance in July 2013. She has a Bachelors of Arts in interdisciplinary studies, in sex work and performance history from Goddard College. Her focus was in burlesque history and it's history in sex work. Her future endeavors include teaching classes in her under-served Brooklyn community, an instructional burlesque DVD project and extravagant burlesque show productions. You can keep up with her by logging on to her facebook fan page, her website, and read about the wonderful things taking place in her community by following her wordpress blog, Ihearteastnewyork. 

What We Need & What You Get

$2000 is the minimum I'm asking for in order to cover the cost of traveling and living expenses while I am in Sweden saving the poor Swiss from their doom.  A super human such as myself needs to sleep somewhere to recharge and knock the Swedes dead just by walking down the street. I must eat, because by boobs and booty don't jiggle on air alone. I need to get to and from each destination with ease as well, I'm a warrior princess, you don't expect me to walk do you? And once I'm done in Sweden, I head over to London and Paris where I plot and scheme on how to break in to their system and try to take over their performance scene. It should be relatively easy, as I'm sure once the press gets a hold of what I will do for Stockholm, there will be no stopping me. 

FAQ's

  • What if you make more than the $2000? - My fairy godmother who made this trip all possible needs to be reimbursed the cost of that rather expensive airfare. And if there's anything after that, well I'm a super hero warrior princess performance artist. I often like to change my shell, and do more amazing tricks that change the world through my art. It will go to good use. And you will see the play by play on it.
  • Are you saying that if you don't perform in this showcase, that the Stockholm Fest will be deprived and not have good talent? - No! What I'm saying is is that without me the entire Stockholm is doomed! Stockholm's Black population according to once source, is .8%. This is like a one Black boob giggle factor happening like every ten years. I will be the first..okay so I don't know about the first, but I'm the only this year and that's all that matters. Don't deprive the country of it's basic need to see my pastie covered boobs and my Black bottom in a g-string, repping for the Black Goddess herself, The Hottentot Venus. Do you really want me not to make history on top of leaving these people without the sight of my smooth chocolate flesh? I DIDN'T THINK SO! So kindly donate. :-D

The perks you get will be AMAZING!!! And make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside. From private performances, to glamorous photos that you can hang on your wall to brighten your day, to burlesque classes! How could you not want to contribute to this campaign knowing that there is a possibility that Akynos will be grateful and you helped save a part of the country with the world's eighth highest per capita income???? Like not helping me get there could completely devastate them and their resources. Don't let them go out like that. 

The Impact

Funding performance dreams can be challenging due to the stigma put on bodies that are seen as explicit; women and Black bodies and movement. Especially those with a performance style that does not qualify as high art. By contributing you could help Akynos take over the world! Help her bring the beauty of Black stripteasing history to Europe. So much of Black performance history has been eliminated from history, as well as the images and history of many of the burlesque queens that helped contribute to the history of this rich art. 

Your contribution also helps the community abroad witness that "classic" burlesque is not just limited to the slow striptease or Western aesthetic of disrobing. But be impacted with the knowledge of a long history Black bodies have had in burlesque with sometimes fast movements and stories in Black history.

Aaaaand, need I say it again? You save the country from an All White Stripper syndrome. One that has plagued burlesque stages for far too long, in too many places. So donate a dollar. Save the Swiss. Show a Black breast.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Tell your friends or others you know who are fans of live entertainment. URGE THEM to donate in your name and theirs. And be down with me for life.
  • Use hashtag #helpsavesweden on twitter and add me @akynos - spread the world! the Swiss needs me!
  • Come to one of my performances, and slide the money in my gstring. see here ---> http://ymlp.com/zZRfla
  • I'm a sex worker activist, spread the word to the groups you know. Post it to your sites and blogs! 
  • Even if the campaign has ended you can still logon to www.akynos.com and contribute there. Just click on the contact me option on the bottom left of the page.

One brown boob at a time. One dollar at a time. Help save Sweden. Black boobs forever!

It should be relatively easy, as I'm sure once the press gets a hold of what I will do for Stockholm, there will be no stopping me. 
FAQ's



What if you make more than the $2000? - My fairy godmother who made this trip all possible needs to be reimbursed the cost of that rather expensive airfare. And if there's anything after that, well I'm a super hero warrior princess performance artist. I often like to change my shell, and do more amazing tricks that change the world through my art. It will go to good use. And you will see the play by play on it.


Are you saying that if you don't perform in this showcase, that the Stockholm Fest will be deprived and not have good talent? - No! What I'm saying is is that without me the entire Stockholm is doomed! Stockholm's Black population according to once source, is .8%. This is like a one Black boob giggle factor happening like every ten years. I will be the first..okay so I don't know about the first, but I'm the only this year and that's all that matters. Don't deprive the country of it's basic need to see my pastie covered boobs and my Black bottom in a g-string, repping for the Black Goddess herself, The Hottentot Venus. Do you really want me not to make history on top of leaving these people without the sight of my smooth chocolate flesh? I DIDN'T THINK SO! So kindly donate. :-D



The perks you get will be AMAZING!!! And make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside. From private performances, to glamorous photos that you can hang on your wall to brighten your day, to burlesque classes! How could you not want to contribute to this campaign knowing that there is a possibility that Akynos will be grateful and you helped save a part of the country with the world's eighth highest per capita income???? Like not helping me get there could completely devastate them and their resources. Don't let them go out like that. 


The Impact
Funding performance dreams can be challenging due to the stigma put on bodies that are seen as explicit; women and Black bodies and movement. Especially those with a performance style that does not qualify as high art. By contributing you could help Akynos take over the world! Help her bring the beauty of Black stripteasing history to Europe. So much of Black performance history has been eliminated from history, as well as the images and history of many of the burlesque queens that helped contribute to the history of this rich art. Your contribution also helps the community abroad witness that "classic" burlesque is not just limited to the slow striptease or Western aesthetic of disrobing. But be impacted with the knowledge of a long history Black bodies have had in burlesque with sometimes fast movements and stories in Black history.
Aaaaand, need I say it again? You save the country from an All White Stripper syndrome. One that has plagued burlesque stages for far too long, in too many places. So donate a dollar. Save the Swiss. Show a Black breast.



Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Tell your friends or others you know who are fans of live entertainment. URGE THEM to donate in your name and theirs. And be down with me for life.
Use hashtag #helpsavesweden on twitter and add me @akynos - spread the world! the Swiss needs me!
Come to one of my performances, and slide the money in my gstring. see here ---> http://ymlp.com/zZRfla

I'm a sex worker activist, spread the word to the groups you know. Post it to your sites and blogs! 
Even if the campaign has ended you can still logon to www.akynos.com and contribute there. Just click on the contact me option on the bottom left of the page.

One brown boob at a time. One dollar at a time. Help save Sweden. Black boobs forever!

story:
NOTE: We're also receiving direct donations by check, which have added $1450 to the Campaign Total (upper right on this page) as of May 7.


SHORT VERSION
Control Group Productions needs your support for our new work 'Salon Romantik, op. 5: CREATION' - a series of living physical/digital/embodied installations. Themography: originality, ownership, craft, ART, the birth process, evolution, the instinct to change our world; individual genius vs. collaborative cultivation - an implosion of the modern artist ethos.

Performances at the Studio Theater at the Denver Center for the Performing Arts, June 13-15, 2014, hosted by Denver Theatre District - the first event of its kind to happen on DCPA campus! And the event is a prototype for future curations of local contemporary and avant garde performance, so our success will have lasting impact on Denver's cultural scene.

We want to meet this great opportunity and outstanding presenting support with a truly stunning piece of live art. Your support will pay for the design materials and personnel to do it!


FULL VERSION
Control Group’s Salon Romantik project dismantles artistic genres and cultural contents in a series of 5 works that cut to the core of what live art can do in our world. From stage to art party to outdoor sites, the work delves into its uniquely crafted environments and transforms them powerfully and exquisitely through a succession of explorations of Romanticism – the anti-rational, individualistic, passionate antithesis to Reason, civility, and the myth of perpetual progress.
No final, didactically delivered conclusions here, but we’re smashing things together real hard, and the results are spectacular!: immersive, surreal, transformative experiences that have left audiences gleefully reeling and (so we hear) hungry for more.

‘Salon Romantik, op. 5: CREATION’ is the final work in the series (note: it’s coming out before #4, which is in process on a slower burn). It cuts straight to the heart of the Romantic movement: the godlike nature of the ARTIST, who alone among men creates his precious works of exquisite beauty directly from the unique genius of his unfettered imagination. We’re smashing that stale and more than a bit problematic formulation against a collaborative/ecological model: the powerful natural processes of birth and evolution, the simple magnificence of biology at work. The result: a gallery of living physical/digital/embodied installations, by turns delicate and explosive, featuring work not only by Control Group but also Sweet Edge dance and several other truly righteous Denver artists.

And did we mention that it’s being presented at the Studio Loft at DCPA, hosted by the Denver Theatre District?? This is a REALLY BIG DEAL for us – an opportunity for massive visibility and impact with our work, and a chance to have a major, long-lasting effect on how our city uses its largest performing arts institution.

I’m not kidding – Denver Theatre District views this presentation as a potential prototype for future presentations of this type of highly innovative, finely crafted, unconventional, highly contemporary performance. So, yes, your support for this particular project stands to have a pretty huge effect.

And with the presentation hosted by DTD and the rehearsal process facilitated by Control Group's residency at Colorado Conservatory of Dance, every dollar donated here (and all box office profit) goes to MAKING THE ART – paying our artists and creating the world of the performance.

As you look through our giving levels, please remember that this is a non-profit endeavor. Our thank-you gifts are much less in cash value than what we are asking you give in support of this project. We hope that you give generously because you believe in the work and in the value of a locally grown and operating Colorado avant garde arts scene.

Thank you.

EVER UPWARD.

story:
ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGN

We’re harunalee, an experimental theatre company based in Brooklyn NY, and we have two incredible opportunities to share with you.

Our show MEMORY RETROGRADE has been offered public presentations by two major Off-Broadway theaters. Even more exciting, we’ve been able to accept both offers so that the greater NYC theater community can be a part of our most ambitious work to date.

This show has evolved over the past three years through performances at Little Theater, Danspace/Food For Thought, and a two year residency at BAX|Brooklyn Arts Exchange. Through our persistent and committed work to develop this show, we have now been offered two simultaneous opportunities that might not normally converge: three performances of MEMORY RETROGRADE in December as part of Ars Nova’s Maker’s Lab, and two performances in January as part of The Under the Radar Festival's INCOMING! Series while partaking in The Public's Devised Theater Working Group. 

Combined, we will have five performances of MEMORY RETROGRADE across two theaters, bringing our work to new audiences at Ars Nova and The Public, and marking our first inclusion in an APAP showcase presentation. This opens the door to the pursuit of a long-time company goal: touring the theater we make to other cities in the US and around the world. 

For this to dream to materialize, we are currently seeking funding for: materials, production costs, and the compensation of professional performers, designers and technicians who are integral to this collaboration process.

In a moment when so many important causes and cultural organizations need our support, we recognize that the ability to also support the arts is a privilege that not everyone can afford. But if you have the resources to help create a better world in more ways than one, we hope you can throw your hat in our ring. Even the smallest donation makes an enormous difference. 

 

WHO WE ARE

harunalee is an ensemble of theater makers and designers who collaborate across artistic disciplines to create experimental plays and performances helmed by Kristine Haruna Lee. With an eye for handmade and craft objects, they create epic visual landscapes that physically accompany Lee’s text. Since 2010, they’ve created six original works: Memory Retrograde, to the left of the pantry and under the sugar shack, War Lesbian, Drunkfish Oceanrant, Plum de Force and Strange Worlds in my Mind.

Their work has been developed/presented by Ars Nova’s Maker's Lab, Brooklyn Arts Exchange Artist Residency, La MaMa Club, Bushwick Starr Propeller Project Series, Dixon Place Mondo Cane! Residency & Commission, JACK, York College Performing and Fine Arts, Prelude Festival, New Dramatists, Asian American Writer’s Workshop, Danspace/Food for Thought, Little Theater, Target Margin Lab and Ars Nova’s ANT Fest. They are currently part of The Public’s Devised Theater Working Group, and have been supported by The Indie Theater Fund, The Mental Insight Foundation, Lower Manhattan Cultural Council Arts Grant for their collaboration with Built for Collapse, and the Lotos Foundation. 
 
harunalee is Stivo Arnoczy, Sasha Arutuynova, Karen Boyer, Andrew R. Butler, Greg Laffey, Sarah Lurie, Lauren Swan-Potras and Kristine Haruna Lee.

Read harunalee's statement on Equity + Social Justice.

 

ABOUT MEMORY RETROGRADE

The discovery of a pocket watch in a timeworn attic catapults a pair of old lovers through an epic expanse of generations and landscapes—the Venetian Renaissance, an Egyptian burial, a 1970s doctor’s office, and a virtual reality forest in the near future. In this dioramic triptych of realism, post-modern historic farce, and media performance, harunalee confronts the ways memory and trauma are racialized and gendered across time. MEMORY RETROGRADE negotiates the inextricable relationship between personal and cultural memory, and transforms the English language into an emotional territory, where heightened experience is synonymous with the irrationality of words and language.


WHAT WE NEED

To produce MEMORY RETROGRADE for these dual presentations, harunalee needs a total budget of $18,095. 

We are receiving significant in-kind support such as rehearsal space, marketing/publicity, technicians, FOH staff, and venue rental, as well as basic remuneration for artists from the institutions who are presenting us. These costs are equivalent to about  $10,000 from Ars Nova’s Makers Lab. In addition, we are receiving an honorarium of $2,000 from The Public’s Under The Radar Festival. 

This total of $12,000 is not enough to even pay the artists and technicians fair wages who will bring this show to life. The combined wages for all bodies hired for this project amounts to $14,715. The additional cost of set, costume, and lighting materials as well as transportation, contingency, and donation processing fees is $3,380, bringing us to a total of $18,095. Minus the $12,000 of institutional support, and we are left with $6,125 to raise via individual donations from supporters like you! 

If you’d like to see our full line-by-line budget, it’s available online here. 

Any size of donation is meaningful, and donating is not the only way you can support our work. The most significant thing you can do is to come see our show! Ticket are now available for our performances at Under The Radar INCOMING! Series, and tickets to our Maker’s Lab performances at Ars Nova will be available November 10th. Regardless of whether you can offer us a financial pledge, we hope you’ll share this campaign, and publicly show your support for our work and the artists who make it. 

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Any theatrical production carries the risk of an unexpected and uncontrollable calamity, but in terms of the currently slated production, the risks are low. Both presenters are professional off-broadway theaters with many decades of combined experience, and the wheels of production for both presentations are already smoothly in motion. 

Staging the same show in two different venues in the span of a single month presents many challenges: keeping two production timelines, designing and staging a piece for two spaces, transferring the show from one venue to the next, and marketing both effectively and clearly. We see this challenge as a preparation for the similar feat of touring a show to differing venues on a tight schedule. This is a particularly apt challenge, since touring is a goal that we hope to move towards via this production. 

As we enter our fifth year as a cooperative company, we carry with us a wealth of experience and relationships that help us to surmount challenges and minimize risks. This is our fifth crowdsourced campaign, and sits in the middle range of the amounts we have raised in the past. Furthermore, we have the administrative and institutional assistance of both the Under The Radar Festival’s Devised Theatre Working Group, and Ars Nova’s Maker’s Lab to help guide us in meeting our goals and mounting a successful production. 

We promise to communicate with the same transparency that we have demonstrated in this campaign, and keep you abreast of all developments. In addition to campaign updates, we’d love for you to follow along via our instagram and facebook pages.

Thank you so much for reading about our campaign! We hope you’ll be able to make a donation so we can bring MEMORY RETROGRADE to life!

story:
We've had such a fun time hosting a room party the last couple years, that we're back.

With this being the 20th anniversary of CONvergence, it had us strolling down the vestiges of our memories to 1999. There was a lot of craziness going on.

Would our computers be able to handle the tick over to the year 2000?

Would our preparation bunkers hold off the apocalypse?

Did we have enough water?

Was Prince wanting to party like the future, or what?

We are the Earworm collective (Garrick/Liz/Maggie/Trish/Wade) and we've been attendees at CONvergence for the past 10 years (or so). We've hosted a party room the past 2 years, and this will be magical #3 (it is the magic number afterall). The more money we can raise, the more amenities the room can offer. There's party room rental, decorating, drinks, and more.

Luckily, in the future, nothing goes to waste, and due to our own lucrative investments in The Stuff company, drone technology, and appropriate handling of the wonderful tips from last year, we only need to raise about 1/3 of the cost to host a room.

Rough budget breakdown (will be tweaked as we go)

Cabana Room rental - $800

A brand new bar - $300

Decorations - $400

Drinks & cups - $900

Spiffs for donors - $100

Flyers and Posters - $200

Indiegogo fees - $200

Total: $2,900

Last year we contracted with a local artist to come up with a logo for our room, He did an amazing job on the Earworm logo, and Singing Sandworm. This year he's graciously agreed to design a poster. 

Also, what says 90's like pinback buttons? That's right, some of our donation levels include these wonderful buttons that you can attach to your lanyards. We're so excited to have a button making party!

Also, because it's an Earworm for many people, there might be a pop-up "Hamilton" sing-along during one of the convention days (Don't judge us too harshly on the timing. We know it's not from the new century but... timey wimey).

story:
Continuing the fine tradition started by John Lennon & Yoko Ono, Alfred & Alma Hitchcock, and Patty Hearst & the SLA, Emily Owens & Hollis James joined forces to create projects they are passionate about. Each darkly comic show will be a secret handshake for cool kids--a pop-culture pastiche, presented with punk-rock attitude. 

We are dedicated to blending the seriously funny and the hysterically serious to provide NYC with the Viking funeral it deserves. Here's our pledge to you: No productions over 90 minutes. No shows with an all-white cast. And no revivals--which means you’ll have to get your Shakespeare where you get your marijuana, in the park. 

Hot Tramp's inaugural production is a new comedy by Hollis James (co-creator of the hit web series, Teachers Lounge), inspired by his knock-down-drag-out battle with drug addiction. It's about a guy named Jack, his friend Kyle, and Kyle's friend cocaine. Thanks to his new friends, Jack's life quickly begins to spiral out of control. He loses his job, his girlfriend, his health, and all sense of personal hygiene. Will Jack find the strength to get his life back on track or will Kyle ultimately win?

What We Need & What You Get

Unfortunately we're not independently wealthy. We don't have trust funds or generously rich benefactors. We are proud to present KYLE as a co-production with FRIGID New York @ Horse Trade, which does eliminate one of our biggest expenses (theater rental). But there is still a ton of stuff we're going to have to figure out how to pay for. Hopefully that's where you come in! 

We need to:

  • Pay our actors 
  • Pay our designers 
  • Pay our stage manager
  • Hire a photographer to take press photos
  • Buy props, set pieces, and costumes
  • Design and print postcards, programs, and other promotional materials
  • Rent rehearsal space
We're grateful for donations of any size. In exchange for your generosity, we offer exciting perks such as tickets to see the show in March, a poster signed by the cast and creative team, a tote bag sporting our super-hot pinup girl logo on the front, a drug-themed CD soundtrack curated by playwright Hollis James, and an invite to our opening night cast party (location TBA). 
 
We look forward to seeing you at the theater!

What We Need & What You Get
Unfortunately we're not independently wealthy. We don't have trust funds or generously rich benefactors. We are proud to present KYLE as a co-production with FRIGID New York @ Horse Trade, which does eliminate one of our biggest expenses (theater rental). But there is still a ton of stuff we're going to have to figure out how to pay for. Hopefully that's where you come in! 
We need to:

Pay our actors 
Pay our designers 
Pay our stage manager
Hire a photographer to take press photos
Buy props, set pieces, and costumes
Design and print postcards, programs, and other promotional materials
Rent rehearsal space

We're grateful for donations of any size. In exchange for your generosity, we offer exciting perks such as tickets to see the show in March, a poster signed by the cast and creative team, a tote bag sporting our super-hot pinup girl logo on the front, a drug-themed CD soundtrack curated by playwright Hollis James, and an invite to our opening night cast party (location TBA). 
 We look forward to seeing you at the theater!

story:
About Us

Eternal Theatre Collective is a youth not-for-profit organization dedicated to providing opportunities to young performing artists between the ages of 13 and 25. Too often young talent is overlooked in the performing arts world because they haven't gained enough real-world experience to book the work they need. We believe that young people are just as capable of creating amazing and beautiful theatre - especially when they collaborate with each other and learn from the process.

Everyone we work with, from the actors to the designers, the creative team to the managerial team and even the board of directors is under 25 years old. We offer fantastic opportunities for youth to experiment and grow in their craft in a professional and collaborative environment.

     "A company like this is rare – I find most cast those who are recent graduates, have been in    the industry for years or (when necessary) children under 10 years of age.

     This is difficult for young artists in this industry as we are hired based off experience (not only talent), but what happens when you cannot find experience or roles that fit your age range? Eternal provides this. It does not matter the colour of your skin or your size: it is your personality and the character you bring to the show."

          -Hailey Fowler, Choreographer for 13

 

The challenge with our work is that we don't have huge funding powers, which is why we always count on generous people like YOU to help us continue to create opportunities and make dreams a reality for young people in our community.

This summer, we're doing a musical with a rock score, so we really need microphones to be able to amplify the voices of our actors to be heard over the band. Renting microphones is an expensive task which is why we're asking YOU to help us reach our goal. With YOUR help, we can ensure that all the talented young actors in our production will have their voices heard loud and clear - and for many of them, it will be the first time that will happen on a professional stage.

   

  "Growing up with dreams of working in "big-city" theatre, I am incredibly grateful to have the chance to work with ETC to turn my own ideas and designs into the sets for 13. I came to ETC with very little training and experience in set design and construction, but a strong interest in learning more and being able to put on an incredible show. 13 has given me and the other youths of ETC the chance to participate in a professional and constructive environment, where we can learn and showcase our skills for the thriving theatre community in Vancouver."

           - Bailey Madison Kaye, Set Designer for 13    

 

What We Need & What You Get

Microphones are going to cost us around $700 to rent for the entire period of the production - but any funding we can get to help offset the costs makes a HUGE difference! If we end up raising more than our goal, all extra funding will go towards the costumes, props and set budgets for the show, to give us the resources to make our production better than ever imagined!

 

     "Being in this show means a lot to be because it has given me to opportunity to work with some extremely talented youth. Either it be my fellow performers who I am already so blown away by, or others who work tirelessly behind the scenes, I know this show is special because of everyone's passionate effort. Being given an opportunity to perform in one of my favorite musicals, and to have it done by such an incredible group of youth, makes me so happy and sure about the future of theatre in Vancouver."

          - Kendra Cordick, Kendra in 13

 

In exchange for your generosity - we have some really exciting and fun rewards available.

For any donation of $1 - we'll give you all our eternal love and gratitude (and we're young so there's a lot of it to give!) AND we'll send you a personal shout out through our social media channels so we can let all our followers know how fantastic you are!

For any donation of $5 - you'll get all of the above AND high fives whenever we see you AND on social media! Don't know what a social media high five is? Donate and find out!

For any donation of $15 - you'll get all of the above AND a free treat at concession when you come and see our show in August!

For any donation of $25 - you'll get all of the above AND a personalized thank you video from one of our amazing company members telling YOU how much you've changed their life!

For any donation of $50 - you'll get all of the above AND our talented cast and creative team will re-write one of the songs in 13 to be about YOU! On top of that you'll get a personalized video of our talented company singing YOUR song to you! Wow!

For any donation of $100 - you'll get all of the above AND a free ticket to 13 for any night of your choosing!

 

    Your Impact

         "Being part of "13: The Musical" allows me and the rest of the people involved in the production to inspire those to get out of their comfort zone and follow their dreams, because if all of us can by being part of this production, why can't they? Being part of 13 also allows me to take a role in showing that the theatre community that is becoming increasingly diverse. It would be greatly appreciated to receive help fundraising so that Eternal Theatre Collective could help us better achieve our goals in inspiring others."

              - Jeremy Cruz, Malcolm in 13    

     

    ETC is a fairly young company, but we've already been lucky enough to have seven successful projects in the past, including 2 cabaret concerts and 4 amazing short plays. None of our success would be possible however without the generous support of our community.

         "Because of 13 I have made such amazing new friends and have gotten to work with incredible talent. With your help and donations we will be able to bring this heartfelt musical to life."

              - Maya Piscopo, Molly in 13

     

    In donating to our campaign you are not only fuelling the dreams and growth of these young people, but you are also feeding the passion, learning and love of the craft of the next generation of theatre makers, ensuring that Vancouver will have a thriving theatre community long into the future.

         "I think theatre is important because of the way it brings people together the way that 13 did for me and us. It's so special to share all these hilarious and memorable moments with such friendly and amazing people on and off stage!"

              - William Davis, Simon in 13

       

      Other Ways to Help

           "My hypothesis for this show is attendees are going to be surprised by the high calibre the show presents. Donate to Eternal Theatre Collective to continue this legacy of opportunities for young artists- I can guarantee you it is greatly appreciated and you will not be disappointed."

                - Hailey Fowler, Choreographer for 13

       

      If you can't donate to our campaign this time around, but still want to help - don't fear! There are tons of things you can do to help support out show:

      Share the campaign on social media, and talk about Eternal Theatre Collective with your friends and family!

      Check out our website at www.eternaltheatre.com and subscribe to our newsletter!

      Most importantly, buy tickets to come see our show in August! It's going to be a fantastic show, thanks to you!

      With your help we can get the word out about the work we're doing; we'll be able to achieve all our goals together and bring fantastic opportunites to young artists in Greater Vancouver for decades to come!

       

      13 runs August 9-12 at 7pm at the Revue Stage on Granville Island.

      Tickets are $17 for youth and $22 general.

      Tickets available at: http://eternaltheatre.bpt.me/

story:
Introducing ZANNA REDUX

ZANNA REDUX, a musical written by Tim Acito,  takes place in Heartsville, USA, a wholesome Midwestern town known for its civic pride, good old-fashioned family values… and all-gay population.  When two high school seniors are discovered to be secretly heterosexual, the town is thrown into chaos, hearts are broken, and everyone is forced to confront the biggest questions of today – What do I stand for?  What is America?  And will this magic wand clash with my prom dress? 

Thoroughly ironic and shamelessly sincere, this big-hearted fable mixes pop, rock, funk and techno to remind us that finding ourselves requires remembering those we’ve left out.  

The show is a modern version of Acito's original work, ZANNA DON'T, which debuted off-Broadway in 2002. The show went on to be performed off-West End and internationally. 

Who We Are & What We're Doing

We're bringing ZANNA REDUX to life with an updated script and new songs.

We are a nonprofit, called The Broadway Dreams Foundation, that provides unparalleled access, mentorship and opportunity to students of all ages and backgrounds looking to fulfill their dream of making it to Broadway. Our alumni can be seen performing on stages internationally, including on and off Broadway. 

Our reprisal and update of ZANNA REDUX will be fully cast from students and alumni of The Broadway Dreams Foundation from an array of ethnic backgrounds, in order to give our students yet another incredible shot at fulfilling their dreams and the opportunity to learn from workshopping a professional musical first hand. 

Every summer, we host week-long intensives across the country and allow local students to learn from Broadway stars, coaches, directors, choreographers and talent agents. This year, we're looking to bring the creators of ZANNA REDUX on our summer intensive tour with us to New York City, Toronto and Philadelphia in order to provide even greater opportunity to even more students. We'll workshop throughout the summer and fall, and potentially bring our show to Broadway!

What We Need & What You Get

Why are we crowdfunding?

  • Cover travel costs for the ZANNA REDUX creative team in order to take them with us on tour 
  • Cover production costs of workshopping the show in different cities
  • Write new music and rewrite much of the original script
What's in it for you?
  • Smile for supporting an impactful nonprofit AND a unique piece of theater!
  • Supporting ZANNA REDUX makes you an integral part of the production and our perks are designed to make you feel as such! Get your name noted in our programming, represent the cause with BDF swag or a signed poster, join us for private workshops or rehearsals, and, finally, sit for lunch with an accomplished performing arts professional.

The Impact

Your support will help our creative team and The Broadway Dreams Foundation to workshop new material for this very special show, and hopefully bring it to a Broadway stage. You'll also be creating an invaluable educational and creative experience for aspiring students from all socioeconomic backgrounds across the country. 

We're producing ZANNA REDUX because we believe in the project and the message that it bring to the table -- for students and audiences alike. Our organization believes in bringing unparalleled educational and creative opportunities to students so that they can live out their dreams. The musical promotes acceptance and the ability for individuals to live their own truth and fulfill their dreams. It's a message that we expect to leave a lasting impression on audiences. 

For our team, it's important to remind audiences that our culture has taken tremendous steps toward equal rights and awareness of differences. However, there is still a long way to go!

Our creative team is tried and tested in the Broadway community and our Broadway Dreams Foundation alumni have found incredible success on Broadway stages. We're confident in this project and it's track for success. We hope you'll join us!

Challenges

The most significant challenge for our creative team has been to make sure that the piece is entertaining and enjoyable, in order for it to resonate with the younger demographic. If it isn't that, it's not going to teach any of the lessons that we hope to instill!

Other Ways You Can Help

The Broadway Dreams Foundation is constantly seeking new opportunities to bring to our students. Learn more about our organization, classes and intensives that you can take part in, and ways that you can volunteer or donate. 

Visit us at www.mybroadwaydreams.com!

story:
What? Who?

Experimentorium is looking for completion funding for its new production The Engagement.

    Founded at RADA in 2017, Experimentorium is an award-winning film and theatre production company.

    What we have

    The Engagement tells the true story of how alcoholism tore apart a couple and their family. The play had a successful performance in Brighton and now Experimentorium are partnering with Steaming to bring the piece to London.

    Initial support has been pledged by the Carne Trust.

      What we need

      In our latest film, Fragments, we interpreted our ideas through available locations and technology and the film has gone on to win awards in numerous international film festivals. In The Enemies (our most recent theatre production), we used real household waste as set-dressing to give more immediacy and recognisability to the political message. We engage with production limitations and make them work to our advantage, we know what we can do without and consequently, what we need. 

      The campaign for The Engagement aims for £1,000 completion funding to cover some or all of:

      • Rehearsal space
      • Insurance
      • Stunt props
         

      These practical elements are the basic essentials needed to elevate the piece in a manner that is both safe and effective.

      With this completion funding we will be able to afford appropriate rehearsal facilities in London for us to develop and devise material in a safe and efficient manner. We will always rely on physical work to tell a story over full sets or naturalistic production values but this means that the materials we do use must be absolutely reliable to keep our performers safe. In line with this aim, we need to fully insure the production and to ensure that everybody (our performers, and indeed you our audience) can relax and concentrate on the piece, in peace.

      If we don't reach the amount required the money raised will go firstly towards insurance and props and then rehearsal space.

      What you get

      We are offering rewards at various levels in return for your support. These include materials used in the show, copies of the script, digital versions of the performance and thank yous on our company social media.

      Impact

      This piece was selected for performance at the Bread and Roses because of the importance of the message and story.  Research from King's College London, published in July, suggests that 1 in 5 people admitted to UK hospitals, drinks in a harmful way and that 1 in 10 are alcohol-dependant. With cuts to rehab services affecting the help those who suffer with alcoholism can access, this issue is more pressing than ever.The Engagement is a true story and also not a unique story, with your help we can make a contribution to the national conversation.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      We understand that you can't help every project going, we are in the same position. We'd much rather you came to see the show and if you can give us a like and a share along the way it would be greatly appreciated. 
      Please feel free to drop us a line at laura@experimentoriumproductions.com to ask about tickets or other ways to support the production.
